title: 2015 Toyota Prius c Four
subTitle: It's all about that fuel economy.
promoTeaserSmall: It's all about that fuel economy.
promoTeaser: It's all about that fuel economy.
metaDescription: It's all about that fuel economy.

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-passenger, front-wheel-drive hybrid hatchback
Trim levels: One, Two, Three, Four
Base price: $19,540 (Prius c One); $25,310 (Prius c Four) (prices include destination charge)
This car: $25,600
Engine: 1.5-liter four-cylinder engine, 73 horsepower, with Toyota Hybrid Synergy Drive and Eco/EV modes and nickel-metal-hydride battery
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: 53 mpg city/46 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars and notation of Safety Concern in front crash testing; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick
My favorite standard feature: Rearview camera
Options I can’t live without: Heated seats (standard on Prius c Four)
Notable standard features on this model: Power tilt and slide moonroof, heated outside mirrors, integrated LED foglights, SofTex fabric-trimmed seats and steering wheel
Notable options on this model: Sixteen-inch tires and aluminum wheels ($300)
You might also be considering (prices include destination charge):
2016 Ford C-Max Hybrid SE ($25,045)
2015 Honda Civic Hybrid ($25,555)

By now, the Toyota Prius is very well established on the roads of the United States, although this one, the smallest in the Prius family, is more of a novelty. Despite the fact that the Prius—in all of its various sizes and versions—is a hybrid, it's solidly in the mainstream. The fan base for the Toyota Prius is sincere, unironic, and motivated by only the best environmentalist intentions. Having said that, there are those who might, let's say, poke a little fun at Prius drivers. But we won't. Why?

Fifty miles to the gallon, that's why. Yes, you can tootle around town in this car, merrily knowing you're getting up to twice the fuel economy of the majority of big cars and SUVs around you. The Toyota Prius c, introduced in 2012, is down at the cheap end of the scale for hybrids. If the Tesla Model S is an indulgence at $70,000, the Prius c is downright frugal with its starting price of $20,375 (including destination charge). Looked at that way, perhaps a Prius driver has a point when he or she starts feeling a little holier-than-thou?

It’s small, yes, especially compared with the larger Prius and Prius V, but the Prius c has plenty of size mates in the Fiat 500, Ford Fiesta and C-Max, Scion xB, Chevrolet Spark, and many others. It’s not exactly a powerhouse with its 73 horsepower, but for around-town driving, many people will feel that’s an acceptable compromise.

The Prius c can be driven in EV Drive mode, in which the electric motor drives the vehicle, powered by the battery, for short distances—and we mean truly short distances of under a half mile. In Eco mode, the climate control system’s operation is limited and the car’s power is slightly reduced to save energy. Battery regeneration happens during braking through Toyota’s justly famous Hybrid Synergy Drive system. What you need to know as a Prius driver is limited, since the hybrid system’s operation is basically seamless and unnoticeable. If you want to geek out, there are readouts and scores to obsess over on the upper information screen.

The Prius c comes in One, Two, Three, and Four trim levels, echoing the structure of the larger Prius and Prius v models. The differences between One and Four are not tremendous, especially considering the $5,000 price differential, meaning that the less luxury-minded might want to save that money and get the entry-level Prius c. Even that base model has Bluetooth and steering-wheel-mounted audio controls, a rear wiper and spoiler, and all the same mechanicals. With the top model, though, you add heated front seats and outside mirrors, integrated LED fog lights, a moonroof, and special eight-spoke wheels. All but the base model get cruise control and 60/40 percent split folding rear seats, and the Three adds push-button start and Entune premium audio with navigation.

It all sounds like a really good deal, but don’t be mistaken: this is a small, light, inexpensive car without a lot of power. You will feel it if you try to, say, go out on the expressway and put on a burst of power. There isn’t much of that. It’s cute, stylish, and especially in the bright green of the car we tested, has a sense of fun. But in little ways, such as the thin, hard seats, the flimsy USB port cover, and the old-school gearshift, you feel the economy. For this price, and with this gas mileage, it is going to be worth it to a lot of people.

The Verdict:

You should consider buying the Prius c for three reasons only: size, price, and fuel economy. If you are considering ever driving children on a regular basis, this is probably not the Prius for you. If you do a lot of highway driving, you might prefer the standard Prius or the largest in the lineup, the Prius v. If you prize comfort, power, or any combination of the two, you'll want a car with more horsepower and a cushier interior. But if you have made up your mind you want a hybrid, need the price to be affordable, and don't care how fancy or how spacious it is, have a look at this one. For the right person, it will feel just green, cheap, and small enough.

title: 2016 Mazda 6
subTitle: The mid-size sedan that will be as fun to drive as it is to look at.
promoTeaserSmall: The mid-size sedan that will be as fun to drive as it is to look at.
promoTeaser: The mid-size sedan that will be as fun to drive as it is to look at.
metaDescription: The mid-size sedan that will be as fun to drive as it is to look at.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive sedan
Price range: $21,495 - $30,195
Trim levels: Sport, Touring, Grand Touring
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 184 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed manual, six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: Manual: 25 mpg city/37 mpg highway; automatic: 26/38 mpg; automatic w/i-ELOOP: 28/40 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus
Our favorite standard feature: Push-button start
Notable standard features on this model:Leather-trimmed steering wheel and shift knob, seven-inch infotainment touchscreen (all models); rearview camera (all but manual-transmission Sport model); LED headlights (Touring and Grand Touring)
Notable options on this model: Power moonroof, heated seats
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Hyundai Sonata, Nissan Altima, Toyota Camry, Volkswagen Passat

The Mazda 6 has received rave reviews since its launch for being a spacious, quality, efficient, and pretty sedan, and that all holds true for 2016. With added options that make it a bit more posh, the Mazda 6 appeals to buyers across the socioeconomic spectrum. A seven-inch touchscreen and Sport mode buttons now come standard on all three trim levels, and Parchment leather has replaced Almond leather in the Grand Touring. The optional Technology package include heated seats and navigation. You have one engine option—a 2.5-liter four-cylinder—but two choices of transmission: six-speed manual and six-speed automatic. The Mazda 6 received five stars from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and is a Top Safety Pick Plus, the top rating of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. With 98 cubic feet of passenger volume and 15 cubic feet of cargo space, the Mazda 6 is no minivan, but it is roomy enough.

New for 2016: Electronic parking brake
Upgraded center console, dash, and armrest design

More on the 2016 Mazda 6

Jean's Driveway: 2016 Mazda 6 Touring

title: 2016 Mazda CX-3
subTitle: The Mazda of compact crossovers. Good things come in small packages.
promoTeaserSmall: The Mazda of compact crossovers. Good things come in small packages.
promoTeaser: The Mazda of compact crossovers. Good things come in small packages.
metaDescription: The Mazda of compact crossovers. Good things come in small packages.

pageElements.text:
Mazda CX-3

Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive compact crossover
Price range: $19,960 - $24,990
Trim levels: Sport, Touring, Grand Touring
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 146 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: Sport, Touring, Grand Touring: 29 mpg city/35 mpg highway; Sport AWD, Touring AWD, Grand Touring AWD: 27/32 mpg
Safety ratings: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: 18-inch aluminum alloy wheels
Notable standard features on this model: 18-inch alloy wheels, LED lighting, heated side mirrors, power moonroof, leather seats with suede inserts, navigation system with voice command, seven-speaker Bose audio
Notable options on this model: Smart City Brake Support, all-weather floor mats, Mazda Mobile Start
You might also be considering: Buick Encore, Chevrolet Trax, Fiat 500X, Honda HR-V, Jeep Renegade, Kia Soul, Nissan Juke

The compact crossover game is one nearly every automaker is trying to get in on, and Mazda came onto the field at full sprint with the all-new CX-3. Attractive, sharp, and responsive, the CX-3 brings together classic Mazda handling and consumer-demanded space. You can take on twisting roads with full control and style while lugging camping supplies, new furniture, or friends and family. There is only one choice of engine – a 2.0-liter four-cylinder with 146 horsepower – and one transmission – six-speed automatic with paddle shifters. Don’t let the limited engine and transmission options get you down, though. The CX-3 comes with a whole slew of notable standard features, including LED lighting, power moonroof, leather seats with suede inserts, and best of all, navigation. The options aren’t quite as exciting. When searching for the best of both worlds in style and practicality, people now turn to the compact crossover. And thanks to its high-quality features and sharp design, the CX-3 will top the compact crossover list.

New for 2016:
The CX-3 is a new model.


More about the 2016 Mazda CX-3

Review: 2016 Mazda CX-3

The quality most people first think of when it comes to Mazda? Fun to drive. The CX-5 confirms the stereotype, even as a crossover. With two choices of engines—a 2.0-liter or 2.5-liter—and six-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission choices give you some flexibility when shopping for a family-size vehicle. Additionally, all of the automatic-equipped models come standard with a Sport mode button. Mazda Connect infotainment is standard on the Touring and Grand Touring models and included in the CX-5 Sport Rear Camera package on the Sport. Everything about the interior is comfortable and easy to use, from the materials on the door trim to the placement of gauges and controls. The CX-5’s full slate of top Good ratings got it a Top Safety Pick Plus rating from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.
New for 2016: New grille and fog light surrounds, electronic parking brake

subTitle: The full-size Cadillac meets the electronic future.
promoTeaserSmall: The full-size Cadillac meets the electronic future.
promoTeaser: The full-size Cadillac meets the electronic future.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive full-size luxury sedan
Price range: $46,290 – $67,775; Vsport $64,765 – $73.315 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: Standard, Luxury, Premium, Platinum; Vsport: Premium, Platinum
Engines: 3.6-liter V-6, 305 horsepower; Vsport: twin-turbocharged 3.6-liter V-6, 410 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/28 mpg highway (front-wheel drive); 17/26 mpg (all-wheel drive); 16/24 mpg (Vsport)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA): ; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS):
Notable standard features: Magnetic Ride Control suspension
Notable options: Head-up display (standard on Premium and Platinum), rear-seat entertainment system, panoramic sunroof
You might also be considering: Audi A6, Lexus ES

Technology is the story in what's new for Cadillac's big luxury sedan, the 2016 Cadillac XTS, this year. Apple CarPlay gives you access to many of your smartphone apps on the Cadillac's Cue infotainment screen. There's also inductive wireless phone charging for that phone. There's OnStar with 4G LTE on-board Wi-Fi that lets you and your passengers use wireless Internet on up to ten devices. Best of all, there's Surround Vision to give you a 360-degree view above and around your XTS. It's part of the optional Driver Awareness package, which pulls out all the active-safety stops with lane keeping and blind spot assistance, rear cross-traffic alert, forward collision alert, and the famous General Motors Safety Alert Seat to buzz you on the upper leg when you're straying from your lane.

But this Cadillac is also about space and comfort: the 40 inches of rear-seat space and the 18 cubic feet in the trunk will make this feel like the full-size sedans of old (almost). For those interested in Cadillac's increasingly strong reputation for performance, there's the Vsport with its twin-turbo V-6 making 410 horsepower.

title: 5 Cool Things about the Kia Sedona
subTitle: It's the little things—and the business-class comfort—that make the 2016 Kia Sedona SXL more than a minivan.
promoTitle: 5 Cool Things about the Kia Sedona
promoTeaserSmall: The little things and the business-class comfort make the 2016 Kia Sedona more than a minivan.
promoTeaser: The little things and the business-class comfort make the 2016 Kia Sedona more than a minivan.
keywords: 5 Cool Things about the Kia Sedona
metaTitle: 5 Cool Things about the Kia Sedona - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The little things and the business-class comfort make the 2016 Kia Sedona more than a minivan.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Kia has a plan to help its Sedona thrive even as overall minivan sales continue to decline, faced with American's love affair with the sport-utility vehicle. It starts with the business-class comfort we found in the 2016 Kia Sedona SXL, the top-of-the-line model from Kia ($44,690 as tested, including destination charge). Kia refers to the Sedona as a multipurpose vehicle, or MPV, to try to distance it from the negative image of a minivan. Minivans are actually true utility vehicles anyway, and this one is angling to be synonymous with passenger comfort.

The Sedona received a complete redesign in 2015 that has been well received. The exterior design has moved toward the aesthetic of a crossover utility vehicle. From head on, it isn't immediately identifiable as a minivan, showcasing the smartly designed tiger-nose grille that defines the modern Kia lineup. The side profile pushes the crossover effect with shorter front and rear overhangs. The strategy seems to be working: Sedona sales have improved significantly since the 2015 model hit the showroom floor.

Thanks to these efforts by Kia, the Sedona is arguably the best-looking minivan in the segment, but it may lose its sash soon. The segment sales leaders—Toyota Sienna, Honda Odyssey, and Chrysler Town & Country—are all set to bring out completely redesigned models for 2017. But while the sun is still shining on it, here are five cool things about the 2016 Kia Sedona SXL.

1. Reclining seats. I spent some time over the long weekend lounging in the First Class Lounge Seating in the Sedona's second row, and I have never been as comfortable on a road trip before. Yes, I drove, too, but I was jonesing for the fully reclining center row captain's chairs the entire time. The seats are only found on the top SXL trim level. A leg rest flips out, fully supporting your legs, and the seat reclines waaaaay back. To afford more space for your legs to fully extend, the entire seat slides back and forth as well as from side to side. I brought along an eyeshade to get maximum comfort, but the SXL comes standard with built-in second- and third-row pull-down sunshades. One caveat: the lounge seats cannot have seat heating or cooling. Also, Kia has a disclaimer that traveling while fully reclined will compromise the effectiveness of the restraint system. So this might give pause to parents.

Warning to parents of large families who need to seat eight: you will have to forfeit the fully reclining second-row seats and go down a trim level to the SX. The eight-seat configuration has a center seat in the second row that folds down and becomes a console when not in use. It can also be completely removed from the vehicle. I personally would consider sending that eighth passenger to boarding school so I could keep the lounge seating. For those who draw the short straw and end up in the third row, it reclines slightly as well. It is split 60/40 and can be stowed in the floor. When storing the second row, the lounge seats take up a large amount of space compared with the standard seats,  which slide forward and fold against the front seats.

It also must be stated that the comfort level is definitely hampered by a rough ride, and to compete with the likes of Toyota and Honda, Kia needs to revisit the suspension before the 2017 models are on sale.

2. Illumination. I am a sucker for lighting, and the Sedona won me over even before I entered the cabin. As you near the car with the key in your pocket, an indented oval around the key pops to life with a lovely blue glow. I must admit that I also like to see the aftermarket lights that shine down under tuner cars. So dismiss my opinion if you are a curmudgeon.

3. Multiple USBs. Continuing the light show are three, yes three (2.1 amp) fast-charging USB ports. Each one glowed red in the dark, and if you listen closely you can hear the Hallelujah Chorus. Gone were the arguments about whose turn it is to charge their device. The auxiliary port also has the guiding red glow. Adding to the electric powerplant on wheels is the standard power plug along with two 115-volt power outlets, one in the center console and another in the cargo area. Who doesn’t want to straighten their hair while flying down the highway? The USB that was positioned behind the front console won praise from the second-row recliners and added to their business class experience. Just like consumer demand in the 1990s brought cupholders to the masses, our tech-driven lives now require USBs for all passengers.

4. Overhead camera. The Surround View Monitor’s series of cameras provides a bird’s-eye view of your vehicle. The overhead view style of monitor is popping up in more and more vehicles, and I cannot say loudly enough how much I love this feature. It automatically activates when the vehicle is in reverse, but there is also a button you can push to turn it on manually. I personally used it many times to make sure I was perfectly placed in a parking spot. No more getting out of the car and realizing that my car is straddling a yellow line. The first time I drove a car with an overhead camera, I was dumbstruck by the technology. It seems like there is a drone flying over your vehicle, but it is just four cameras working together to create the view. Genius.

5. Active safety: lane departure and forward collision warning. Both the lane departure and forward collision systems are part of the Technology package in the Kia Sedona SX and SXL ($2,800), but blind spot detection and cross-traffic alert are standard on the SX and SXL and an option on the EX. Yes, the lane departure warning audible alert is annoying, but it could also be a life saver. A minivan is the go-to vehicle for long road trips. And on road trips, drivers often remain behind the wheel for longer hours than common sense suggests is safe. Having your vehicle helicopter-mom your lane keeping is a really useful safety feature. When I was teaching my daughter to drive, reminding her to stay centered in her lane caused enough friction to set a forest on fire. The lane departure warning would have been a godsend. Then it would have been the car nannying her rather than me. It (unlike a helicopter mom) can also be toggled off when you desire.

The forward collision warning system entices me when I think about all the distracted drivers I see as I pilot my vehicle down the road. If every car could have an audible alert when in danger of a collision, it would obviously cut down on accidents. I especially think about texters, whose eyes are off the road for just a tad too long. A vehicle that is vying for families must cocoon the occupants in safety features. It is no longer enough to slap a baby on board sticker in the back window.

images.caption: 2016 Kia Sedona: USB and auxiliary plug.
2016 Kia Sedona: the plug openings are illuminated.
2016 Kia Sedona: more places to plug in.

title: Top Ten from the Tokyo Auto Show
subTitle: The weirdest and most fascinating concepts, plus a few more normal entries from the annual show in Japan.
promoTitle: Top Ten from the Tokyo Auto Show
promoTeaserSmall: The weirdest and most fascinating concepts, plus a few more normal entries from the annual show in Japan.
promoTeaser: The weirdest and most fascinating concepts, plus a few more normal entries from the annual show in Japan.
keywords: Top Ten from the Tokyo Auto Show
metaTitle: Top Ten from the Tokyo Auto Show - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The weirdest and most fascinating concepts, plus a few more normal entries from the annual show in Japan.

pageElements.text:
1. Daihatsu Nori Ori

What’s this? A miniaturized subway car? The design certainly seems to draw on that idea, and there’s almost enough room inside to stand up. The only thing missing is something for straphangers to hang onto. But the Nori Ori takes accessibility a step further. An access ramp extends when the sliding side doors are opened, and there are hinged doors at the rear, with enough room behind the seats for a wheelchair or two.

Ground clearance is minimal—if it weren’t so tall, the Nori Ori would be a lowrider—and the front end design looks like it was inspired by something in a Pixar movie. No word on power, and for all its accessibility this little Daihatsu's dimensions and low-slung chassis don’t seem feasible for production. On the other hand, tiny transportation pods make sense in Japan, and the Nori Ori wouldn’t really look too bizarre in the Tokyo traffic mix.

2. Honda Wander Stand

If you thought the Daihatsu Nori Ori was weird, this little rolling phone booth rates as otherworldly. Yes, there are wheels at all four corners, faired in under those little fenders. Yes, there is propulsion of some sort, probably electric, so you can probably wander, as the name suggests. Preferably on level ground. Maybe at the mall. Honda said the traditional rickshaw was the inspiration. Yes, there are seats in there, for two, and no, you can’t stand. The pod is designed to operate autonomously, so there’s no steering wheel. But there is a rotating joystick that allows some maneuvering, including laterally. Other control functions are accessed on a touchscreen.
Though bizarre, this personal mobility module concept isn’t totally out of the question for some sort of production version. Think retirement communities.

3. Lexus LF-FC

The core of this sexy grand sedan is fuel cell propulsion, with a fuel cell stack under the long hood, hydrogen tanks below the floor, and a battery pack at the rear. The battery powers a trio of electric motors, two inside each of the front wheels and a third driving the rear wheels. Lexus says the system will provide an “exhilarating driving experience.” Parent company Toyota says it is “getting ready to embrace a hydrogen-based society,” but if or when that comes to pass remains to be seen, and not soon.
Other cutting-edge techno elements of the concept package—a holographic center dash console, gesture control, and automated driving capability—are much closer to production reality.

Stylistically, the LF-FC was a Tokyo show traffic stopper with its sleek contours, tightly wrapped skin, low roofline, short overhangs, and sense of sophisticated muscularity. This is a big car, longer and lower than any of the high-end German cars that rule this class—the Audi A8, BMW 7 Series, and Mercedes-Benz S-Class. It’s also much longer and lower than the current Lexus LS, the company’s premier sedan. Aside from fuel cell power, we’ll see many of this concept’s features, including styling, when the next-generation LS sedan makes its debut in 2017.

4. Mazda RX

Is the world ready for a rotary-engine revival? Or were the mobs surrounding this sleek two-seater at the Tokyo show simply seduced by its elegantly sexy skin? Smart money says it’s the sheetmetal. A rotary engine was the unique core of Mazda’s identity from the late Sixties until the RX-8 went out of production in 2012. Mazda R&D has continued working to bring the engine back to market viability ever since. And company insiders insist that it’s going to happen, calling the revivalist engine the Skyactiv-R. Time will tell.

5. Mercedes Vision Tokyo

At a glance, the shape is vaguely minivan-esque in the Dustbuster style of the Pontiac Trans Sport and the Chevrolet Lumina APV. But the Mercedes-Benz Vision Tokyo's doors don’t slide, it’s far more slick, and of course it's far more sophisticated. The entire body, including the windows, is coated with silvery paint, and blue LED accent lights lend drama to the package. Power is delivered by a fuel cell system feeding electric motors. While there were no tech details on the powertrain, Mercedes suggests a potential range of 600 miles. The interior is distinguished by lounge seating, for a more communal environment and better access to a variety of electro toys.

The interior layout—Mercedes characterizes it as “a chill-out zone in the midst of the megacity traffic mayhem”—is viable because the Vision is fully autonomous and drives itself. However, should one of the occupants be seized with a need for actual control, a command causes a small seat to set itself up and a steering wheel pops out of the dashboard.

6. Nissan Teatro for Dayz

"Teatro" is Spanish for theater, and that’s apt since this concept has little to do with driving and a lot to do with infotainment. There are enough configurable video screens inside to rival a TV news studio, and the only conventional interior vehicle elements are the steering wheel and foot pedals. All the other controls are on touchscreens—no knobs, no switches—and it’s clear that driving plays a very subordinate role in this vehicle’s mission. When the Teatro is in motion, exterior digital screens can be programmed to convey mood or message, Goodyear Blimp style.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Um_GUzx7HfM" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

7. Nissan 2020 Vision Gran Turismo

Nissan enlisted the digigeeks of Gran Turismo, the computer supercar driving game, in developing this stunning sports car concept, hence the name—and the car’s virtual presence on Gran Turismo 6. But this is more than virtual reality. Yes, it was initially conceived strictly for video gaming, but then the London-based design team got a green light to take the car to the concept stage. The 2020 Vision Gran Turismo, in fact, is widely believed to be a blueprint for the next-generation GT-R, Nissan’s two-seat supercar. Expectations are for a hybridized powertrain, amplifying the 545-horsepower twin-turbocharged V-6 that propels the current GT-R.
The concept says 2020, but Nissan has long since announced that work is in progress on the GT-R make-over. Look for the new car to be in showrooms well before the end of the decade.

8. Suzuki Mighty Deck

Not to be confused with the Mighty Ducks, this Mini-size two-seater concept by Suzuki isn’t as bizarre as some of the concepts that turn up at this show—until you get to the rear. Instead of a hatchback, there’s a miniature pickup bed, with wood paneling. Not really big enough for a proper tailgate party, but that’s not an issue since Suzuki is no longer a player in the U.S. market. The interior is distinguished by a tiny center-dash instrument cluster and more wood paneling.

Suzuki has a history of zany names for its concept cars, and this show was consistent with that tradition. Besides the Mighty Deck, Suzuki displayed the Hustler, the Lapin, the Escudo, and the Hustler Scoot.

9. Toyota Kikai

You know the old saying that what you see is what you get, and that’s certainly true of this zany Toyota SUV concept. Pretty much every mechanical element is right out there for everyone to see—including the driver. From the pilot’s seat, which is in the middle of the vehicle, transparent floor panels reveal what’s going on with the front wheels and the lower suspension components. The upper portions of the suspension are atop the hood, giving driver and passerby of the suspension in action. The rear-mounted engine is also exposed, dressed up with a lot of chrome, including the exhaust plumbing, The interior is a Luddite’s delight—no touch screens, no digitalia, just a collection of good ol’ analog dials and conventional switches.
Kikai is the Japanese word for machine. Hmm. Wonder how you say dream machine in Japanese. That would be appropriate, since the prospects for Kikai production can be summed up thus: in your dreams.

10. Yamaha Sports Ride

A Yamaha car? Well, why not? Like any successful company it seeks to expand its horizons. Consider the Motobot, a Yamaha show property from the company’s R&D division. It’s a robot rider conceived to pilot a motorcycle at speeds up to about 125 mph. Spooky.

This snappy little two-seat sports car concept is more rooted in reality, as well as possible production. It’s not the company’s first street-legal four-wheeler; Yamaha unveiled a small two-seat commuter, the MOTIV, at the 2013 Tokyo show. But the Sports Ride is a lot more appealing, and far more advanced.

Developed by Gordon Murray Design Limited in Surrey, England, a racing-car shop with Formula 1 connections, the front-engine, rear-wheel-drive chassis is composed of carbon fiber. The car is dimensionally similar to the new Mazda MX-5 Miata, but some 650 pounds lighter. And Yamaha has plenty of potent motorcycle engines capable of making the car a serious rocket.
When or even whether the Sports Ride will actually find its way into production is a question Yamaha refrained from addressing at the show.

title: Is the Walker Always Right?
subTitle: Laura: The driver is the bad guy if a walker gets hit. Molly: Blame is shared. Whose side are you on?
promoTeaserSmall: Laura: The driver is the bad guy if a walker gets hit. Molly: Blame is shared. Whose side are you on?
promoTeaser: Laura: The driver is the bad guy if a walker gets hit. Molly: Blame is shared. Whose side are you on?
keywords: Pro/Con: Is the Walker Always Right?
metaTitle: Pro/Con: Is the Walker Always Right? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Laura says the driver is the bad guy if a walker gets hit. Molly says blame is shared. Whose side are you on?

contributors.displayName: Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

pageElements.text:
Laura Says: People Were Here before Cars

Isn't it annoying that you have to watch out for those pesky pedestrians when you drive? I am like you; I have sighed with impatience at having to wait for people to slowly mince across an intersection when I'm in a hurry. I have been pissed off when college students (they're thick on the ground in Ann Arbor, Michigan, where I live) blithely step out into the street without looking.
The only thing that mitigates my disgust is remembering the time when I, too, was a college student and did the same thing.

Molly Jean and I were just arguing about this because we were reading about three—three!—bad accidents that happened in our town in the past week. All took place under rainy and/or dark conditions, true, but they all also happened on main roads, not back streets. One person was hospitalized when she was hit while crossing at the light on Main Street downtown just before 7 a.m. Another person was killed while riding a bicycle in the bike lane of a well-lit multi-lane street at 2 a.m. In the third case, a fourteen-year-old crossing a dark road on Halloween with friends is in critical condition after being hit and dragged for two miles in the undercarriage of a car. That driver is still on the loose almost a week later.

What do all of these have in common? The person driving the car. The person who was so unobservant, so detached from the experience of driving, that he or she not only ran into a human being in a place where people were to be expected, but then drove away, in at least one case completely oblivious to having done so.

Of course pedestrians need to watch for cars. Of course it's in their control to avoid almost any vehicle by just not stepping out into the road until they're absolutely sure no cars are coming. But people were here before cars, their bodies are more vulnerable than cars' exteriors, and if you're driving, you need to watch out and expect them to appear, even at night, even in the rain, even in an unexpected place.

Sit back for a minute and think about what you're doing when you are driving a car. You are behind 2,000-plus pounds of metal with an engine, rolling down the road capable of dealing death and destruction to the small, fragile bodies of human beings. Get the hell off your phones, and never stop thinking about exactly what you're doing when you are driving and whom you could hurt.
Molly Says: It Doesn't Matter Whose Fault It Is If You're Dead

I follow two separate mantras when it comes to pedestrian safety. When I am the driver, I work very hard to be vigilant when it comes to scanning for pedestrians. However, when I am a pedestrian I take full responsibility for my own safety.

Sometimes I feel like the pedestrians in Ann Arbor are playing a game of Frogger. I frequently see pedestrians who blindly cross the street without considering that the two-ton vehicle that is piloted by a human could possibly barrel into them. It does not matter if you are in a crosswalk or jaywalking; it makes sense to make eye contact with a driver before you proceed to cross a street. As we all learned in middle school, assuming makes an ass out of u and me, and in this case it could also have dire consequences.
I frequently see pedestrians who blindly cross the street without considering that the two-ton vehicle that is piloted by a human could possibly barrel into them.

I agree that a responsible driver is always on the lookout for bipeds. But in the real world, drivers make errors all the time. Accident statistics support the fact that humans driving cars make mistakes. It is also not a stretch to say that in car versus homo sapiens, the car wins. Every. Single. Time. Raise your hand if you have ever had a close call that was your fault. I have accidentally run a stop sign, almost pulled out to pass a car on a highway directly into another car, and, yes, I have failed to see a pedestrian in my blind spot. Each incident left my hands shaking but also made me double down on my own safety when I am a pedestrian.

My parents gave me advice to use as a young driver and reminded me that it applied when I was a pedestrian as well.

"Here lies the body of Johnny O'Day
Who died preserving his right of way.

"He was right, dead right, as he sailed along
But he's just as dead as if he'd been wrong."


This simple poem nails my perspective on the pedestrian question. I try to walk at least four miles a day, and my husband and daughter are big walkers as well. I live right near a very busy intersection within walking distance of downtown. I taught my daughter to walk down a block to a quieter intersection where there is less turning traffic. People are in a hurry when they are in their cars. I have witnessed dozens of accidents at this intersection as drivers desperately try to make a light. At that exact moment, pedestrian safety has slipped their mind as top priority. Agreed, it should be part of a driver’s mind set at all times, but it is not.

I find the most dangerous crosswalks are the ones that are on high-traffic four-lane roads. On multiple occasions, I have seen cars coming up to a line of cars that have stopped at a crosswalk, going into the open lane, and zipping through the crosswalk, nearly missing a pedestrian. It is especially dangerous in towns with high numbers of tourists who are not expecting a crosswalk mid-block. I have held my breath more than once when I am stopped at a crosswalk and a car darts around me. Again, the prudent pedestrian should peek around and make sure all lanes are safe before they proceed.

Drivers are increasingly distracted by technology. Add in a driver who is lost or looking around for his or her destination, and an oblivious pedestrian doesn’t stand a chance. Crossing gets even tougher with darkness, and rain adds a Molotov cocktail to the mix. One of the recent pedestrian accidents in Ann Arbor was a woman allegedly crossing during early morning rush hour, during a rainstorm, with an obstructed view behind a black umbrella. It was a recipe for disaster, and it breaks my heart. I just wish we could time-travel back to the moment before she stepped off the curb. Her eyes meet the driver’s eye, and she safely proceeds across the street.

I wholeheartedly agree that drivers must be on the lookout for pedestrians. And those who want to lay the responsibility solely on drivers, I wish you the very best. But to anyone I love, please presume that the driver of the car does not see you.

title: 2016 Nissan 370Z
subTitle: Stoking the eternal Z flame, forty-seven years on.
promoTeaserSmall: Stoking the eternal Z flame, forty-seven years on.
promoTeaser: Stoking the eternal Z flame, forty-seven years on.
metaDescription: Stoking the eternal Z flame, forty-seven years on.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Two-seat, rear-wheel-drive sport coupe
Trim levels: Base, Sport, Sport Tech, Touring, Nismo, Nismo TECH
Base price: $30,815 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $30,940
Engine: 3.7-liter V-6, 332 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/26 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not rated
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Porsche Boxster ($53,095)
2016 Porsche Cayman ($53,595)
2016 Ford Mustang V-6 Fastback ($24,795)
Fun-O-Meter: 9.0

When I look at the 2016 Nissan 370Z, I can’t help remembering back through the Nissan Z cars of my career, which, by the way, does not go back to the first, groundbreaking, 150-horsepower 1969 240Z. My favorite of the lot came thirty years later, after wildly successful sales, numerous amateur and national racing championships (Paul Newman set several track records in 1985), and a sudden drop in sales as America fell out of love with sports cars for a sudden affair with minivans and sport-utility vehicles. Sad times indeed.

But Nissan came roaring back in 1990 with the 300ZX Twin Turbo, an absolute smash hit that took the Big Four national car magazines—Car and Driver, Automobile, Road & Track, and Motor Trend—by storm. This fourth-generation Z car had an all-new 3.0-liter V-6 that produced 300 horsepower, and it was blisteringly fast, a beast that drew untoward constabulary attention to my spirited driving on more than one unfortunate occasion, convincing me finally to use my cruise control regularly. Those were the days.

Year after year, the enthusiast car mags heaped on the Best of the Best of Everything Fabulous on that 300ZX Twin Turbo as horsepower grew to 365 in 1995 (the Z’s twenty-fifth anniversary), until 1996, when Nissan pulled the plug and almost went under as a company. Renault rode in and picked Nissan up in 1999, creating one shaky company out of two shaky companies, but at least the Z returned in 2002, passing its 45th anniversary last year.

God bless Nissan for keeping the performance driving flame alive by continuing to build and sell the two-seat 370Z—and at a price that is well below its closest competitors. The only option on the coupe I drove was a $125 set of carpeted floor mats, in fact, for an as-tested price just over $30,000. For the price of a boring car, you could have this.
My memory may have unjustifiably placed the 1990 300Z Twin Turbo in the pantheon of the greatest cars I have ever driven. Well, it’s my memory.

My memory may have unjustifiably placed the 1990 300Z Twin Turbo in the pantheon of the greatest cars I have ever driven. Well, it’s my memory. At least it was quicker and cooler than any of its competition at the time. Today’s 332-horsepower, non-turbocharged 370Z is still a very special car for a very special driver: one who has no need for a back seat and doesn’t need cargo space for anything but a couple of pieces of luggage or a few grocery bags. There's a carpeted nook behind each of the front seats that could hold a modest purse or briefcase. But the 370Z is for traveling light.
You can tell just from looking at it, can’t you?

The short overhangs, the steep rake of the rear hatch, the big black ten-spoke eighteen-inch wheels shoved out to the corners. All of that gives the 370Z a personal snug-as-a-bug-in-a-rug look. One with an edge, for sure.

Graphics are simple, clean. The deep front hood meets a low, large black intake. Slices of light decorate each of the four corners, and the door handle is a simple vertical slash of satin-finish chrome. And then there’s the mark of Zorro—the slashing Z logo—behind the front doors on the rear fender arches.
It looks mean. It is mean.

The 370Z is purpose built for someone who believes that the very act of driving is the destination. It wraps around the driver like a second skin, with deep, contoured seats that are bolstered at the sides to hold driver and passenger tight as the road calls for more spirited driving.

The engine is familiar to Nissan performance fans. Its very enthusiastic 3.7-Iiter, 332-horsepower V-6 mates to a six-speed manual or seven-speed automatic transmission. The manual transmission in the 370Z I drove leapt into action no matter what gear I was in. Our test car didn’t have downshift rev matching (introduced by Nissan, for the first time ever in a production car, in the 2009 sixth-generation 370Z). It’s a great feature that allows for fast, precise downshifts, so I had to count on my own ability to keep those downshifts clean and neat.

If you want to feel like a hero driver, you have to spend an extra $3,580 for the 370Z Sport model to get SynchroRev Match, but at least it also comes with extra performance enhancements like a limited-slip differential and bigger brakes. I would recommend you at least test a car with rev matching to experience the thrill. There are those that would argue the superior speed of the automatic with rev matching. It will also add only $1,300 to the base 370Z. I have to admit, that automatic transmission is good, and certainly the only way I’d ever consider an automatic.

But there’s a perfectly great manual available for no extra charge. The shift quality of the 370Z’s manual is exceptional, a hallmark of a car built for driving fun. Shifts are decisive and crisp. The steering wheel, another key component of a true driver’s car, is smallish in diameter, nicely padded with beautiful leather, and fairly linear in delivery.

The instrument cluster is simple, with large, clear gauges. The speedometer is marked to 180 mph for your amusement. An additional set of important gauges—water temperature and oil pressure—join an analog clock in a small cluster mounted atop the center of the dash and angled toward the driver.

You won’t find much extraneous distraction in a base 370Z. You won’t find modern driver assist safety technologies. No blind spot monitoring, but there is smart cruise control, along with modern HID xenon headlamps. No rearview camera, but Bluetooth hands-free phone, ABS braking, and a sophisticated double-wishbone suspension are standard equipment. For another $11,000, you can buy the convertible roadster version.
The four additional 370Z coupes add in technical bells and whistles, the luxury amenities and trappings, all the way to a pumped-up 350-horsepower Nismo version with a jaunty little rear wing.
Buy one of those if you must. But you will find the real heart and soul, the eternal Z-car flame, alive and well for the price of an entry-level ticket.

title: 2016 Nissan Altima SR
subTitle: A sporty Altima joins the lineup as Nissan makes its mid-size sedan more attractive to more people.
promoTeaserSmall: A sporty Altima joins the lineup as Nissan makes its mid-size sedan more attractive to more people.
promoTeaser: A sporty Altima joins the lineup as Nissan makes its mid-size sedan more attractive to more people.
metaDescription: A sporty Altima joins the lineup as Nissan makes its mid-size sedan more attractive to more people.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
Trim levels: 2.5 (base, S, SR, SV, SL); 3.5 (SR, SL)
Base price: $26,115 (price includes destination charge)
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 185 horsepower
Transmission: Xtronic continuously variable automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 26 mpg city/37 mpg highway (SR); 27/39 mpg (SL)
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated; 2015 model was Top Safety Pick
My favorite standard feature: Siri Eyes Free and NissanConnect with mobile apps
Notable standard features on this model: Sport suspension, special eighteen-inch aluminum alloy wheels, rear deck-lid spoiler
Notable options on this model: LED appearance package ($600), includes LED headlights and A/C vents in rear passenger console
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion SE, Honda Accord Sport, Hyundai Sonata Sport

America's thirst for crossovers aside, every automaker needs to make a good, solid mid-size sedan. That's what millions of people are buying. The 2016 Nissan Altima is no exception to this rule; quite the contrary. Nissan counts heavily on this, its biggest seller, so naturally it has pulled out all the stops to make the 2016 Altima as desirable as possible to as many shoppers as possible. Having just driven two of the six varieties of Altima, we can confirm that it's working.

The design of the 2016 Nissan Altima is called Energetic Flow, which (no matter how you feel about this sort of design speak) you'll understand just by looking at the "boomerang" headlamps and the V-shaped grille. The Altima now looks more like the upper end of Nissan's lineup, cars like the Maxima and the Murano. It's an attractive but not an ostentatious look.

The biggest change for 2016 is that Nissan added a "sporty" version, the SR, intended to go up against the Honda Accord Sport, the Ford Fusion SE, and other still economical, but slightly more fun-to-drive, versions of competitor cars. If you are hoping for a less boring version of the traditional mid-size sedan, but don't want to pay a premium price, the Altima SR might be your car. It has a masculine, no-frills feeling inside and a slightly more aggressive appearance outside, with special eighteen-inch wheels and tires, a stiffer suspension, and better noise insulation—including an extra layer of acoustic barrier in the windshield. I deferred to a veteran driver with racing experience, choosing to appreciate the Altima SR's poise at higher speeds from the passenger's seat, while he tried out the car's sporty credentials on an interestingly curvy rural driving route.
If you are hoping for a less boring version of the traditional mid-size sedan, but don't want to pay a premium price, the Altima SR might be your car.
My own more workaday driving style was rewarded, too, when it was my turn to drive, as would that of most people just trying to pass slower cars and feel reasonably powerful while doing so.

A lot of people claim to dislike continuously variable transmissions. The Altima's newly updated Xtronic CVT, also found on the Maxima, might be the one to convince those people, not just because it feels smooth and natural in its new, third-generation version, but because with it, the 2016 Altima offers 39 mpg on the highway (37 mpg in the SR). That's better than any of the other mid-size sedans out there and a 1-mpg improvement over last year's Altima.

After that invigorating outing in the SR, the Altima SL 2.5 ($32,595 as tested) felt absolutely plush. This model, with the same 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine and CVT, was loaded with electronic and safety features. It was equipped with the SL Tech and LED packages ($2,190), which include NissanConnect infotainment with navigation, mobile apps, intelligent cruise control, and forward emergency braking. Forward collision warning, including a more advanced predictive version that watches as far as two cars in front of you, are part of the $1,700 Technology package on the SL only, while blind spot warning and rear cross-traffic alert are standard on the SL. We're big fans of active safety features like these, and seeing them included at the reasonable price point of the SL, it's good to think how many more people will benefit from them.

The SL also had a power sliding and tilting moonroof (an $800 option) as well as a Bose premium sound system, heated front seats, and my very favorite indulgence, a heated steering wheel.

One thing you can't get is the latest thing to hit infotainment screens, the smartphone-app-integrating Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. Nissan said it was not their priority, at least at this point. That seems to conflict with Nissan's intention to reach younger buyers through the addition of the sporty SR model. But it's forgiveable in view of the active safety features you get instead.

Driving these two cars one after the other drove home the point that there really is an Altima for any sedan shopper, no matter what you're looking for. Nearly all Altima shoppers will go for one of the four 2.5-liter four-cylinder models, but there are also two with a 3.5-liter V-6. You can get the base Altima for $23,325, while the top-of-the-line 3.5 SL retails at $32,915. (Prices include destination charge.)

More on the Nissan Altima

2016 Nissan Altima Rolls Out

title: 5 Cool Things: Hyundai Virtual Guide
subTitle: Hyundai takes one more step toward the future with a 3D virtual guide for the Sonata.
promoTeaserSmall: Hyundai takes one more step toward the future with a 3D virtual guide for the Sonata.
promoTeaser: Hyundai takes one more step toward the future with a 3D virtual guide for the Sonata.
metaDescription: Hyundai takes one more step toward the future with a 3D virtual guide for the Sonata.

pageElements.text: You think of the owner's manual as that brick-shaped volume you never take out of the glove box after the first day you own the car. The Hyundai Virtual Guide is the intriguing successor to that.

Lately you can look up your owner's manual online, which is very handy. But the Hyundai Virtual Guide goes far beyond that to create a tablet experience. Here are five cool things about this newly announced feature, which will be on the 2016 Sonata and, later, the 2016 Tucson.

1. Hold the tablet up to your car, and everything it sees will be labeled.
This is the best part of the app: you are interacting with your own car. More than forty-five features are highlighted in the app, and we can assume Hyundai will add more as it perfects the Virtual Guide idea.

2. Watch walk-throughs of basic maintenance functions on your phone or tablet.
This is not an app that will teach you to give your car a brake job, but for very simple but important tasks—replacing the washer fluid, for example—the app will walk you through it, step by step. There are some fifty informational guides on this app.

3. No more flipping through an index!
The best part about the Hyundai Virtual Guide is how it frees you from looking through a paper or online owner's manual. Those owner's manuals in PDF form are great, but they also run to hundreds of pages. The Virtual Guide cuts to the chase by showing you the maintenance and feature information you are most likely to need, and you gain access to it in the same way you'd browse any website, which feels more natural, these days, than using an actual book.

4. 3D images!
This is the best-looking owner's manual you'll see, and certainly the most portable. Hyundai calls it "augmented reality," which is a stretch—for now—but the 3D overlay images of six areas of the vehicle are, we hope, the wave of the future for owner's manuals.

5. Easily downloaded on Apple App Store and Google Play.
It's not out yet, but you Sonata (and, soon, Tucson) owners will be able to start using it before the New Year, Hyundai says.

title: Driver's Ed Books for Parents
subTitle: Two books by dads who want to equip parents with a better way to help new drivers.
promoTeaserSmall: Two books by dads who want to equip parents with a better way to help new drivers.
promoTeaser: Two books by dads who want to equip parents with a better way to help new drivers.
metaTitle: Driver's Ed Books for Parents - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Two books by dads who want to equip parents with a better way to help new drivers.

pageElements.text: You think teething is bad. You think middle school is awkward for both you and your kid. All true. But, for sheer terror, nothing matches the day your teenager starts driving the family car.

Now it's not that you don't trust your teenager. But you feel so....helpless handing over those keys, hoping but not quite convinced that the driver's ed class has educated him or her enough for what's out there.

Two dads have addressed that feeling by publishing their own slim paperbacks to help parents help their kids. Either (or both) of these books can give you the boost you need to supplement the driver education classes in which your child is—you hope—paying close attention, with practical advice and tips you may not have thought of.
Oh, and either one is good to hand to the kid as well.

What Teenage Drivers Don't Know: The Unwritten Rules of the Road

by John Harmata and Paul Zientarski
$9.95 from Lake Effect Publishing

Harmata had a serious scare when he was eighteen. It involved black ice and a 360-degree spinout. Uninjured but more than a little freaked out, he spent the next three decades taking driving seriously. He and driver education program chairman Paul Zientarski have catalogued the most common dangers on the road in this seventy-two-page manual. Those range from country road hazards to driving through fog, with anecdotes and practical advice for handling each one.
Reading this book is like having your own dad sitting in the passenger's seat, passing on a lifetime of well-earned expertise.

If you (and/or your teenager) aren't a little nervous after reading through this book's laundry list of dangers, you aren't paying attention. But don't stop there; go on to the very useful tips that follow. There's an entire section on what to do after an accident, for example, including how to behave in court, and another on parking lot etiquette and technique. It's like having your own dad sitting in the passenger's seat, passing on a lifetime of well-earned expertise.

Harmata wins bonus points for his chapter titled, "Why Teens Should Never Let Friends Borrow Their Vehicle." Those bonus points probably won't come from your teenager, but he is right, and his six reasons (including #5, "never assume a friend is going to admit to having received a parking ticket while using your vehicle") will give parents the ammunition they might need to convince their kids.

Not So Fast: Parenting Your Teen through the Dangers of Driving

by Tim Hollister
$12.95 from IPG Books

This book addresses teen driving from a psychological perspective, helping you as a parent understand why teenagers think and drive the way they do, and giving you ideas about how to approach your own child in a productive, helpful way around driving. The author's inspiration comes from the most tragic source: his own son died in a one-car accident less than a year after getting his license.

Hollister did everything right. His kid was driving a Volvo. He took an approved driver education course and had more than the required amount of on-the-road practice. He wasn't texting, under the influence of alcohol or drugs, or otherwise breaking the law. He just lost control of the car on a curve, because of inexperience.

Hollister starts there. Using the latest ideas about how teenagers' brains develop, and without overstating or trying to frighten the reader, he gives parents a lot to think about. "Understand and accept the dangers of teen driving as your baseline" is the take-away message, and no matter how convenient it is to hand teens the car keys so they can get themselves to hockey practice from now on, it's an essential message for parents.
This book lays out the Teen Driving Agreement idea in complete detail, giving you a road map that will actually let you succeed at it.

What's most useful about this book is its plan for teens and parents to work together to improve those safety odds. You may have seen various ads and public service announcements suggesting you have a Teen Driving Agreement with your child. This book lays it out in complete detail, giving you a road map that will actually let you succeed at it.

The bonus in Not So Fast is its advice on mentoring other people's teenagers, including the best way to talk to other parents about their children's driving. It also makes suggestions for dealing with your local schools and becoming a safe driving activist in your community. Hollister is obviously deeply affected by this issue, and his resulting thorough coverage of the challenges of teen driving makes useful reading for every parent.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive coupe, convertible, or hatchback
Price range: $42,845 - $59,945
Trim levels: 428i, 428i xDrive, 435i, 435i xDrive

You might also be considering: Audi A5, Lexus RC, Infiniti Q60

If the technology-loaded 7 Series makes you want to be a passenger, the 2016 4 Series will demand that you take the driver's seat. It’s menacing, athletic, and sleek, and what it sacrifices in back seat comfort it makes up for in performance. To enhance the car’s raw abilities is the dynamic handling package, which offers variable-assist sport steering and adaptive suspension. Speed-sensitive steering comes standard, as do dynamic cruise control and rain-sensing windshield wipers. The 435i xDrive has 16 cubic feet of cargo space, and with the 40/20/40 split configuration of the rear seats, you can have access to even more space in the trunk.

New for 2016: Tough-looking Sport Line appearance package is standard on all 4 Series models.

More about the BMW 4 Series:

Woo-hoo time in the snow with a 2015 BMW 435i xDrive Coupe

title: Which Cars Have Wireless Phone Charging?
subTitle: Want to charge your phone in the car? Sick of messing with cords? Here are your current choices.
promoTitle: Which Cars Have Wireless Phone Charging?
promoTeaserSmall: Want to charge your phone in the car? Sick of messing with cords? Here are your current choices.
promoTeaser: Want to charge your phone in the car? Sick of messing with cords? Here are your current choices.
keywords: which cars have wireless phone charging
metaTitle: Which Cars Have Wireless Phone Charging? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Want to charge your phone in the car? Sick of messing with cords? Here are your current choices.

pageElements.text: You know the drill. You get in the car, you reach for your phone to plug it in and charge it, and then you realize you forgot the cord. Or your cord, for some reason, isn’t quite working. (They do that.) Or you want to use the phone, but first you have to wrestle with the charge cord. All far too low tech when you’re charging a $300 phone in a $30,000 vehicle, don’t you think?

Many automakers are responding to the seemingly limitless need to charge smartphones by providing wireless charging pads. They’re so much easier to manage in the car. Just drop your phone onto the surface, and the charging happens with no further intervention from you.

Wireless charging works through communication between a transmitter built into the charging mat and a corresponding one in the smartphone. Apple’s iPhones aren’t wireless charging ready, although an increasing number of Android phones are. If yours is not, you will need a special case or attachment from your friendly Best Buy, wireless carrier, or other technology supplier.
There’s no doubt wireless charging is the direction charging is going, so why not be an early adopter?

1. Cadillac

What models have it? All 2016 Cadillac models except SRX
The luxury arm of General Motors rolled out wireless charging on the 2015 ATS and now offers it on every 2016 model except the SRX as standard equipment. Visit the Cadillac website for full details and information on whether your smartphone is compatible.

2. Chevrolet

What models have it? 2016 Impala, Malibu, Volt, Cruze
The populist automaker has just introduced something nobody else has (yet): Active Phone Cooling, which has a vent to direct air from the car’s A/C system to the charging pad. You already know that heat is very bad for your phone’s battery, and charging pads can be hot; this is intended to fix that problem.

3. Dodge and Chrysler

What models have it? Dodge Caravan R/T, Dart, Viper, Ram; Chrysler 200 and Town & Country
In this case, the wireless charging mat is supplied by the automaker’s Mopar aftermarket company. The purchase of the vehicle comes with a voucher that you redeem for a special case for your smartphone. See the details here.

4. GMC

What models have it? 2016 Yukon and Yukon XL (SLT and Denali models)
Wireless phone charging is standard on the uplevel SLT and Denali versions of the Yukon/Yukon XL SUV. Visit https://my.gmc.com/learn/wirelessCharging/ for full details and information on whether your smartphone is compatible. Watch a demonstration:

5. Jeep

What models have it? Cherokee (Limited and Altitude models)
Wireless charging has been available on the Cherokee since 2014. It’s different technology than the Mopar products on Chrysler and Dodge vehicles, even though they have the same parent company. You select it as an option with the Uconnect infotainment system.

6. Lexus

What models have it? LX570, NX200t (standard and F Sport), NX300h
The wireless charger is a $220 option on these select Lexus models. The center console holds a tray with an indicator light to tell you when your phone is fully charged.

7. Toyota

What models have it? Avalon, Camry, Land Cruiser, Prius, Tacoma
Toyota’s wireless charging tray is similar to that of its corporate sibling Lexus: there’s an amber light while charging is in progress, and a green light once the phone is fully charged. Watch a demonstration here.

images.caption: Chevrolet wireless charger with Active Phone Cooling.
