subTitle: A bus that drives like a very nice car.
promoTeaserSmall: A bus that drives like a very nice car.
promoTeaser: A bus that drives like a very nice car.
metaDescription: A bus that drives like a very nice car.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Seven-passenger, front-wheel-drive minivan
Trim levels: LX, EX, SE, EX-L, Touring, Touring Elite
Base price: $30,175 (LX) (prices include destination charge)
This car: $45,650
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 248 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/28 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick (2015 model)
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Chrysler Town & Country Limited Platinum ($41,640)
2016 Kia Sedona SXL ($40,795)
2015 Toyota Sienna Limited Premium ($45,955)

Fun-O-Meter: 6 for the driver, 8 for the kids

The Honda Odyssey is a perennial success in a world in which minivans’ popularity has continued to shrink. That’s because Honda knows its audience. The Odyssey was already a big improvement on its competition fifteen years ago when it was introduced to admiring American moms and dads, and it continues to ride at the top of the segment. Honda figured out exactly why people liked the original minivans, the Chrysler Town & Country and Dodge Caravan: how you sat up high in it, how carlike it was to maneuver, and how nice it was to have that low load floor not only to step in, but to load in kids and cargo..
Then they improved everything, making everything seriously better.

As the Odyssey approaches the end of its fourth generation, with an all-new model expected in 2017, it’s still very desirable, at least for those who need the size and passenger capacity of a  minivan.

The very first Odyssey was more of a tall MPV, but by the second generation, making its debut in 1999, it was a full-fledged minivan. It didn’t take long before Honda Odysseys were lined up in front of every child care center, elementary school, and soccer field in the land.
If there is any vehicle that is completely focused on creating the most exquisite experience for the passengers, especially the ones in the back seat, the Odyssey is it.
And why not? If there is any vehicle that is completely focused on creating the most exquisite experience for the passengers, especially the ones in the back seat, the Odyssey is it.

Having said that, if the back-seat passengers are happy and entertained, the driver wins, too. The seating for up to eight, the entertainment, the clever seats reconfigurability, the ease of getting in and out, the flexible center console that serves both front and back seat—no wonder this minivan is so coveted.

The 2016 Honda Odyssey is a carryover model with some improvements, but you can tell this model is due to be updated. The fact that there’s only one USB connection, up by the driver, is a dead giveaway. As for active safety technology, the 2016 Odyssey doesn’t have adaptive cruise control or road departure mitigation, as in the Honda Sensing suite of technologies you can get on the 2016 Accord, Pilot, and Civic. The Touring Elite model I tested does offer lane departure and forward collision warning, as well as Honda’s unbeatable multi-view rearview camera.

One of the very best things about the Odyssey is its movable center console in the front row. You can remove it and have a pass-through, desirable especially for parents of babies and toddlers. In place, the bin is big enough for a medium-size purse, while the top is cleverly designed for fast food fans. It will hold two cups in front, two in back, and the center part is designed to hold a typical fast-food tray if you’re lucky enough to live in In-N-Out Burger territory.
There’s a flip-down trash ring, too, something you won’t find elsewhere.

That same amazing flexibility is true of the seats. Believe it or not, if you want to put three people or car seats in the second row, you can. Heaven forbid. Just what you wanted, to be chosen as the permanent field trip mom for the preschool.

The fold-down 16.2-inch DVD rear entertainment system above the second row is a wonder to behold, and it comes with two pairs of headphones. At some point you will want to take a break and sit in the back seat and watch. I can’t resist thinking it would also be great for date night for the grownups.

Honda’s clever seat-folding technology gives you near-instantaneous one-touch access to the third row. Press the button and watch the second-row seat move up to let someone clamber in the back. Or just press the upper part of it and create a recline. In the second row, you can slide both outboard seats toward the doors to make room to put three child safety seats in the row. You can also move the center seat forward to bring it closer to the front row or fold it down to reveal a center console. The Magic Seat 60/40 split-folding rear seats drop down into the floor nearly instantly when you pull the “magic” straps on the seatback. It really is kind of like magic. Once everyone in the back rows gets seated, they’ll enjoy the fact that the Honda Odyssey Touring Elite offers tri-zone climate control.

So all the passengers are covered; what about the driver? I love the dual infotainment screens. The tendency (the correct one) will be to keep your eyes up on the top screen for all the important stuff, instead of looking down at your phone (the wrong one). Voice recognition for phone calling is fairly simple, although a little confusing at first because, once paired, the screen will show random names from your contacts list as an example of how to word your request, using a different name every time, and your first thought is “No, I don’t want to call P.J. O’Rourke!” At the top, you quickly realize, is the real number you’re calling.

If you’re not used to parking a minivan, the Odyssey has a small learning curve. It is very easy to drive, but it’s so long that you may have to relearn parking. The steering is light enough that you can pull into a straight spot, but you may find yourself needing to back out and pull back in despite the reasonable 36.7-foot turning radius. This is where the rearview camera, standard on all Odysseys, comes in handy. Honda’s LaneWatch is part of the package on the Touring Elite model. Put on the right turn signal, and a camera in the passenger’s-side door mirror shows what’s behind your vehicle to the right. is an invaluable aid for people with a vanload of distraction, a.k.a. the eight passengers it can hold.

The sliding side doors and rear liftgate are all electric. When you first get in the car, you’ll notice a panel of controls to the left of the steering wheel to operate them. The liftgate also opens or closes using the key fob. My only complaint is that it’s not height adjustable, meaning you’ll want to consider before opening it inside a garage. I also think every vehicle with a big hatch should adopt some form of automatic opening, without the need even to press a button, such as Ford’s kick-foot method or Hyundai’s proximity key. When you’re dealing with kids and packages in a vehicle like that, it’s the ultimate in luxury.

The brakes are well modulated. As long as you’re not going 70 mph down a side street, you’re going to make that stop sign with no drama. The ride is drama-free as well. The suspension is quite refined, and there was no bouncing or school-bus feeling to the Odyssey.

There are eight trim levels, with a $15,500 range between the base model and the top trim level we drove. The details on the top Touring Elite model are exquisite, particularly the Cool Box, which sits below the infotainment screens. Using the car’s air conditioning, the box will keep your juice boxes, Frappuccinos, sandwiches, and snacks cool while you travel. They need to start out cold, however. The Touring Elite also gets the HondaVAC, a built-in vacuum that lives in the back of the vehicle behind the third row. 
 
You could just about buy the base model, the LX ($30,175) and pick up a base Honda Fit on the side ($16,625) for the $45,650 price of the Touring Elite, but the options on the top-end Odyssey are highly desirable. Check out the high-value Special Edition model ($34,275), new for 2016, to get some of those features at a lower price. Case in point? The HondaVAC is on the SE. God, I love that thing. Then again, I am a little OCD about my automotive environment. But people who need that vac will love it, too. It reaches everywhere in the vehicle, it’s built in, and it works like a charm on those errant Cheerios. What other vehicle do you know that has one? That would be none.

Another small but significant reason to consider the Odyssey is that it has the best fuel economy in the minivan category, at 19 mpg in town and 26 mpg on the highway. The Chrysler Town & Country and the Toyota Sienna both get 25 mpg on the highway, while the Kia Sedona gets 22 mpg.

I wouldn’t own a Honda Odyssey if I didn’t have kids or some other reason to need the space and number of seats. It’s a purpose-built vehicle. But driving it is certainly a totally pleasant experience. Especially at the top Touring Elite level, equipped with very nice leather and amenities. There’s no sense driving a bus if you don’t need one, but the minivan environment is the only perfect conveyance for families with little kids. My husband always had a minivan because he was a tradesman. He, of course, totally trashed the interior with all of his tradesman crap. And dog. Between the Magic Seats, the third row that folds down, the second row that flips up, you can create a fairly massive deep spot that can hold a lot, including a big cooler. When everything folds down, it’s a flat floor. I can’t overstate the importance to me of the flat load floor, which lets me put a kennel back there. Where there’s a bump between the two, it can be very tippy. I don’t want my dog on an angle; it upsets him.

There aren’t many minivans left, and the ones that are around are successful because they’ve mastered the platform. Their makers have figured out what their clients not only need, but what they desire. In Honda’s case, they’ve amped that up by imagining things you never dreamed you could find. When you’re talking about eight passengers, you’re talking about a bus, but with the Odyssey it’s a bus that drives like a very nice car.

images.caption: HondaVac in the 2016 Honda Odyssey Touring Elite.

title: 2016 Toyota RAV4 Hybrid
subTitle: Now there's a new choice for the hybrid buyer in the popular SUV's lineup.
promoTeaserSmall: Now there's a new choice for the hybrid buyer in the popular SUV's lineup.
promoTeaser: Now there's a new choice for the hybrid buyer in the popular SUV's lineup.
metaDescription: Now there's a new choice for the hybrid buyer in the popular SUV's lineup.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text:
Type: All-wheel-drive, five-passenger, four-door crossover utility vehicle
Trim levels: Hybrid XLE, Hybrid Limited
Base price: $34,510 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $36,560
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder with electric motor, 194 combined horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: 34 mpg city/31 mpg highway/33 mpg combined
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
Favorite standard feature: Height-adjustable power liftgate
Notable standard features on this model: Trailer sway control, hill start assist, eighteen-inch alloy wheels, LED exterior lighting, heated outside mirrors with integrated turn signal and blind-spot warning indicators, blind spot monitor with rear cross-traffic alert, Toyota Safety Sense suite of driver-assistance features, seven-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth and iPod connectivity, premium audio
You might also be considering: Honda CR-V, Ford Escape, Hyundai Tucson, Kia Sportage, Chevrolet Equinox

Twenty years ago, the Toyota RAV4 helped to change our way of thinking about compact vehicles. As a “cute ute,” the RAV4 offered a high seating position, great maneuverability, and more utility than compact sedans. And it was indeed cute, even with its carbuncle of a spare tire on the tailgate.
Now the RAV4 Hybrid joins the lineup. It’s the first time a gasoline/electric hybrid powertrain is offered in the lineup of the popular compact crossover utility vehicle.
The new Hybrid model, available in XLE and Limited trim and arriving now in dealerships, joins a refreshed 2016 RAV4 lineup that incorporates comprehensive improvements and revised styling.
For those who love command seating, need all-wheel drive, and like the idea of an efficient hybrid powertrain, the 2016 Toyota RAV4 Hybrid is an interesting new choice.

For those who love command seating, who need all-wheel drive, and who like the idea of an efficient hybrid powertrain but find the Toyota Highlander Hybrid too big or expensive, the 2016 Toyota RAV4 Hybrid is an interesting new choice. There was previously a RAV4 EV, but the Hybrid doesn’t make that battery-electric vehicle’s compromises. In fact, in addition to class-leading fuel economy of 33 mpg combined, the RAV4 Hybrid is quicker out of the gate and has greater towing capacity than its gasoline-powered siblings.
“We think we’re going to broaden our appeal in a really hot segment,” said Bill Fay, Toyota’s general manager.

The RAV4 Hybrid’s 33 mpg is noteworthy. I recall a 4,500-mile road trip in the original RAV4. It was dainty and lightweight, with a smaller engine, yet it slurped fuel and was as loud as Van Halen. Compared with other 2016 RAV4 all-wheel-drive models, the Hybrid gets about 32 percent better fuel economy in city driving.  
	
Basic revisions to the 2016 RAV4 results in a stiffer body, better braking and steering response, and more supple suspension. Our test vehicle, a top-of-the-line Hybrid Limited, was quiet and smooth.

Rather than a clockwork mechanical system, the on-demand all-wheel-drive cleverly distributes driving forces using electric motors in front and rear and selectively engaging the wheels as road conditions change. The benefit is being rid of the pushy front-drive effect that takes you to the outside of the turn under acceleration.

The surprising news is that the Hybrid offers increased performance beyond fuel economy. The dash from 0 to 60 mph takes 8.1 seconds, which Toyota says is about one second quicker than non-hybrid models. And it tows a 1,750-pound trailer, compared with 1,500 pounds for non-hybrid models. By the way, trailer sway control is standard with the Limited, so you have less reason to fear crosswinds and sudden lane changes when hitched to your personal watercraft or utility trailer.

The continuously variable automatic transmission has six ranges that can be manually selected by moving the shifter into the Sport setting, but I couldn’t figure out the point of it and stayed with full automatic mode. An EV mode lets the driver creep along on battery power for six-tenths of a mile at speeds below 25 mph.

There is some slight downside to the Hybrid. The nickel-metal hydride battery pack and electric motors add 320 pounds, bringing the Hybrid Limited to just shy of 4,000 pounds. And you bet the added mass was noticeable on California Route 74, the Ortega Highway, which curved first through housing developments beyond San Juan Capistrano, then through sycamores and oaks along Caspers Wilderness Park, finally delivering us to the Ortega Oaks Candy Store and Goods (“Holiday Orders Welcome”) in the Santa Ana Mountains.

Oh, by the way, because of the battery pack behind the rear bench, the Hybrid’s cargo area is about two percent smaller than the standard RAV4, at 70.6 cubic feet. That difference means the seat backs don’t quite fold flat. We use our utility vehicles for nearly every conceivable purpose and think it’s a big tradeoff. For example, Giovanni the Italian Spinone’s car kennel might not fit.

People at the candy store distinguished the RAV4 Hybrid Limited from merely gas-powered LE, XLE, Limited, and the new SE models by its unique eighteen-inch alloy wheels (seventeen-inch on Hybrid XLE) and wide Bridgestone Ecopia tires. It had an assertive stance, a large semi-elliptical expanse of glass on the side, and an overall look that’s more suggestive of mall crawling than trail running. The latter is the Toyota 4Runner’s job. Our car wore a sparkling coat of Blizzard Pearl paint and had standard full LED exterior lighting. Blue-accented badges are also unique to the Hybrid.

The upgraded cabin trim looks terrific on the whole 2016 RAV4 lineup, but we were unimpressed with the soggy feel when we pulled open the cargo area’s cover. Under the cargo floor, there’s a full-size (seventeen inch) spare tire, which allows the fitting of a traditional liftgate instead of the swing-out tailgate of 1996. The power close button and six-setting height-adjustable operation are big advances.

Whereas the Hybrid XLE has cloth upholstery, the Hybrid Limited had lovely cinnamon-and-black SofTex simulated leather upholstery with white stitching. The lower part of the dashboard, which is covered in the same material, sweeps away toward the passenger door, enhancing the open and spacious feel. The a new 4.2-inch display between dials in instrument cluster is included in Hybrid XLE and Limited models. The bright, touch-sensitive 7-inch central screen is included in the Limited, available in XLE, and it’s a jim-dandy for how it splits displays and can be customized.

The Limited included an optional eleven-speaker JBL audio system. Its merits include remarkable sharpness, door-rumbling bass, and spacing that gave the feeling of being amid the audience in a live recording. Naturally, there’s an impressive level of connectivity and voice recognition.

Toyota Safety Sense, a new suite of driver assistance features, is standard in the Hybrid Limited and an option in the Hybrid LXE. It combines a pre-collision braking system with pedestrian detection, lane departure alert with steering assist, automatic high beams, and radar-governed cruise control. A blind spot monitor with rear cross-traffic alert was also included. The optional bird’s-eye 360-degree camera is the cherry on top of the cake.

Revised styling gives all 2016 RAV4 models a gawky, Abstract Expressionist front end and a slightly ducktailed rear, but we think we’ll get used to it. The driving experience is pleasant, and 33 mpg will be easy to endure. Toyota’s hybrid system still whines when the regenerative braking function engages, reminding us of streetcars and the trains that run between airport terminals. But this, too, is endurable.

The RAV4 Hybrid Limited represents a lot of value, with premium touches that suggest a trickle-down from Lexus. Toyota offers seven other hybrid models, but the RAV4 is expected to attract 30,000 to 45,000 buyers per year—maybe even you.

title: 2015 Toyota Yaris
subTitle: A basic car widens its appeal.
promoTeaserSmall: A basic car widens its appeal.
promoTeaser: A basic car widens its appeal.
metaDescription: A basic car widens its appeal. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Hatchback
Price range: $15,670–$18,445 (includes destination)
Trim levels: L, LE, SE
Engine: 1.5-liter four-cylinder, 106 horsepower
Transmissions: 5-speed manual, 4-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): Manual: 30/37; Automatic: 30/36 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5 door: 4/5 overall rating
Our favorite standard feature: Nine air bags
Notable standard features on this model: A 6.1-inch touchscreen display and Bluetooth
Notable options on this model: Navigation
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Spark, Honda Fit

The historically style-challenged Yaris gets a makeover for 2015 that helps pull it even further out of the bargain basement where its humble life began. Redesigned head- and taillights and an aggressive black grille give the diminutive hatchback—offered in both three- and five-door bodystyles—a sportier look. The interior received a thorough restyle as well with upgraded seats—a six-way-adjustable driver’s seat is standard—soft-touch materials on the front doors and instrument panel, and a new gauge cluster. Toyota took steps to reduce road noise from entering the cabin by using acoustic windshield glass and adding more sound deadening materials throughout the cabin. The Yaris grew by two inches overall as well and a wider track, a retuned suspension, and a more rigid structure should help improve the Yaris’s stability and handling. A first for Yaris is the option of a dealer installed navigation system. Black trim on the headlights and wheels dress up the top-of-the-line SE. In fact, all the Yaris models are looking sharper thanks to the work of Toyota’s ED2 studio located in the South of France. Seems like the little Yaris is growing up but thankfully the price tag still remains in its teens.

New for 2015

A makeover that includes a wider trapezoid grille, new fog, head- and taillights, nicer interior materials, and increased sound deadening in the cabin.

You might also be considering: Ford Edge, Honda Crosstour, Subaru Outback

Toyota’s marriage between sedan and SUV comes in an attractive well-proportioned vehicle intended to fit in at the soccer fields, the weekend cottage, or for a night at the opera. Family oriented at its core, the Venza has an ample 36.2 cubic feet of cargo space behind the second row. The large liftgate allows for easy access and the low load floor helps save your back. The base LE comes with helpful dual zone climate control, display screen, and reading lights for the spacious rear seat row. The XLE and Limited models get more standard luxury features like heated seats, a leather trimmed steering wheel, and keyless entry and start. The Limited is powered by the 3.5-liter V-6 mated to all-wheel drive, delivering the power and handling expected for $40,000. Otherwise the LE and XLE offer your choice of front-wheel drive or all-wheel drive and the XLE can be fitted with the base four-cylinder or upgraded to the V-6. For $2000, the V-6 is a bit of a no-brainer since it gets nearly the same gas millage as the four-cylinder and moves the Venza with an authority the four just can’t match. The look and feel of the Venza’s interior won’t win any awards—the ivory leather is quite nice though—but it is well organized and has modern features like a USB connection and 12-volt outlets to keep the family happy.

New for 2015

The Tow Prep Package is now standard on V-6 models. It comes with a larger radiator fan and a heavy-duty alternator to help handle loads of up to 3,500 pounds. A sonar-based backup sensor is now standard on all Venza’s.

title: 2015 Toyota Tundra
subTitle: A workhorse with upscale options.
promoTeaserSmall: A workhorse with upscale options.
promoTeaser: A workhorse with upscale options.
metaKeywords: 2015 Toyota Tundra; Toyota; pikcup; truck; Japanese
metaDescription: A workhorse with upscale options. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Pickup
Price range: $29,610–$49,075 (includes destination)
Trim levels: SR, SR5, TRD Pro, Limited, Platinum, 1794 Edition
Engines: 4.6-liter V-8, 310 horsepower; 5.7-liter V-8, 381 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 4.6-liter, RWD: 15/19; 4.6-liter, AWD: 14/18; 5.7-liter, RWD: 13/18; 5.7-liter, AWD: 13/17 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 overall rating
Our favorite standard feature: Large interior control knobs are easier for gloved hands to use.
Notable standard features on this model: High Solar Energy-Absorbing (HSEA) glass filters out most harmful UV rays to help reduce occupant sun exposure, prolongs interior material life, and to keep the interior cooler on sunny days.
Notable options on this model: A blind-spot monitoring system is optional on the Limited, Platinum, and 1974 Edition models.
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Silverado, Dodge Ram, Ford F-150, Ram 1500

Toyota’s half-ton pick-up got a makeover last year so not much has changed for 2015. Last year’s styling tweaks, including a wider, big-rig style grille, a more sculpted exterior, and an attractive new dash design, still look fresh. There are six trim grades in the versatile Tundra line in three cabin sizes: Regular Cab, Double Cab, and Crew Max. Four-wheel-drive is optional on all but the off-road-ready TRD Pro. The SR and SR5 models are powered by a 4.6-liter V-8 but if your work or play demands more muscle you can choose the 5.7-liter V-8 or step up to the Limited, Platinum, 1794 Edition, or TRD Pro models that all come with the larger power plant. The 1794 Edition—in reference to the founding date of a San Antonio ranch that now happens to be the site of the Tundra assembly plant—has a western themed interior with saddle brown embossed leather and ultra-suede. It features heated and ventilated front seats as well as Toyota’s Entune Premium JBL Audio system with navigation and an app suite. Interior comforts abound but the Tundra was made for serious work. Add the Tow Package and take advantage of the TOW/HAUL shift mode that adjusts the throttle, shift timing, and includes better cooling and electrical systems to deal with the extra stress of pulling large loads.

New for 2015

A spray-in bed liner is a newly available option. Under seat storage has been added to select Double Carb models. The TRD Pro model is new for 2015 and gets a number of off-road specific features.

title: 2015 Toyota Tacoma
subTitle: A compact pickup done right.
promoTeaserSmall: A compact pickup done right.
promoTeaser: A compact pickup done right.
metaKeywords: 2015 Toyota Tacoma; Toyota; pickup; truck; Japanese
metaDescription: A compact pickup done right. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Pickup
Price range: $21,850–$38,500 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Access, Double, TRD Pro
Engines: 2.7-liter four-cylinder, 159 horsepower; 4.0-liter V-6, 236 horsepower
Transmissions: 5- or 6-speed manual, 4-or 5-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): I-4, manual, RWD: 21/25; I-4, manual, AWD: 18/20; I-4, automatic, RWD: 19/24; I-4, automatic, AWD: 18/21; V-6, automatic, RWD: 17/21; V-6, manual, AWD: 16 /19; V-6, automatic, AWD: 16/21 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 overall rating
Our favorite standard feature: Fold-up rear bench with under-seat storage
Notable standard features on this model: Tilt-and-telescope steering wheel with audio controls.
Notable options on this model: Hill-start assist and downhill assist
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Colorado, Nissan Frontier

Like most pickups today, the Tacoma can be had in a mind-boggling array of configurations. Five seats are standard, but the rest is up to you. The first choice is cab style. There is the Access Cab, with two front doors that swing wider for second row access, or the Double Cab, with four full-size doors. Once you’ve got your cab sorted, think about bed length—short or long, both come standard with a composite liner and two-tier loading deck—and drive wheels—rear-wheel drive or four-wheel drive. Don’t forget to consider the powertrain. There are two-engine sizes and four transmission choices. After all that, choosing the exterior color and options should be a cinch. There are also a handful of options packages to further customize your Tacoma. A work truck, a family weekend helper, or an off-road plaything, there is a Tacoma to meet the needs of every pickup buyer.

New for 2015

The TRD Pro Series adds an off-road ready suspension and unique wheels and tires.

title: 2015 Toyota Sienna
subTitle: Taking care of the family business.
promoTeaserSmall: Taking care of the family business.
promoTeaser: Taking care of the family business.
metaDescription: Taking care of the family business. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Minivan
Price range: $29,485–$47,035 (includes destination)
Trim levels: L, LE, SE, SE Premium, XLE, XLE Premium, Limited, Limited Premium
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 266 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): FWD: 18/25; AWD: 16/23 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick plus; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 overall rating
Our favorite standard feature: Side curtain air bags for all rows
Notable standard features on this model: Backup camera
Notable options on this model: The Driver Easy Speak options that projects the driver’s voice throughout the vehicle using the vehicle’s speakers.
You might also be considering: Dodge Grand Caravan, Honda Odyssey, Nissan Quest

While a lot of manufacturers are giving up on the minivan, Toyota keeps improving its Sienna for those who need the versatility only a minivan can provide. The 2015 exterior refresh includes slimmer headlights and sharper front grille. Inside, Sienna veterans will appreciate the new more cohesive dash design. Gone is the asymmetrical swoop in the dash to make way for a thoughtful, driver-oriented center panel that facilitates efficient use of the various controls like the three-zone climate system and displays for multi-media and navigation. Several trims are available beginning with the base L starting at just over $30,000, and climaxing with the Limited trim that will put you well over $40,000. All-wheel drive is available on several models, LE, XLE and Limited, and those with more sporting aspirations will gravitate toward the SE trim and its sport-tuned suspension and more aggressive exterior accents. With the second-row bench and the third row upright, the Sienna can carry eight passengers. If you choose the second-row captain’s chairs, that number is reduced to seven. Should those passengers get out of hand, you have a new ally in the ground-breaking Driver Easy Speak option. It broadcasts your voice—without having to shout—through the vehicle’s speaker system, “Attention, this is your mother speaking. Return the juice boxes to the cupholders!” Who says minivans aren’t cool?

New for 2015

The Driver Easy Speak system is so brilliant it bears mentioning again.

title: 2015 Toyota Sequoia
subTitle: Big and brawny.
promoTeaserSmall: Big and brawny.
promoTeaser: Big and brawny.
metaKeywords: 2015 Toyota Sequoia; Toyota; Japanese; SUV; sport-utility
metaDescription: Big and brawny. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: SUV
Price range: $45,320–$65,245 (includes destination)
Trim levels: SR5, Limited, Platinum
Engine: 5.7-liter V-8, 381 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): FWD: 13/18; AWD: 13/ 17 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: N/A
Our favorite standard feature: Second and third row retracable sunshades
Notable standard features on this model: Tow package
Notable options on this model: Blu-ray disc player
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Tahoe, Ford Explorer, Nissan Armada

One engine choice is all you get in the outsize Sequoia but at 381 horses this 5.7-liter V-8 is plenty to push this big sport-ute around. The brawny V-8, integrated hitch, and trailer-sway control system make towing—a maximum of 7,400 pounds—a breeze. You do have a choice of either two-wheel or four-wheel drive. If driving challenges like steep inclines or difficult weather figure regularly into your schedule, consider adding Toyota’s Multi-Mode 4-wheel-drive system with a limited-slip locking center differential. The interior is voluminous to be sure, seating eight adults while still maintaining 18.9 cubic feet of dedicated cargo space in the back. Fold down the second- and third-row seats and capacity reaches an expansive 120.1 cubic feet.

The ultra-wide dash accommodates all the necessary instrumentation, climate controls, and even double-decker glove compartments. Still, for its size this large SUV has one of the tightest turning circles you’ll find and handles the curves with unexpected grace. Adventure essentials like running boards, roof rack, and headlight-washers are standard on all three trims. Choose the SR5 Sport Appearance package for a unique black interior. The Limited offers some leather accents and Lexus-inspired gauges, while the Platinum ramps up the mechanical tech with adaptive air suspension and a laser-based cruise control system that measures the distance to the cars ahead and brakes when necessary. Fortunately, the Sequoia does not suffer from the boxy exterior design so common in its class giving it the kind of driveway appeal your neighbors may appreciate.

New for 2015

Entune audio system with navigation and the Toyota App suite.

title: 2015 Toyota RAV4
subTitle: Getting better every year.
promoTeaserSmall: Getting better every year.
promoTeaser: Getting better every year.
metaKeywords: 2015 Toyota RAV4; Toyota; SUV; sport-utility; crossover; Japanese
metaDescription: Getting better every year. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: SUV/crossover
Price range: $24,565–$30,735 (includes destination)
Trim levels: LE, XLE, Limited
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 176 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): FWD: 24/31; AWD: 22/29 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: FWD 4/5 overall rating; AWD 5/5 overall rating
Our favorite standard feature: Backup camera
Notable standard features on this model: Eco mode
Notable options on this model: Height-adjustable power liftgate available on XLE
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Equinox, Ford Escape, Honda CRV

Toyota’s RAV4 was a pioneer in the compact sport-utility market and, although its grown significantly since then, it remains a favorite in its category. While it’s grown larger, it’s also become more stylish with a subtly sculpted exterior and an attractive, smartly organized interior. Despite it’s more polished look, the RAV4 still excels as a cargo carrier. It can swallow more than 37 cubic feet of gear behind its third row and more than 70 with its third- and second-row seats folded. It can be also be optioned with all wheel drive. Three trims are available. The base LE comes standard with an array of comfort and safety features, the only option being roof rails. The XLE includes the rails, a moonroof, five-spoke seventeen-inch alloy wheels, and adds HD radio and traffic to infotainment system, Entune. A two-tone terracotta and black interior adds a little flair on the Limited edition. Not quite as luxurious as the name Limited implies, it does add leather trim on steering wheel shifter, a height-adjustable power liftgate, and eighteen-inch alloy wheels. The Limited also can be optioned with driving aids like blind spot warning, Rear Cross-Traffic Alert, and lane departure warning. Every trim includes a backup camera, Toyota’s Star Safety system that improves brake reaction, traction, and stability, as well as two 12-volt power outlets. And for days when you are have to squeeze that oversized science project to school, you’ll appreciate a second row that folds completely flat. The RAV4 proves you don’t have to be surrounded by leather and wood to feel well taken care of.

New for 2015

Eighteen-inch wheels with black painted pockets and pearl white exterior paint are part of the new Blizzard Pearl Premium Package, available on the Limited trim only.

title: 2017 Ford Escape
subTitle: Check out the safety and connectivity added to the menu for the new generation of Ford's compact crossover.
promoTeaserSmall: Check out the safety and connectivity added to the menu for the new generation of Ford's compact crossover.
promoTeaser: Check out the safety and connectivity added to the menu for the new generation of Ford's compact crossover.
metaKeywords: Ford at Los Angeles Auto Show
metaDescription: Check out the safety and connectivity added to the menu for the new generation of Ford's compact crossover.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive compact sport-utility vehicle
Release date: Early 2016
Estimated price: Starting around $25,000
Competes against: Honda CR-V, Kia Sportage, Mazda CX-5, Toyota RAV4
What’s most interesting: Impressive number of active safety features

The Escape is Ford’s entry in the booming compact sport-utility market, the company’s second-best-selling vehicle behind the Ford F-150 pickup—a combination of slick styling and agile handling that trails only the Honda CR-V in the crowded segment sales race.

But no one remembers who runs second, and to push the Escape to the front of the field, Ford has given its compact crossover freshened front and rear styling, an updated interior with soft-touch surfaces and a new instrument panel, two new EcoBoost engines, and a bevy of new techno goodies.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/zVlJKgRSilQ" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Driver assist features top the list of new tech items: adaptive cruise control that can bring the vehicle to a complete stop; active park assist that can handle ordinary parallel parking or backing in at right angles to the curb; lane keeping assist that can nudge the vehicle back into the center of its path; and a driver alert system that monitors the lane-keeping system for signs that the person at the wheel may be fatigued. Sync Connect is another new feature that is sure to be a strong selling point. Operating via a smartphone app, it allows the owner to remotely lock, unlock, or even start the Escape from anywhere there’s cell service.

The two new turbocharged engines, both four-cylinders, are a 180-horsepower 1.5-liter and a 2.0-liter rated for a robust 245 horsepower. A 2.5-liter four-cylinder continues to be the standard engine, offered only in the base S trim level. All the engines are mated to a six-speed automatic transmission, and Ford anticipates a five percent fuel economy improvement in the new turbos. The new Escape is due to reach Ford showrooms in the spring as a 2017 model.

title: 2017 Fiat 124 Spider
subTitle: Italian answer to the Mazda Miata is coming next summer.
promoTeaserSmall: Italian answer to the Mazda Miata is coming next summer.
promoTeaser: Italian answer to the Mazda Miata is coming next summer.
metaKeywords: Fiat at Los Angeles Auto Show
metaDescription: Italian answer to the Mazda Miata is coming next summer.

pageElements.text:
Type: Two-passenger front-engine, rear-wheel-drive roadster
Release date: Summer 2016
Estimated price range: $26,000 to $35,000
Competes against: Mazda MX-5 Miata
What's most interesting: Italianate interpretation of Japanese design

Ever since the new Mazda MX-5 Miata made its debut, we’ve been waiting for its Italian counterpart, and here, at last, it is. Unveiled at the L.A. Auto Show, the Fiat 124 Spider revives a cherished name from the past with a design that draws its inspiration from the 1967 Pinin Farina original. But while the sheetmetal is all Fiat, most of the subdural elements of the new two seater—chassis and suspension design—are Mazda.

The key difference lies under the hood, which shelters Fiat’s turbocharged 1.4-liter four-cylinder, rated for 160 horsepower—about the same as the Miata’s non-turbo 2.0-liter, but with considerably more torque: 180 pound-feet. That’s important, because the fetching Fiat interpretation of the roadster is substantially bigger than the tightly wrapped Miata—five inches longer—and substantially heavier: the basic Spider with six-speed manual transmission weighs about 100 pounds more than the Mazda version.

To lovers of Italian style, this probably won’t matter. There will be two models, the basic Classico and the uplevel Lusso (Italian for luxury). With the on-sale date still a half-year away—the roadster will reach Fiat’s U.S. showrooms next summer as a 2017 model—pricing is still a guess.
But with its more luxurious persona, expect it to be higher than its Miata cousin.

title: 2017 Infiniti QX30 AWD
subTitle: A crossover greater than the sum of its parts.
promoTeaserSmall: A crossover greater than the sum of its parts.
promoTeaser: A crossover greater than the sum of its parts.
metaKeywords: Infiniti at Los Angeles Auto Show
metaDescription: A crossover greater than the sum of its parts.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-door, five-passenger front- or all-wheel-drive crossover utility vehicle
Release date: Mid-2016
Estimated price: Upper $30,000 to mid-$40,000 range
Competes against: Mercedes-Benz GLA-Class, BMW X1, Acura RDX
What’s most interesting: Voluptuous styling

The Infiniti QX30 is made of the same basic pieces as its competitors, but how they’re put together adds up to something special. This new entry in the premium compact crossover segment has style—all the way from its boldly thrusting mesh grille to the crescent cut that zigzags across the rear pillar. Infiniti executive design director Alfonso Albaisa points out the long hood, the cabin that’s slid back on the chassis, and what he calls the “cool gestures” of the body’s flowing lines and dramatic creases. He refers to the body’s “muscles.” Bottom line: If you’re looking for straight and flat, go to Land Rover.

The all-wheel-drive QX30 AWD, sitting at the Los Angeles Auto Show with the front-wheel-drive Q30S—which made its debut at the Frankfurt Auto Show earlier this fall—are greater than the sum of their parts, but the parts aren’t bad. This crossover starts with a turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine that makes 208 horsepower. A seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission transmits that output, and the driver can exercise manual control with paddle shifters, if so desired. The QX30 promises to be involving and entertaining en route and will always make a splash upon arrival.

Albaisa also says the body’s “artistry” translates into “tailoring” inside the cabin. Again, there’s nothing pathbreaking inside, but it’s all put together so marvelously. In the QX30, it's Nappa leather or cloth. In the Q30S, the white leather inserts in the front seat cushions reappear on the upper parts of the rear seats. “We’re not just wrapping something in leather,” he says. It’s more like being wrapped in splendor.

Of course, the Q30 Sport and QX30 AWD will be available with a suite of the latest safety and driver assistance features, including predictive forward collision warning. And look to the Infiniti Q30 for high-level infotainment content. We opened the cargo cover, where we thought a spare tire might be, and found a whopping Bose subwoofer instead. So it’s assured the phrase “tinny sound” will never be applied here.

title: 2017 Buick LaCrosse
subTitle: Full-size sedan with flair.
promoTeaserSmall: Full-size sedan with flair.
promoTeaser: Full-size sedan with flair.
metaKeywords: Buick at Los Angeles Auto Show
metaDescription: Full-size sedan with flair.

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-door, five-passenger, front- and all-wheel-drive sedan
Release date: Summer 2016
Estimated price: Mid-$30,000s
Competes against: Lexus ES350, Toyota Avalon, Lincoln MKZ
What’s most interesting: Tri-shield insignia is redesigned with colors added for a new Buick image

Big and sleek, the 2017 Buick LaCrosse presents a persuasive case for a luxurious sedan that goes about its business swiftly and quietly. Built on an all-new chassis, it’s lighter in weight and promises to deliver nimble handling, thanks to a sophisticated multilink rear suspension. Stretching out to 197.5 inches in length, the LaCrosse has an NBA-worthy back seat and an impressively capacious trunk. Everything about the design is well proportioned. In fact, the new car made its global debut here on giant twenty-inch wheels, and it’s hard to imagine the standard eighteen-inch wheels won’t seem puny by comparison.
“This car is another statement of the ongoing strength of Buick,” said General Motors president Dan Ammann.

“This car is another statement of the ongoing strength of Buick,” said General Motors president Dan Ammann. The LaCrosse is among the first GM products to use the new-generation 3.6-liter V-6 engine, which puts out 305 horsepower. Several efficiency measures are incorporated to guarantee excellent fuel economy. The eight-speed automatic transmission adds an extra level of refinement. Advanced all-wheel drive not only yields improved traction in bad weather but also better agility on dry roads.

Don’t expect to be stinted on creature comforts in the new Buick LaCrosse. The front seats have an available lumbar massage feature. Do expect a plush ride because of the self-adjusting suspension—and a quiet one because of active noise cancellation technology like that found in the headphones given out in first-class air travel.

The LaCrosse is available with Teen Driver Technology, which mutes cabin audio and portable devices when front-seat occupants are not wearing seatbelts. It also monitors preset speed limits and gives a report for parents. That's tangible proof Buick is thinking of the LaCrosse owner as a parent, not a grandparent.

images.caption: 2017 Buick LaCrosse gets the new face of Buick.
Buick's Avenir Concept that helped inspire the 2017 LaCrosse.

title: 2017 Hyundai Elantra
subTitle: One look tells you this new sedan will be desirable amid tough competition.
promoTeaserSmall: One look tells you this new sedan will be desirable amid tough competition.
promoTeaser: One look tells you this new sedan will be desirable amid tough competition.
metaKeywords: Hyundai at Los Angeles Auto Show
metaDescription: One look tells you this new sedan will be desirable amid tough competition.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
Release date: January 2016
Estimated price range: $18,250 - $24,500
Competes against: Chevrolet Cruze, Ford Focus, Honda Civic, Kia Forte, Mazda 3, Nissan Sentra, Toyota Corolla, Volkswagen Jetta
What's most interesting: Mid-size roominess in a compact sedan

What do consumers want from their compact cars? Well, everything, of course, but roominess is right near the top of the list, and that’s one of several strong suits for the sixth generation of Hyundai’s Elantra sedan.

The Elantra is a little bigger than the current car, a dimensional increase that shows to particularly good advantage in the rear seat. Although it’s nominally a compact, the EPA goes by interior volume, which bumps the Elantra up to mid-size (where it joins the Honda Civic and Toyota Corolla). Increased use of high-strength steel and massive employment of industrial adhesives add up to a 30 percent improvement in chassis rigidity, and Hyundai also cites a number of new sound-deadening measures.

There are two new engines: a 147-horsepower 2.0-liter four (standard) and a 128-hp turbocharged four, the latter paired with a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission. Hyundai claims efficiency improvements over the current Elantra powertrain choices.

Like every new car rolling out these days, the Elantra has an increased inventory of safety features. Among them are lane keeping assistance, blind spot detection, rear cross-traffic and lane change assist, and a rearview camera with dynamic guidelines. (Hyundai anticipates top ratings from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration). There's also expanded infotainment technology, wrapped up in handsome packaging that looks like a small-scale version of the mid-size Sonata sedan—although not all that small.
The new Elantra will reach dealers in early January, as a 2017 model.

title: 2016 Honda Civic Coupe
subTitle: The sexiest version to date of the all-new Civic.
promoTeaserSmall: The sexiest version to date of the all-new Civic.
promoTeaser: The sexiest version to date of the all-new Civic.
keywords: 2016 Honda Civic Coupe - LA Auto Show
metaKeywords: Honda at Los Angeles Auto Show
metaDescription: The sexiest version to date of the all-new Civic.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger compact coupe
Release date: March 2016
Estimated price range: $19,000
Competes against: Hyundai Elantra, Kia Forte Koup, Scion tC
What's most interesting: Smartphone app integration

The Honda Civic is a practical car for practical people, but this fresh coupe version of the all-new tenth-generation Civic is just plain sexy. It’s also right up to date with a new touchscreen infotainment system that supports Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, so you can run some of your favorite smartphone apps on the car’s screen. Compared with the 2015 Civic Coupe, it has a lower roofline, but more interior room, including more than five more inches of legroom in the back seat.

A first for a Civic Coupe is a turbo engine choice, a 1.5-liter four-cylinder making 174 horsepower. The standard engine is a 2.0-liter four-cylinder that makes 158 horsepower, yielding an expected 41 mpg on the highway. Most Civic Coupes have a continuously variable automatic transmission, but the base model is available with a six-speed manual.

The whole Honda Civic lineup is all new for 2016, so if a coupe is not exactly your thing, there is something—from the 41 mpg on the highway you'll get in the sedan to the fun you'll have in the upcoming Type-R performance model—that you'll find worthy of your interest.

title: 2016 Mazda CX-9
subTitle: You have to look inside to really appreciate this crossover.
promoTeaserSmall: You have to look inside to really appreciate this crossover.
promoTeaser: You have to look inside to really appreciate this crossover.
metaKeywords: Mazda at Los Angeles Auto Show
metaDescription: You have to look inside to really appreciate this crossover.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-door, front- or all-wheel-drive, seven-passenger crossover utility vehicle
Release date: Spring 2016
Estimated price: Low $30,000s
Competes against: Chevrolet Traverse, Ford Edge, Honda Pilot, Toyota Highlander, Nissan Pathfinder
What’s most interesting: Turbocharged four-cylinder engine

Look at the 2016 Mazda CX-9 in either of two ways. First, as a designer from another company observed, it has “decent proportions” and the sheetmetal “isn’t too tortured.” Or you can say this all-new seven-passenger crossover vehicle, which is 1.2 inches shorter than its predecessor yet has a 2.2-inch longer wheelbase, takes a conservative step forward.

“Notice how proud and upright the grille is,” said design director Julien Montousse. The LED headlamps add even more attitude.  And, yes, the cabin is raked back on the chassis. The show vehicle was painted in Mazda’s new Machine Gray and stood on twenty-inch wheels.

But the real highlights are inside. Craftsmanship is emphasized: genuine aluminum inlays stretch over the dashboard and doors, and there’s rosewood in the center console. There’s also what Montousse calls “a sense of horizontal spaciousness.” And the auburn Nappa leather upholstery in this Signature series model made us pant aloud. Gorgeous cabin!
A new turbocharged 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine promises peppy performance, producing an impressive 250 horsepower.

Under the hood, a new turbocharged 2.5-liter four-cylinder promises peppy performance, producing an impressive 250 horsepower. At the same time, Mazda says the CX-9 will be “among the most fuel-efficient vehicles in its class.” It weighs as much as 287 pounds less than the outgoing model, so less power is needed to maintain cruising speed; with 310 pound-feet of torque available, the six-speed automatic transmission won’t often have to hunt for a lower gear when the driver wants to hustle around someone on the highway.

The CX-9 can be equipped with Mazda’s i-Activsense suite of safety and driver assistance features, lots of infotainment goodies, and a twelve-speaker audio system. It gives up nothing to its competitors. We can’t wait to see it outside, in natural light, and then to slide in behind the wheel.

title: 2017 Mercedes-Benz SL and GLS
subTitle: Two great leaps forward for two classic Mercedes-Benz models.
promoTeaserSmall: Two great leaps forward for two classic Mercedes-Benz models.

pageElements.text:
2017 Mercedes-Benz SL-Class

Type: Two-door, two-passenger rear-wheel-drive convertible
Release date: Spring 2016
Estimated price range: Upper $60,000s
Competes against: Porsche 911, Maserati Granturismo
What’s most interesting: Stays true to its heritage

2017 Mercedes-Benz GLS-Class

Type: Four-door, seven-passenger all-wheel-drive SUV
Release date: Spring 2016
Estimated price range: Upper $80,000s
Competes against: Cadillac Escalade, Land Rover Range Rover, Infiniti QX80, Lexus LX570
What’s most interesting: A country-club locker room condensed into an SUV

Creatures of the United States’ market, the new Mercedes-Benz SL roadster and Mercedes-Benz GLS sport-utility vehicle made their global debuts at the Los Angeles Auto Show. The SL roadster was created in 1957 after Southern Californians argued for removing the top of the coupe, which had been introduced three years earlier.

The 2017 model represents a sixty-year span; as with your great aunt’s high school photo, it’s still possible to recognize the young lass. The new SL is wider, and its eyes and jewelry are a bit overdone. Inside, though, it’s breathtaking. And when there’s more than a glint of sunshine, the top comes off quickly—in fact, the car will go as fast as 25 mph while this happens. No one will look askance, either.

Not that 25 mph is remotely like top speed here. The SL comes with any of four available engines. The least of them, in the SL400, is a V-6 that puts out a mere 362 horsepower. The greatest is in the Mercedes-AMG SL65, a twin-turbocharged V-12 that makes 621 horsepower and 738 pound-feet of torque. Foothill Boulevard in suburban Pasadena will crumble beneath your wheels.
“Every car we build includes our game-changing driver assist systems to round out this incredible package,” says Mercedes-Benz USA president and CEO Steve Cannon. So everything’s taken care of.

The original SL knew about power and performance, but it wouldn’t recognize such electronically governed features as active body control with curve tilting or the intelligent lighting system with its intense LEDs.

As Mercedes’ top-of-the-line SUV, the GLS—formerly known as the GL—lacks the SL’s V-12 engine and convertible roof, but little else. It has a selection of whomping powerplants (diesel or gas V-6s and up to 577 horsepower from a V-8) and a nine-speed automatic transmission that enhances efficiency. The GLS also has a brightly trimmed yet ever-so-tasteful interior with amazing functionality.

title: Pro/Con: Is the Speed Limit Carved in Stone?
subTitle: Laura hates it when she's stuck behind a slowpoke. Molly says, Chill out. Whose side are you on?
promoTitle: Pro/Con: Is the Speed Limit Carved in Stone?
promoTeaserSmall: Laura hates it when she's stuck behind a slowpoke. Molly says, Chill out. Whose side are you on?
promoTeaser: Laura hates it when she's stuck behind a slowpoke. Molly says, Chill out. Whose side are you on?
keywords: Is the Speed Limit Carved in Stone?
metaTitle: Is the Speed Limit Carved in Stone? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Laura hates it when she's stuck behind a slowpoke. Molly says, Chill out. Whose side are you on?

contributors.displayName: Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

pageElements.text: Molly Jean Says: What's Your Hurry? It's Fine to Go Slow

It is not my fault that you are in a hurry. The Constitution does not protect your right to drive at the speed limit at all times. I make it a priority not to get a speeding ticket. Especially on two-lane roads, I do not speed. I may want to actually, God forbid, drive more slowly than the posted speed. The beauty out the window as I drive through rural Michigan sometimes is worthy of a slow roll.
Sharing the road does not mean dictating that everyone must have the exact same driving style. Take a moment to remember that you are only in charge of your own vehicle.

Once a tailgater looms in my rearview mirror, I will pull over at the next available opportunity to let them continue along. For all I know, that person is a doctor speeding to save someone’s life. No judgment here. But I would appreciate a moment to find a safe place to pull over.

Conversely, when I am in a hurry and come up on a Sunday driver, I have an inner dialogue that reminds me that perhaps that driver is not comfortable driving faster. I often think of my own mother, who is a perfectly capable driver but prefers to amble along. It helps me back off and wait for the opportunity to pass. Sometimes it is frustratingly long, but seriously it adds up to minutes, not hours.

Sharing the road does not mean dictating that everyone must have the exact same driving style. Take a moment to remember that you are only in charge of your own vehicle, and you don’t know why a person is driving slower.  Breathe deeply and enjoy the countryside until you can safely pass. Namaste.
Laura Sky Brown Says: Get Out of Your Personal Bubble (or Power Trip) and Follow the Posted Speed, Damn You
Namaste my foot, Molly.

I spend about forty-five minutes each day commuting back and forth to Jean Knows Cars World Headquarters on a two-lane paved country road. Most of the way, the posted speed is 50 mph. It is beautiful, winding through a small town and past woods and farmland. I enjoy the scenery very much. What I don’t do, however, is slow down to 30 mph and let a funeral cortege of other cars stack up behind me. If I’m the only car on the road, I might let my prevailing speed creep downward while I daydream a little. But I am always very aware if I’m in a line of cars, and I keep to the posted speed limit when someone is on the road behind me.
I enjoy the scenery very much. What I don’t do, however, is slow down to 30 mph and let a funeral cortege of other cars stack up behind me.
Molly fervently disagrees with me on that; she believes the speed limit is the maximum speed, not the only speed you can go on a surface street.

She might have the letter of the law on her side, but she’s wrong anyway. There’s a social contract that people need to follow when they share road space. I think some people tend to inhabit a little world of their own when they drive, even (especially?) on the back roads or around town. People who will not drift anywhere below the speed limit on the freeway will let themselves be lulled into it in the countryside or town. At that point, they’re just being bad neighbors.

A good driver is aware of the traffic around him or her and ensures that he or she is not blocking other people’s progress. Of course I don’t mean little old ladies who are genuinely uncomfortable going the speed limit. The rest of you, step it up, would you?

I remember my first year as a licensed driver, feeling very comfortable going the posted speeds on all roads and thinking that the speed limits were very well chosen. Into the second year of driving, I began to realize that those speed limits were chosen to be the comfort zone for the worst, least experienced drivers. Translation: Just about anyone should be capable of comfortably hewing to the posted speed limit on most days. Speed limits certainly are not dangerously high anywhere I’ve ever driven. So quit daydreaming, talking on your phone, adjusting your radio dial, or going on some kind of first-guy-in-the-line power trip, and go the speed limit if there are cars behind you, for God’s sake. image: istock/Thinkstock

title: Book Review: 100 Things for Gearheads
subTitle: Are you working on your car adventure bucket list? Jason Fogelson's book has some ideas. So do I.
promoTeaserSmall: Are you working on your car adventure bucket list? Jason Fogelson's book has some ideas. So do I.
promoTeaser: Are you working on your car adventure bucket list? Jason Fogelson's book has some ideas. So do I.
metaKeywords: 100 Things for Every Gearhead to Do Before They Die
metaDescription: Are you working on your car adventure bucket list? Jason Fogelson's book has some ideas. So do I.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
100 Things for Every Gearhead to Do before They Die
by Jason Fogelson
Reedy Press, 2015
208 pages, $18
Available from Books for Gearheads

Jason Fogelson has created a bucket list in this book, supposedly for gearheads, but any driver/historian/adventurer or family looking for next year’s quirky vacation itinerary will enjoy it. To help your imagination, Fogelson has created an index divided thus: Rides and Drives, Auctions, Car Museums, New Car Shows, Classic Car Shows, Concours d’Elegance, Factory Tours, Land Speed Records, Motorcycle Museums, Off-Roading, Racing, Rallies, Test Drives and Experiences, Driving Schools, Track Days, Motorcycle Track Days, and Wrench on Your Ride. The pages of the last category will undoubtedly remain pristine in many books.
I discovered that I have completed almost half of the list—forty-two, to be precise. Not sure I have enough time left to complete Fogelson’s Top 100.

So what strikes your fancy? What adventure have you already completed on your way to automotive nirvana? Which of these do you think you need to tick off to become a certified “car guy"? How about just picking one adventure from each chapter?

Who cares? Well, I cared enough to actually thumb through every single page highlighting the little numbered Interstate logo at the top of each thrilling moment (some not so thrilling, some actually boring) that I had completed in my lifetime. I discovered that I have completed almost half of the list—forty-two, to be precise. Not sure I have enough time left to complete Fogelson’s Top 100. [Nonsense, my dear—Ed.]
I edged the Range Rover all the way down Black Bear Pass, one three-point turn after another, until I reached Telluride. It remains my most accomplished off-road moment.

Imagine if you used this book for the family vacation to Colorado to see the relatives in Fort Collins. You could thumb through the Gearhead List and find the Pikes Peak Highway (#9) and the Alpine Loop from Ouray to Silverton to Lake City (#64). I just happen to have done both. The first was during practice for the actual Race to the Clouds, with Roger Mears at the wheel. We started halfway up the hill, and I distinguished myself by passing out from lack of oxygen with only one leg in the racing suit I’d borrowed from Roger, Jr. I ended up on oxygen in a MASH unit at the base of the hill, while Roger, Sr., carried on and crashed off the mountain, stopped from certain death by a snowbank that hadn’t melted all the way. I completed the second Colorado drive in a Range Rover, then finished off the entire terrifying adventure by edging all the way down Black Bear Pass, one three-point turn after another, until I reached Telluride. It remains my most accomplished off-road moment to date.

Oh, I have more stories, but why not go make your own? Fogelson has created this useful framework for you. I’d suggest you get out a map (you remember those things?) and a highlighter and put dots on the locations of all 100. Then string a few together. You’ll be entertaining yourself—gearhead or not—for years to come.

Now I am preparing my own list, of Things Every Gearhead Should Do in Europe before They Die. I'll post it on this site when it's done. Meanwhile, I would like Fogelson to send me his definitive list of the Top 100 Albums Every Music Freak Should Own Before They Die. He definitely has it in him.

title: Porsche Mission E Concept
subTitle: Porsche's electric-car plans come thrillingly to life in this concept.
promoTeaserSmall: Porsche's electric-car plans come thrillingly to life in this concept.
promoTeaser: Porsche's electric-car plans come thrillingly to life in this concept.
metaDescription: Porsche's electric-car plans come thrillingly to life in this concept.

pageElements.text: Without using the phrase "Tesla fighter," it's hard to fully appreciate the Porsche Mission E concept that was unveiled at the 2015 Frankfurt Auto Show. That's because this car, Porsche's first all-electric sports car, is promised to go on sale in less than five years, and is unmistakably going to be a strong Tesla competitor when it gets here.

Consider the specs. It will charge in fifteen minutes to 80 percent of battery capacity. Its full range on a charge is more than 300 miles. It has two permanent magnet synchronous motors (like the power behind this year's 24 Hours of Le Mans winner, the Porsche 919 Hybrid), making a total of 600 horsepower. It will go from 0 to 62 mph in less than 3.5 seconds. It has all-wheel drive, all-wheel steering, and an alluring aluminum, steel, and carbon fiber polymer body.

Porsche calls its dedicated charger the Porsche Turbo Charging system, a good riposte to Tesla's Supercharger moniker. This 800-volt port is what gives the Mission E its lightning-quick fifteen-minute charge time. You can also connect the Mission E to a 400-volt charging station.
Some of the coolest features on this concept include the use of cameras to replace side mirrors, and the use of holograms to adjust the five round instrument panel binnacles to the driver's position.

No matter how you feel about electric sports cars, you can't deny that competition will be good for the marketplace. Maybe, in the not-too-distant future, these will actually come down enough in price that the more budget-minded shoppers among us can justify owning one.

title: 2016 Alfa Romeo 4C
subTitle: Lightweight but serious, and seriously beautiful.
promoTeaserSmall: Lightweight but serious, and seriously beautiful.
promoTeaser: Lightweight but serious, and seriously beautiful.
metaDescription: Lightweight but serious, and seriously beautiful.

pageElements.text:
Type: Two-passenger, rear-wheel-drive coupe or convertible
Price range: $55,495 - $69,995 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: 4C, 4C Launch Edition, Spider
Engine: 1.75-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 237 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/34 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: Leather-wrapped steering wheel
Notable standard features on this model: Halogen projector headlamps, 7.0-inch infotainment screen, remote keyless entry
Notable options on this model: Dual racing exhaust, leather package, bi-xenon projector headlamps
You might also be considering: BMW M3, Chevrolet Corvette, Porsche Cayman

The Alfa Romeo 4C is a hot car. Boasting strong sweeping lines, a sleek profile, and classic styling, this vehicle will turn heads. Beyond that, it will provide a satisfyingly engaging experience behind the wheel, the main point of this carbon-fiber-bodied two-seater. A 1.75-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine, teamed with a six-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission with Launch Control and paddle shifters, produces 237 horsepower. What's Launch Control? It's triggered when you press on the brake, fully push down the accelerator, and touch the left steering wheel paddle. Release the brake, and the Launch Control system controls the transmission, power, and traction for maximized acceleration.  Top speed: 160 mph. You can use the Driving Mode selector to choose All Weather, Natural, Dynamic, or Race modes. This is not a car for comfort but one for excitement. The 4C and 4C Launch Edition are coupes, while the Spider has a cloth top; a carbon fiber hard top is coming later in 2016. Personalization choices include track packages, six wheel options, and four choices of brake calipers, as well as extra-cost color options that give you more than one kind of red to choose from.
New for 2016: A carbon fiber hard top is planned for later in the year on the Spider.

More to Read:

2015 Alfa Romeo 4C Spider

title: 2016 Hyundai Sonata Hybrid
subTitle: The hybrid for normal people.
