pageElements.text:
2016 Hyundai Sonata Hybrid Limited

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive hybrid sedan
Trim levels: SE, Limited
Base price: $26,825 (SE); $30,925 (Limited) (prices include destination charge)
This car: $35,765
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder plus lithium-polymer battery with electric motor; total 193 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 39 mpg city/43 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: 2015 Top Safety Pick
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Ford Fusion Hybrid Titanium ($31,815)
2015 Honda Accord Hybrid EX-L ($32,875)
2016 Toyota Camry Hybrid XLE ($34,955)
Fun-O-Meter: 7

What would it take to get you to buy a hybrid car? It’s a question worth asking, because for many years people have thought they were too expensive, technologically a little scary, or just not worth the hassle for a few extra mpg. Some of them looked (ahem) weird, too.
And all of them were boring.

This is where I admit to my longtime prejudice against hybrids. It was based on solid anecdotal evidence. If you did the math, it made no financial sense to buy one, at least way back when the first Honda Insight and Toyota Prius came out in in the late 1990s. You couldn’t put enough miles on it to ever amortize the extra cost. But it wasn’t about the cost or even its fuel economy to the people who bought it. It was all about being green. And then there was the strident, proselytizing Ed Begley, Jr., factor, although I did love him in Best in Show.
For someone who gardened organically long before the first hybrid car and belonged to the Biodynamic Farming and Gardening Society, I was strangely antagonistic. Was.

For someone who gardened organically for twenty years before the first hybrid car and belonged to the Biodynamic Farming and Gardening Society (everyone else was eighty-two), I was strangely antagonistic toward the Prius people. Then again, I was also the person who belonged to The Nature Conservancy and went to an annual TNC meeting in northern Michigan driving a high-performance, twelve-cylinder AMG Mercedes-Benz coupe. A woman engulfed in a dense cloud of patchouli oil accosted me when I rolled up. “How do you justify driving that car here?!?” she shouted. “Too far to walk,” I said.

These days, even the most cautious shoppers can feel safe to put a toe into the water. 
The 2016 Hyundai Sonata Hybrid just might be the car to inspire you to do a cannonball.

So, what’s to like about this second-generation Sonata Hybrid? Start with a commendable 10 percent fuel economy improvement over the first-generation Sonata Hybrid, to 39 mpg in the city and 43 mpg on the highway. If that doesn’t impress you, compare it to the turbo 1.6-liter four-cylinder gasoline-fueled Sonata Limited, which gets 28 mpg city and 38 mpg on the highway.

The new Hybrid also boasts a 10 percent increase in cargo capacity, up to 13.3 cubic feet, over the last Sonata Hybrid. Competing hybrid brands are in the same ballpark for gas sipping, although the Sonata Hybrid can go a class-leading 24 miles on electricity alone, but the Sonata Hybrid is the class leader in cargo space.
For price comparison, the 2015 Sonata Limited (the top-end model) starts at $34,350, including destination charge, while the 2016 Sonata Hybrid Limited starts at $27,350.
This hybrid has one great advantage: It starts with a really solid foundation, the Sonata.

This hybrid has one great advantage: It starts with a really solid foundation, the Sonata, which was redesigned in 2015. It looks more sophisticated, with a very handsome, clean front and rear appearance.

The interior is beautiful and elegant, a blend of tasteful, neutral colors including taupe, gray, matte black, a high-gloss wood trim, and a splash of piano black. Multiple textures include perforated leather seat inserts in all positions. The (heated) steering wheel and shift knob are also wrapped in leather. The doors are trimmed in a reasonably attractive stitched leatherette. Keeps the cost down, don’t you know.

At the more expensive Limited level, both front and rear seats are heated, and the front seats are also ventilated, as in cooled. The steering wheel is also heated. Those of us in cold climates pause to praise the Hyundai product planner.

A gorgeous panorama roof is part of the $4,500 Ultimate package, which is more about the full suite of advanced 360-degree safety systems. This package also includes a colorful 8.0-inch touchscreen navigation unit. Below it is the climate control system with a really neat set of control buttons that seem to float in their space, not closed in by trim.

Aside from cosmetics, there are a few functional details to consider. First is a horrid buzzing noise when you move the shifter from Park into Drive. The first few times, I about jumped out of my skin. But then, hybrids can be very quiet, and I suppose this is a good way to ensure you know when your car is engaged. In a similar vein, the push-button start has an Off setting that lights up to prove you have shut off the engine. Again, with the silence of a hybrid, this is useful.

I felt a bit of heaviness in the suspension on rough patches, in the way that hybrids can feel heavy. The steering is passably connected, a bit like me in Catholic grade school.

The Verdict:

Overall, apart from the gauges that let you play “how fuel-efficient am I being?” there are not that many differences from a traditional car, at least not differences that you can feel—until you realize how infrequently you have to head to the gas station.

And that’s just the point with the Sonata Hybrid. There’s nothing holier-than-thou about owning or driving this kind of hybrid. It’s attractive, functional, comfortable, and affordable. Why wouldn’t you want to drive one?

title: 2016 Volkswagen Beetle Dune
subTitle: Something simple and happy out of VW. Refreshing!
promoTeaserSmall: Something simple and happy out of VW. Refreshing!
promoTeaser: Something simple and happy out of VW. Refreshing!
metaDescription: Something simple and happy out of VW. Refreshing!

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-passenger, front-wheel-drive two-door compact sedan or convertible
Release date: Early 2016 (sedan); fall 2016 (convertible)
Estimated price range: High $20,000s
Competes against: Ford Focus, Honda Civic, Kia Soul, Mini Cooper
What’s most interesting: Sits a little higher off the ground

Volkswagen is always good for a special-edition Beetle. The bulbous car just makes you want to decorate it, somehow. In the past few years since the current version came out in 2011, there have been pink ones, denim-colored ones, a Fender guitar edition, and a set of Beetle convertibles based on 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s design themes.

But the Beetle Dune is not a mere gold color scheme; it is an homage to the Baja Bugs of the 1960s, which were not just no-frills but anti-frills vehicles. The 2016 Beetle Dune started out as a concept, shown at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit in January 2014, but soon you'll be able to buy one.

At least, the Beetle Dune attempts to channel the "iconic spirit" of those legendary VWs. It does this with 0.4 inch more in ground clearance, a central air intake in the front bumper, a rear spoiler, special side moldings, and wheel-arch extensions. It gets special eighteen-inch Canyon aluminum wheels. Both doors get "Dune" graphics, and the taillights are LEDs. An optional Technology package adds bi-xenon headlights with LED daytime running lights and LED lighting around the license plate. (Not quite something you can picture on a vintage Baja Bug.) The engine is the standard Beetle's turbocharged 1.8-liter four-cylinder making 170 horsepower, teamed with a six-speed automatic transmission.

Sport seats get contrasting orange stitching, and there's a standard 6.3-inch infotainment screen with a rearview camera and parking distance sensors. Apple CarPlay and Android Auto connectivity are standard. A Technology package can be added to get a tilting and sliding sunroof, push-button start with keyless access, and dual-zone automatic climate control, as well as Fender premium audio.  No pricing has been released yet.
You can get the Beetle Dune in the Sandstorm Yellow shown here, or in white or black pearl. The yellow Dune has body-color upper door and dashboard trim; the others get black.

images.caption: 2016 Volkswagen Beetle Dune: coupe and convertible.

title: 2017 Cadillac XT5
subTitle: Understated, for a Cadillac, but with all the luxury touches you'd expect.
promoTeaserSmall: Understated, for a Cadillac, but with all the luxury touches you'd expect.
promoTeaser: Understated, for a Cadillac, but with all the luxury touches you'd expect.
metaKeywords: Cadillacs at Los Angeles Auto Show
metaDescription: Understated, for a Cadillac, but with all the luxury touches you'd expect.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive luxury crossover
Release date: Spring 2016
Estimated price: $40,000
Competes against: Audi Q5, Acura RDX, BMW X3, Infiniti QX50, Lexus RX, Lincoln MKX
What’s most interesting: Rear Camera Mirror system with video display

The luxury crossover formerly known as the SRX has been replaced with this all-new model named the XT5 (which, according to Cadillac, stands for crossover touring five-seater). Cadillac crossovers are going to get the XT designation from now on. This one is lighter (by a not inconsiderable 278 pounds) and more spacious for rear-seat passengers than the outgoing model. It's also, we should mention, better-looking, and it has ridiculous levels of technology on board.

"A feeling of space is the ultimate luxury," said global design chief Andrew Smith, and especially in a crossover, that makes perfect sense. To that end, the lines and surfaces inside the XT5 are clean and—for a Cadillac—relatively unadorned.

Cadillac's Cue infotainment system gets an upgrade for the XT5, featuring a faster processor—you'll just have to try it out and see if you think so—plus a wireless phone charger in the center console, 4G LTE making it a wireless hot spot, and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto smartphone integration. There's an optional head-up display and LED lighting inside and out—although full LED headlamps are optional.

The XT5 gets the same new 3.6-liter V-6 engine that's in the 2016 ATS, CTS, and brand-new top-of-the-line CT6 sedan. It makes 310 horsepower and is teamed with an eight-speed automatic transmission, also new. The XT5 is front-wheel drive, but an all-wheel-drive model is available.

There's a full slate of safety technology. Most notable is the Rear Camera Mirror system, which shows streaming video over the rearview mirror that has been corrected to keep from showing passengers, rear pillars, and roof images. This is claimed to increase the driver's rear vision by 300 percent, but not to worry—those passengers are still there. Lane keeping assist, full-speed-range adaptive cruise control, rear cross-traffic and side blind zone alerts, and automatic parking assist are all standard.

title: 2016 GMC Yukon XL Denali
subTitle: This big, elegant luxury-utility vehicle is one more reason GMC is a brand worth watching.
promoTeaserSmall: This big, elegant luxury-utility vehicle is one more reason GMC is a brand worth watching.
promoTeaser: This big, elegant luxury-utility vehicle is one more reason GMC is a brand worth watching.
metaDescription: This big, elegant luxury-utility vehicle is one more reason GMC is a brand worth watching.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Eight-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive extended-length sport-utility vehicle
Trim levels: XL SLE, XL SLT, XL Denali
Base price: $51,635 (base XL SLE 2WD), $71,940 (Denali 4WD) (prices include destination charge)
This car: $76,600
Engine: 6.2-liter V-8, 378 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 14 mpg city/20 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not rated
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Cadillac Escalade ESV Standard AWD ($79,565)
2016 Ford Expedition EL Platinum AWD ($67,220)
2015 Infiniti QX80 AWD ($67,345)
2016 Lincoln Navigator L AWD ($70,330)
2016 Toyota Sequoia Platinum ($65,715)

Fun-O-Meter: 7

There are stylish cars, there are big utility vehicles—and then there’s the 2016 GMC Yukon XL Denali, a prime example of both. This supersize sport-utility vehicle offers understated but absolute luxury to the buyer who doesn’t need a posh nameplate.

Its appeal is borne out by the demographics of the GMC Yukon XL buyer. This is no nouveau-riche mobile. It’s for the confidently prosperous driver. True to its standing as the sibling of the hard-working Chevrolet Suburban, the Yukon XL, sitting on its extended 130-inch wheelbase, is a vehicle for women who need to haul horse trailers. It’s for people who tow boats. Or, like me, people who need to haul around a dog pack’s worth of kennels and hunting gear. (We have the Chevy, the working girl’s less expensive version.)

GMC says the median income of the Yukon XL Denali buyer is $239,000, and the average age is forty-six, with two-thirds of buyers classified as “professional.” Almost a quarter of those are women. Tellingly, the most important reasons for buying this massive SUV are ride comfort, passenger capacity, and the need for a “family oriented vehicle.” Yukon Denali buyers cited the exterior styling, overall quality, and previous experience with the model as their deciding factors.

GMC’s global head of design and user experience is Helen Emsley, a talented salt-of-the earth Brit. She made a name as the woman who designed the stunning interior of the new Chevrolet Corvette Stingray, the best interior it has ever had. GMC consciously focused on creating a unique front and rear for the Yukon XL, with distinct C-shaped (C as in GMC) design cues. That shape is most noticeable in the taillamps and, on the XL Denali we tested, in the unique high-intensity-discharge headlamps.

“We’re trying so much, now, at GMC, to do the different materials...to get the depth,” Helen told me at the New York Auto Show this spring, when we walked around the Denali version of the smaller GMC Terrain. “We didn’t want to just bling it and chrome it out.” Having said that, the Yukon XL Denali does get a chrome grille, but it is mercifully light on meaningless bling.

The Yukon XL offers a more premium experience than the Suburban. Its materials, quiet and subdued look and feel, and details like the simple, elegant stripe of wood trim on the doors all speak to the kind of luxury that goes without saying. Twenty-inch wheels are standard on the XL Denali, while, as on the model we tested, twenty-two-inch wheels and tires are an option.

The Yukon XL Denali also has a stronger, more sophisticated presence on the road than the Suburban. That’s not all down to looks. The Yukon XL Denali’s 6.2-liter V-8 makes 420 horsepower and 460 pound-feet of torque, while the top-end Suburban LTZ has a 5.3-liter V-8, making 355 horsepower and 383 pound-feet of torque. That’s, in part, what you’re paying the extra $4,000 for when you choose the Yukon XL Denali. The Suburban gets slightly better fuel economy as a result: 15 mpg in the city and 22 mpg on the highway, compared with the Yukon XL Denali’s 14/20 mpg.

Although the Yukon XL was all new for 2015, this year’s model still gets a few changes, notably Apple CarPlay—the latest must-have connectivity feature—as well as a standard hands-free liftgate on the SLT model and the addition of lane-keeping assist. A small quality-of-life improvement is the addition of a capless fuel filler on all models.

Other quality-of-life items include optional illuminated and power-operated side assist steps and a hands-free liftgate, standard on SLT and Denali models, that opens or closes by waving your foot under the rear bumper. Its height can be easily programmed by turning a knob, then manually adjusting and setting the desired height. What’s even more to love? The controls just inside the rear cargo compartment, which let you fold the split-folding third-row seats up and down without lifting more than a finger.

Electronically speaking, there is something that more vehicles will surely be getting soon: a wireless phone charging pad, sitting on the center console. (Some phones need a special case to make them wireless charge ready.) There’s also OnStar with 4G LTE, making the XL Denali a wireless hot spot.  Infotainment is via an eight-inch touchscreen with GM’s clear, easy-to-operate Intellilink, including navigation. On the model we tested, the Open Road package ($2,860) added a rear-seat entertainment system and a power sunroof. Our test vehicle also got the twenty-two-inch aluminum wheels with painted inserts ($1,495) and an extra-cost paint job: Midnight Amethyst Metallic ($395).
The distance-to-end-of-parking-spot visual image that shows up in the instrument panel: very useful when parallel parking a vehicle that’s 224 inches long.

Active safety features include forward collision alert, which shows an icon in the instrument panel that represents the vehicle in front of you. It’s green until you get too close, when it turns amber. You can set its sensitivity to Far, Medium, Near, or (pay attention now, purists) Off. There are also lane keeping assist with lane departure warning, rear cross-traffic alert, side blind zone and lane change alert, and front and rear parking assist. The distance-to-end-of-parking-spot visual image that shows up in the instrument panel: very useful when parallel parking a vehicle that’s 224 inches long.

You can notice the more upscale feeling in the added sound-deadening efforts. The Denali has GM’s Active Noise Cancellation, which, using the audio system speakers, programs the sound in the cabin to improve the quiet feeling. It works. More mechanically, the doors are inlaid into the body-side openings to cut wind noise, and the windshield and front door glass is laminated for quiet. The result is a pleasantly hushed interior environment for such a huge vehicle.

For those who need a more normal-size SUV, there’s the regular GMC Yukon, twin of the Chevrolet Tahoe. It’s still classified as full size, and you can still seat eight (nine, if you configure it correctly), but its shorter 116-inch wheelbase and starting price of $52,360 may be more to some drivers’ tastes.
We utility-vehicle drivers are waiting for a diesel version of the Yukon, the Suburban, or both, but neither GMC nor Chevrolet has made that commitment.

The Verdict:

We utility-vehicle drivers are waiting for a diesel version of the Yukon, the Suburban, or both, to get better fuel economy, more torque for pulling the load, and less expensive maintenance. But neither GMC nor Chevrolet has made a commitment to diesel engines in anything but their newest mid-size pickups, not in the huge SUVs.

And when I say huge….owning one of these is the same kind of decision as choosing to drive a minivan. You would only choose to buy it if you really need the size, capacity, and usefulness of one. But if you need that 7,900-pound towing capacity and/or those eight seats—and you want to do all that with elegance—the Yukon XL Denali deserves serious consideration.

title: 2016 Chevrolet Cruze
subTitle: No diesel this year, but an all-new version of the popular compact car.
promoTeaserSmall: No diesel this year, but an all-new version of the popular compact car.
promoTeaser: No diesel this year, but an all-new version of the popular compact car.
metaDescription: No diesel this year, but an all-new version of the popular compact car.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive compact sedan
Price range: $17,495 – $23,995
Trim revels: L, LS, LT, Premier
Engine: Turbocharged 1.4-liter four-cylinder, 153 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed manual, six-speed automatic
Fuel economy (estimated): 28 mpg city/42 mpg highway (manual transmission), 26/39 mpg (automatic transmission)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: Rearview camera
Notable standard features on this model: Stop/start system to save fuel, rearview camera
Notable options on this model: Heated front seats, heated leather-wrapped steering wheel, heated leather-trimmed rear seats; side blind zone alert, lane keeping assist, rear cross-traffic alert, forward collision alert; eight-inch Chevrolet MyLink infotainment screen (seven-inch screen is standard); OnStar with 4GLTE connectivity that provides a Wi-Fi hot spot for seven devices; Android Auto and Apple CarPlay smartphone connectivity
You might also be considering: Ford Focus, Honda Civic, Mazda3, Toyota Corolla

All new for 2016, the compact Chevrolet Cruze has streamlined its proportions, losing 250 pounds in the process. It's 2.7 inches longer, an inch lower, and features more rear legroom, always a good thing in a compact car. It has also lost the diesel model, giving diesel fans even less choice at a confusing time with the Volkswagen scandal at a fever pitch. But don't worry; there's a diesel Cruze coming back, in the 2017 model year.
Shopping for a Cruze this year is a bit confusing. The Cruze Limited is the previous-generation model, being kept around mainly for fleet sales but still available at retail.

The LT and Premier models get the most options choices, among them a larger eight-inch touchscreen, Bose premium audio with nine speakers, heated cloth front seats (LT) and wireless phone charging (Premier). Push-button start and the ultimate cold-weather luxury, a heated steering wheel, are standard on the Premier model. Active safety features—side blind zone alert with lane change alert, rear cross-traffic alert, and rear park assist—are options on both LT and Premier models, while only the Premier get Forward Collision Alert and Intellibeam headlamps as options.

New for 2016

The Cruze is all new for 2016, with a new turbocharged 1.4-liter engine and an added RS personalization package.
The diesel Cruze goes on hiatus, with a new model expected in the 2017 model year.

More about the Chevrolet Cruze

title: 2016 Chevrolet Colorado
subTitle: Popularity assured, and now you can get it with a fuel-sipping, strong-towing turbo-diesel.
promoTeaserSmall: Popularity assured, and now you can get it with a fuel-sipping, strong-towing turbo-diesel.
promoTeaser: Popularity assured, and now you can get it with a fuel-sipping, strong-towing turbo-diesel.
metaDescription: Popularity assured, and now you can get it with a fuel-sipping, strong-towing turbo-diesel.

pageElements.text:
Type: Rear- or all-wheel-drive mid-size pickup truck
Price range: $20,995–$31,660
Trim levels: Work Truck, LT, Z71
Engines: Turbo-diesel 2.8-liter four-cylinder, 181 horsepower; 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 200 horsepower; 3.6-liter V-6, 305 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed automatic, six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 2.8-liter turbo-diesel, RWD: 28 mpg city/31 mpg highway; 2.5-liter four-cylinder: 22/26-27 mpg; 3.6-liter, V-6: 21/26 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good (moderate overlap front test only)
Our favorite standard feature: Hidden under-seat storage
Notable standard features on this model: OnStar with 4G LTE and available Wi-Fi (LT)
Notable options on this model: Heated front seats, forward collision alert, lane departure warning
You might also be considering: GMC Canyon, Honda Ridgeline, Nissan Frontier, Toyota Tacoma

The Chevrolet Colorado is only a year old, and this sibling to the GMC Canyon is already a definite success. Named Motor Trend Truck of the Year in both 2015 and 2016, it has also garnered praise for its cost to own, resale value, and technology. It's up to date in the latter, for 2016 adding Apple CarPlay smartphone connectivity. The Colorado already had OnStar with 4G LTE and a Wi-Fi hot spot in the cab—or anywhere near the Colorado if it’s turned on—that will connect seven devices. There are four USB ports, an eight-inch in-dash touchscreen display, Bluetooth, and Chevrolet's MyLink infotainment.

The available safety tech includes forward collision alert and lane departure warning. A rearview camera is standard on all models. Triple-sealed doors and thick windshield and side glass help keep exterior noises from entering the cabin. A huge center console keeps all your necessaries at hand. A secret storage compartment under the rear seat will keep your goods safe. And there are plenty of charging ports and a non-skid surface for your phone.

A new turbo-diesel engine ups towing capability from 7,000 pounds to 7,700 pounds, if you choose the rear-wheel-drive model and get the optional trailering package. It does that while achieving 31 mpg on the highway, and you won't top either of those in the mid-size truck category.

New for 2016

The Colorado was an all-new model for 2015.
A 2.8-liter turbo-diesel engine is new for 2016. Tech wise, MyLink infotainment system gets Apple CarPlay capability, and there's an enhanced driver information display in the dash.

More about the Chevrolet Colorado

2015 Chevrolet Colorado

2015 Chevrolet Colorado: L.A. Show November 20, 2013

title: Subaru Impreza Concept
subTitle: Original, uncontrived, appealing. Safe to say we're excited to see this come out next year.
promoTeaserSmall: Original, uncontrived, appealing. Safe to say we're excited to see this come out next year.
promoTeaser: Original, uncontrived, appealing. Safe to say we're excited to see this come out next year.
metaKeywords: Subaru at Los Angeles Auto Show
concepts at Los Angeles Auto Show
metaDescription: Original, uncontrived, appealing. Safe to say we're excited to see this come out next year.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-door, five-passenger sedan
Release date: Late 2016 as 2017 model
Estimated price: $22,000
Competes against: Honda Civic, Ford Focus, Chevrolet Cruze
What’s most interesting: Unprecedented aggressiveness of Subaru design
Subaru will no longer play nice. So we conclude from the new Impreza, billed as a concept car but sure to closely foreshadow the 2017 model.
One problem with the Impreza was lack of availability. That will change soon, as factory space becomes available. Then, everywhere, we will see this handsome sedan.

This compact sedan had the temerity to roll onto the stage, give several hundred people a dirty look, and then just sit there in a cloak of blazing carmine, all self-satisfied about its prospects. And why shouldn’t it be? One problem with the Impreza was lack of availability. That will change soon, as new factory space in Indiana becomes available. Then, everywhere, we will see this handsome little sedan. It is simple and unfussy. Yasuyuki Yoshinaga, president and CEO of Subaru’s parent company, Fuji Heavy Industries, said it’s a “design carved out of hard rigid materials.” And it’s “fused with dynamism.”

The so-called hawkeye headlamps, the highlight of a perfectly composed face, indicate fury. Maybe the car has been following the news. In silhouette, the Impreza looks more like a coupe. Oh, wait, it has rear doors! Character builds through the line that arcs over the front wheel and dips into the door, becoming the bottom lip of a sensuous concavity. It comes off as original, uncontrived, and appealing. Even the large wheels have a sculptural quality with satin, black, and red in a unique combination.

We admire the effort. Combining what we saw with the Impreza’s known hallmarks—efficient four-cylinder engine, turbocharging technology, and all-wheel drive at a modest price—we proclaim our excitement about this concept and eagerly await its production.

title: 2017 Alfa Romeo Giulia
subTitle: Passione, from the active front splitter to the quartet of exhaust pipes.
promoTeaserSmall: Passione, from the active front splitter to the quartet of exhaust pipes.
promoTeaser: Passione, from the active front splitter to the quartet of exhaust pipes.
metaKeywords: Alfa Romeo at Los Angeles Auto Show
Alfa Romeo at L.A. Auto Show
metaDescription: Passione, from the active front splitter to the quartet of exhaust pipes.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear-wheel-drive sedan
Release date: Summer 2016
Estimated price range: $40,000 to $75,000
Competes against: BMW M3, Cadillac CTS-V, Mercedes-Benz C63S
What's most interesting: The Giulia Quadrifoglio holds the Nürburgring lap record for a production sedan

Conventional wisdom says there’s no room for sentiment in business, but that wisdom doesn’t seem to apply to passion. Consider Alfa Romeo. Despite years of dismal sales, Alfa persists where other more rational brands have sputtered to a halt. The essential spark is passion, the critical trait that distinguishes the new Giulia sedan from a platoon of four-door competitors with distinguished pedigrees.
Unveiled in Italy last summer, the Giulia is making its North American debut at the L.A. Auto Show, with cars due in Alfa’s product-starved U.S. showrooms next summer as 2017 models.
Passion is the critical trait that distinguishes the new Giulia sedan from a platoon of four-door competitors with distinguished pedigrees.

The Giulia nameplate dates to the early 1950s, and the star of its revival is this gorgeous sedan, sporting a 505-horsepower twin turbo 2.9-liter V6 engine with Ferrari roots, race-worthy aerodynamic features, world-class performance credentials, active suspension damping, and styling that says passione from the active front splitter to the quartet of exhaust pipes. Bella! With a top speed of 191 mph, it’s the most powerful Alfa production car ever.

The top-of-the-line Quadrifoglio super sedan will be the first to arrive, with a starting price of at least $75,000. If that’s a bit rich, take heart. The Quadrifoglio edition will be followed by a more attainable model propelled by a 276-horsepower turbo four and priced somewhere not far north of $40,000.

title: Scion C-HR Concept
subTitle: Toyota's youth brand embraces the odd in a concept that will see production next year.
promoTeaserSmall: Toyota's youth brand embraces the odd in a concept that will see production next year.
promoTeaser: Toyota's youth brand embraces the odd in a concept that will see production next year.
metaKeywords: Scion at Los Angeles Auto Show
metaDescription: Toyota's youth brand embraces the odd in a concept that will see production next year.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, four-door subcompact crossover/hatchback
Release date: 2016
Estimated price range: Unknown
Competes against: Hyundai Veloster, Kia Soul, Nissan Juke
What's most interesting: Tall ride height
One thing that we know about Toyota's youth-oriented brand, Scion: They aren't afraid to make cars that look a little...unusual.

Case in point is this C-HR Concept (the name stands for "compact" and "high riding"). This concept for a compact hatchback actually started out as a Toyota design study at the 2014 Paris Auto Show, but it's going to come out as a production-model Scion next year. And there's no doubt it fits much better into the wacky Scion stable than the rather more sedate Toyota lineup.

Let's just skip over the awkward claim of Scion officials, at the L.A. show, that the C-HR is for "yuccies," short for young urban creative types. That conjures up unpleasant pictures of bearded, fedora-wearing hipsters. Get beyond the hype, and this is actually a nice blend of crossover and hatchback body shapes without a single boring line to it.

Toyota/Scion said they prioritized agility and stability to make the C-HR a good city runabout. The C-HR features Toyota's New Global Architecture, which incorporates a lower center of gravity, more ride comfort, and a more rigid body. Chief engineer Hiro Koba said he intended the C-HR to be "just as much fun driving in the city during the week" as on the racetrack, where he said he likes to spend his weekends.

Design wise, the C-HR's "cut gem" theme shows in the overall shape as well as the cut-outs in the twenty-one-inch wheels, the side view mirrors, and head- and taillights. No specific on-sale date was given, but expect the production version of the C-HR sometime next year.

title: 2017 Kia Sportage
subTitle: Innovative, and still a great value.
promoTeaserSmall: Innovative, and still a great value.
promoTeaser: Innovative, and still a great value.
metaKeywords: Kia at Los Angeles Auto Show
metaDescription: Innovative, and still a great value.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-door, five-passenger, front- and all-wheel-drive compact crossover
Release date: Early spring 2016
Estimated price: $23,000
Competes against: Honda CR-V, Toyota RAV4, Ford Escape, Hyundai Tucson
What’s most interesting: Can’t stop looking at that face!

Kia has once again shown its knack for shrewd product development as it unveiled the 2017 Sportage, a compact crossover that appeals in every way. The fourth-generation Sportage combines just the right levels of performance, feature content, and style.

Innovative design stands out foremost. Because crossover vehicles look pretty much alike in profile view, intensive effort went distinguishing the new Sportage’s front. Notice those four-element LED foglights at each corner? Kia insiders call them “ice cubes.” Along with the signature tiger-nose grille and new projector-style headlamps, the Sportage has an unmistakable face. It also has an assertive stance, with a long wheelbase, wide body, and nineteen-inch rims on the SX Turbo. As Kia Motors America president and CEO Justin Sohn says, the 2017 Sportage “isn’t just another box on wheels.” Inside, where boxes would be loaded, cargo capacity behind the second row increases by 17 percent and about 10 percent with the second row folded.
As a value-oriented brand, Kia loads on the feature content. Owners will appreciate the smart liftgate that detects the key fob.

Kia’s savvy approach also applies to performance. The Sportage LX and EX have a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine that produces 181 horsepower. The SX Turbo’s 2.0-liter four-cylinder produces a zesty 241 horsepower on regular unleaded fuel. A six-speed automatic transmission is included in all models. Fuel economy figures weren’t released.

As a value-oriented brand, Kia loads on the feature content. Owners will appreciate the smart liftgate that detects the key fob. Heated and ventilated leather seats and a heated steering wheel are available. The UVO3 infotainment system offers apps like geofencing, to keep young drivers within prescribed boundaries, and a parking minder, letting you use your smartphone to find the vehicle. In other words, along with extensive active and passive safety measures, nearly every demand is satisfied.

title: 12 Gifts for People Who Love Cars
subTitle: It’s that time again! Our picks of the most fun, frivolous, and fantastic for gift givers.
promoTitle: 12 Gifts for People Who Love Cars
promoTeaserSmall: It’s that time again! Our picks of the most fun, frivolous, and fantastic for gift givers.
promoTeaser: It’s that time again! Our picks of the most fun, frivolous, and fantastic for gift givers.
keywords: 12 Gifts for People Who Love Cars
metaTitle: 12 Gifts for People Who Love Cars - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: It’s that time again! Our picks of the most fun, frivolous, and fantastic for gift givers.

pageElements.text:
1. Tools for car and home to die for
Sonic Tools USA, $1.51 to $1,899.99
Women can do anything if they learn how to use the tools. And what beautiful tools Sonic makes!! Our visiting college freshman spontaneously threw herself on the floor to unbox this shipment Jean ordered. Beautiful to view, each arrayed in its own labeled spot carved from dense foam. Substantial heft, clever designs, ergonomic perfection. On Jean’s wish list (yes, she signed on to the site): A bright red ¼” disc ratchet ($22.99) that fits in your palm for working in tight spots. Stubby screwdrivers, one slotted, one Phillips head ($1.51). The 16-in-1 ratchet screwdriver ($45.99). The amazing flash pen ($43.99). The sweet utility knife ($12.99). The 91-piece filled suitcase toolbox ($1,399.99). Must have more!!! Trolling for sponsors...

2. Original portrait of a car, motorcycle, or boat
Wirth Motor Company, $395
If you know someone whose car is their most loved possession—or if you are that person—an original portrait may be in order. Iowa artist Tim Wirth paints profile views of cars, each placed in a special landscape. The vehicle’s year, model name, even nickname are hand painted on top of the frame. Each portrait measures 17 by 17 inches and comes in a handmade white pine frame, ready to hang. The work takes six to eight weeks, but that just means you can give a gift certificate and let the lucky recipient get some input into the commissioned work.

3. For the person who wants total garage door control
MyQ Garage, $129.99
You know about apps that will lock or start your car, apps that will check that you remembered to turn off the porch light, and now, an app to open and close the garage door. Those of you who never know what to get Mom and Dad, here you go. Or, for any techie or frequent traveler who wants to control the garage door using a smartphone, MyQ Garage is just the thing. It’s an easy-to-mount door sensor that works with a free app, and it uses the house’s Wi-Fi to operate the garage door.

4. Glovebox-size jumper cable replacement
Cobra JumPack, $119.95
A ten-ounce battery pack that will jump-start a dead battery, charge your phone, and also serve as a flashlight? That’s the claim of Cobra’s JumPack lithium-cobalt battery pack, which has peak current of 360 amps and a set of jumper cables to use it with, plus a 2.4-amp USB to charge phones and other devices. It also has an LED flashlight function that strobes in case you’re stuck at the side of the road. Cobra claims it holds up to 90 percent of its charge for up to eight months.

5. A giant bow for that car you’re buying your sweetheart
Dodson Group, up to $76.50
A four-foot-wide red velvet magnetic bow for that new car you’re gifting this year? Here’s where you can get one. They’re sold by Dodson Group, supplier to auto dealers, but individual orders are OK, or they’re on Amazon.com from the same source. The velvet one in red costs $76.50; you need to order from Dodson before Dec. 16 if you want it for Christmas.

6. A personal electric blanket for the car
Car Cozy, $39.99
Your car has a heater, you say? You still haven’t lived (nor have your back-seat passengers) until you’ve had this warm blanket to snuggle up to on a wintry car trip. It plugs into the 12V outlet in the car and has auto shutoff, so you don’t have to worry about your kids or grandma falling asleep with it on. Beyond mere relaxation, think of the perks of having it in a traffic stoppage or other emergency situation. Watch a video to see it in use.

7. A keychain-mounted tool kit
Ringtool, $28.00
This was originally designed for cyclists to keep them from having to cart around a full-size set of tools. Well, who wants to cart around a full-size set of tools, even if they’re driving something much bigger? This will keep you minimally supplied, in style, with a variety of tools from spoke wrenches to screwdrivers to hex heads and even a bottle cap opener on a ring of hardened stainless steel. You can even use it as a drill bit in a pinch. Made in New York, and approved for getting through security by the TSA.

8. An interactive book for young car fans
How Cars Work, $19.99
British historian Nick Arnold is the author of many fine works for the mechanically minded kid, such as How Machines Work and the Horrible Science series. With How Cars Work, he outdoes himself as he demystifies ten essential systems on a car. The book comes with heavy cardboard miniatures of the components so kids can build their own as they read. Gearbox, steering, exhaust valves, suspension, brakes, and more yield their secrets in simple, everyday language. Hey, maybe your teenage driver trainee should be reading this. Maybe you should, too.

9. Parent-and-child gear and books
Little Red Racing Car, $17.99 and up
Some of the best and most beautiful story books about cars come from the fertile mind of Carpe Viam’s (“seize the road”) Dwight Knowlton. In addition to The Little Red Racing Car and The Greatest Race, you can buy his adult-and-child matching T-shirts that say PLAYS WITH CARS (for the kid) and STILL PLAYS WITH CARS (for the grownup), $33.99 for the pair. The website lets you make and download free posters and blueprints, too.

10. Best anthology of car stories ever
Road Trips, Head Trips, and Other Car-Crazed Writing, $14
Our own Jean Jennings gathered some of the best car stories ever written in this 258-page book that features brilliant tales by authors from Jack Kerouac to Hunter S. Thompson to Dave Barry. Every bathroom and home workshop needs one of these. Signed by the editor. Shipping is free.

11. Car enthusiast stocking stuffers with style
Blipshift, $4 and up
You can find T-shirts about horsepower. You can find bumper stickers that celebrate the joys of the manual transmission. But this company also sells good design, which is harder to find. The creative edge stays fresh because Blipshift invites artists to submit designs (for which they earn $1 per shirt sold). Blipshift only offers up one T-shirt design at a time, priced at $15, and when they’re gone, they’re gone.

12. Homemade gift: car comfort/emergency kit
If you think homemade gifts are best, this is one everybody will appreciate. Pack a sturdy lidded crate with emergency and comfort supplies. Visit the people at Survival Supply for ingredients, if you want to be really thorough. Ideas: an extra mobile charger for the phone; a sturdy candle inside a metal can or a glass jar, plus matches to light it with; packaged or canned food that won’t spoil or freeze (peanut butter, bread, crackers, packaged cheese, snack sausages), and aseptically packaged juice boxes; flashlight and batteries; emergency blanket.

images.caption: #1: More gorgeous photos of the highly desirable Sonic Tools line.
#1: Sonic Tools'  16-in-1 ratchet screwdriver ($45.99), ¼” disc ratchet ($22.99), utility knife ($12.99), and flash pen ($43.99).
#2: Six examples of original car art from Tim Wirth.
#3: MyQ Garage: control the garage door from anywhere, via smartphone.
#4: Cobra makes a glovebox-size jumper cable.
#4: A better look at Cobra's small battery charger.
#5: Dodson Group's giant bow for the top of a car.
#6: The Car Cozy electric blanket for the car. Make sure your car still has a 12V outlet!
#7: A tool set you can carry on your key ring, from Reductivist.
#8: A book to encourage elementary-aged car fanatics, published by Running Press.
#9: Adult and child T-shirt pair from Little Red Racing Car.
#9: Page from The Little Red Racing Car.
#10: Our own anthology of the best automotive writing.
#12: Some of the end-of-the-world gear offered by Survival Supply.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
2016 Subaru Forester 2.5i Premium

Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive crossover/wagon
Trim levels: 2.5i, 2.5i Premium, Limited, Touring; 2.0XT Premium and Touring
Base price: $25,645 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $28,540
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 170 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/32 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated (2015 model was Top Safety Pick Plus)
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, panoramic power moonroof, roof rails, 7.0-inch infotainment screen, Bluetooth connectivity
Notable options on this model: All-Weather package (includes heated front seats and side mirrors, windshield wiper de-icer, steering-responsive fog lights, Starlink navigation system, and EyeSight driver assist system ($1,895); continuously variable transmission ($1,000)
You might also be considering (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Ford Escape SE AWD ($27,945)
2016 Honda CR-V SE AWD ($26,595)
2016 Hyundai Tucson Sport AWD ($28,445)
2016 Jeep Cherokee Latitude AWD ($28,190)
2016 Mazda CX-5 Touring AWD ($27,345)
Fun-O-Meter: 6

The compact crossover/sport-utility vehicle category is more crowded than ever, which means you have more choice than ever. All good news! But actually, if you’re looking to ride up high in a five-passenger, all-wheel-drive vehicle, the choices can look alarmingly similar. One exception is the Subaru Forester, which remains refreshingly station-wagon-like despite the general move to a boxier silhouette.

We tested the second of six trim levels, the 2.5i Premium. Even at this economical price point, the Forester was equipped with full-time all-wheel drive, an infotainment screen, navigation, and some of the latest active safety features. Its as-tested price of $28,540 including destination charge is a compelling sales proposition.
Even Consumer Reports describes its interior as austere, and that’s not a publication that prizes bling. You might say “dowdy,” depending on how much you prize bling.

The Forester is the smaller of Subaru’s five-passenger crossovers, built on the platform of the Impreza, while the Outback is based off the Legacy sedan. As such, the Forester is the choice you’d look at if you’re also considering the Honda CR-V, the Toyota RAV4, the Ford Escape, and other compact crossovers. All practical vehicles, but of them all, the Forester is the most timeless-looking inside and out—even Consumer Reports describes its interior as “austere,” and that’s not exactly a publication that prizes bling. You might say “dowdy,” depending on how much you prize bling.

Who is the kind of person who buys a Subaru? For starters, someone interested in being a savvy consumer. Consumer Reports says the most frequently researched vehicle on its website is the Forester. In fact, 40 percent more viewers look it up than the #2 vehicle….which is also a Subaru crossover, the larger Outback.

The interior reflects the general understated appeal of the Forester, with a lot of plastic but a feeling of durability and a rejection of faddishness. There’s an analog clock, for example, and an old-school center console that may restrict your ability to stow a large handbag. But it has a comfortable sliding armrest top that you don’t always see in the competition. On the other hand, I strongly disliked the large, textured metal rotary HVAC dials, which were stiff and hard to turn. Yes, they are sturdy and will probably last until the end of time. But anyone with arthritis will dislike them even more than I did.

In contrast, the sleek glass touchscreen in the center of the dash was as easy to use as anything I’ve tried, as easy as brushing your fingertips across your chosen icon. Really lovely. But only when the sun isn’t glaring off it, making it impossible to read. The smaller screen above it has an anti-glare matte surface. Just saying.

Speaking of visibility, Consumer Reports, again, praises the Forester for the best outward visibility of any vehicle. Out of five sides—including the massive sunroof, when the shade is opened—you get a gloriously uninterrupted view. That, plus the generous 8.7 inches of ground clearance, gives an open-sleigh feeling, especially in the snow we had in southeast Michigan while testing the Forester.
The Forester is still not a laugh riot to drive, but it’s much more entertaining than the humorless Subarus of yore.

The snow didn’t last long on the Interstate, so we had a good chance to drive the Forester at speed. The carryover 2.5-liter flat-four engine still produces a respectable 170 horsepower, respectable because it’s optimally managed by a continuously variable transmission instead of the disinterested four-speed automatic transmission it was saddled with through 2013, when I last drove a Forester. I had modest expectations as I hit the highway and was totally surprised. The Forester is still not a laugh riot to drive, but it’s much more entertaining than the humorless Subarus of yore.

One complaint: As I pressed the accelerator at 70 mph, the Forester pulled slightly right. As I lifted my foot a touch, it pulled left. It was a tiny adjustment in mass that was almost imperceptible. But it was there, and it bothered me.

Subaru is justly praised for its EyeSight active safety package, available as an option on select models of the Forester, Impreza, Legacy, Outback, and Crosstrek. It includes adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, lane sway warning (when you’re wandering too much within your lane), and pre-collision warning and braking. The package deal is very popular with the practical-minded Subaru shopper. Subaru says 24 percent of Foresters and 31 percent of total Subarus are sold equipped with EyeSight.

On the Forester we tested, EyeSight was part of an overall option package ($1,895) that bundled navigation, SiriusXM satellite radio, and an All-Weather group that included heated front seats and side mirrors and a windshield wiper de-icer. The All-Weather part of the equation was extremely handy when a foot of snow fell overnight and the Forester was buried. Turn the key, get the defrosters going, and before you’ve scraped the first side window, those heated side mirrors are radiating the winter right off the side of the vehicle. In its entirety, we’d call that feature bundle a helluva good deal.

If what you want is a five-passenger crossover, Subaru has two excellent choices: this Forester and the more upscale mid-size Outback. But there’s no seven-passenger choice in Subaru’s admittedly quirky lineup. It’s coming, though, in the 2018 model year, and it will be built in the United States at Subaru of Indiana Automotive. This three-row vehicle doesn’t have a name yet, but Subaru announced earlier this month that it will get a title “synonymous with outdoor adventure.” That’s good, because in Japan the three-row crossover is called the Exiga, which sounds a little too Wall Street for Subaru’s more earthy clientele.

These cars are bestsellers year in and year out. They aren’t sexy. Then again, if you want to get somewhere on bad roads without a moment’s worry, maybe the Forester has just the right amount of allure. Context is everything.

subTitle: The thinking person's sports car.

promoTeaser: The thinking person's sports car.

pageElements.text:
Type: Two-plus-two-passenger, rear-wheel-drive sport coupe
Price range: $26,190 – $28,485 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: Premium, Limited, Series.HyperBlue limited edition
Engine: 2.0-liter horizontally opposed four-cylinder, 200 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual; six-speed automatic with manual mode and paddle shifters (optional on Limited)
Fuel economy: 22 mpg city/30 mpg highway (manual); 25/34 mpg (automatic)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA): 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS): Not yet rated (2015 model was a Top Safety Pick)
Notable standard features: Rearview camera, brake assist, leather-covered steering wheel and shift knob; keyless entry and push-button start (Limited); Alcantara upholstery (Limited)
Notable options: Automatic transmission ($1,100)
You might also be considering: Honda Civic Si, Mazda MX-5 Miata, Mini Cooper, Scion FR-S

The BRZ is an unusual Subaru, coming from the company known mainly for its more practical all-wheel-drive vehicles. This is a small, lightweight rear-wheel-drive sportster that was developed jointly with Toyota (which makes the Scion FR-S sibling to the BRZ) and introduced in 2003. It is named for its boxer (horizontally opposed) four-cylinder engine and its rear-wheel drive. Known for its low center of gravity and no-frills fun to drive, the BRZ is not known for its luggage capacity (a whopping 6.9 cubic feet of cargo volume) or its back-seat comfort. That's not what you'd buy this car for. Option packages aren't, either. Get the Limited model if you want a trunk-mounted spoiler, heated front seats, Alcantara upholstery, and keyless entry with push-button start, among other features. The Premium doesn't have any of these, even as options. All BRZs get Starlink infotainment with a 6.2-inch screen, Sirius XM satellite radio, and smartphone integration. One option is the six-speed automatic transmission with manual mode and paddle shifters, which adds $1,000 to the price and improves fuel economy. For added visual flair, you could go for the limited-edition Series.HyperBlue BRZ. It adds black alloy wheels, black exterior mirrors and badges, and blue stitching on the upholstery.

New for 2016:

Series.HyperBlue special model, limited to 500 copies, priced at $28,485, including destination charge
Rearview camera standard on all models

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive sedan or hatchback
Price range: $15,220 – $22,370 (sedan); $15,820 – $22,370 (hatchback)
Trim levels: LS, LT, LTZ, LTZ Dusk, RS
Engines: 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 138 horsepower; turbocharged 1.4-liter four-cylinder, 138 horsepower
Transmissions: Five- or six-speed manual, six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 1.8-liter, manual: 26 mpg city/35 mpg highway; 1.8-liter, automatic: 25/35 mpg; 1.4-liter, manual: 29/40 mpg; 1.4-liter, automatic: 27/37 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: 4G LTE with Wi-Fi for up to seven devices (3 months, 3GB of data)
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera (LTZ and RS; optional on LT); heated front seats (LTZ and RS); cruise control (LTZ, RS, LT); leather-wrapped steering wheel (LTZ)
Notable options on this model: Forward collision alert and lane departure warning; BringGo navigation app; power sunroof (LT, LTZ, RS)
You might also be considering: Ford Fiesta, Honda Fit, Mazda 2, Scion iA

What the Chevrolet Sonic lacks in size, it makes up for in quirky fun, from its candy colors to its cheerful and even trendy styling. What's better, especially at its price point, the Sonic offers several modern safety features, including forward collision alert, lane departure warnings, automatic crash response, and a rearview camera.

The Sonic can seat five (although four is more reasonable) plus almost 15 cubic feet and 19 cubic feet of cargo space in the sedan and hatch, respectively. Fold down the rear seats—both lie flat or do a 60/40 split—and the hatch can swallow more than 47 cubic feet of gear. And there is plenty of tech in this little car, too: Bluetooth, music streaming through Pandora or Stitcher SmartRadio, Satellite radio, and more. It’s pretty cute, too with a playfully aggressive exterior that can be painted in mild to wild colors. The interior can be outfitted in equally interesting colors and has smart details like contrast seat stitching and racy gauges. This is a small car you can enjoy both driving and looking at.

New in 2016

Three new metallic shades: Nightfall Gray, Kinetic Blue, and Mosaic Black
Chevrolet MyLink standard on LT
Automatic transmission standard on LTZ

title: 2016 Chevrolet Suburban

image.altText: 2016 Chevrolet Suburban Full Size Suv Design 1035X440 004

pageElements.text: You know, when you look at GM's photo of a Suburban with an entire kayak comfortably fitted inside, that you are looking at a seriously capable hauler. But the 2016 Chevrolet Suburban is more than just the sum of its practical parts; it's a major lifestyle choice, one that gives you some of the latest and best connectivity and safety—and luxury—along with its capaciousness. Available in rear- or all-wheel-drive versions, the Suburban doesn't come cheap, and it doesn't sip gasoline, but if you need to carry up to nine people, tow a boat, or put a kayak inside the vehicle, there's virtually no substitute.

In addition to the wireless hot spot provided by OnStar 4G LTE wireless technology, you can get a foot-operated power liftgate, a set of six-spoke twenty-two-inch wheels, and power-release second- and third-row seats.

New in 2016

Forward collision alert, lane keeping assist, and safety alert seat all available in Enhanced Driver Alert package, a bargain at $695 on LS (standard on LT and LTZ)
LTZ gets digital head-up display as a no-cost option
Apple CarPlay with enhanced Chevrolet MyLink smartphone integration
Two new colors: Siren Red and Iridescent Pearl Tricoat

Price range: $23,495–$27,855
Trim levels: LS, LT, LTZ

Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 2.4-liter, FWD: 22 mpg city/32 mpg highway; 2.4-liter, AWD: 20/29 mpg; 3.6-liter, FWD: 17/24 mpg; 3.6-liter, AWD: 16/23 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet tested; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Hill start assist
Notable standard features on this model: OnStar Directions and Connections (for six months) with turn-by-turn directions
Notable options on this model: Heated, eight-way adjustable front seats
You might also be considering: Ford Escape, Honda CR-V, Mazda CX-5, Toyota RAV4

The restyled 2016 Chevrolet Equinox is undeniably more attractive, but the compact crossover segment is very competitive and very crowded. All the better for people searching for a five-passenger front- or all-wheel-drive carryall like this one; you can keep looking until you find exactly the one for you. One of the charms of the Chevy is that it has OnStar with 4G LTE and is a rolling wireless hot spot, which should appeal to families and commuters. And the Equinox undoubtedly appeals to many; General Motors sells about a quarter-million of these every year.

Chevrolet's excellent MyLink infotainment system includes a standard rearview camera on all models; navigation is an option. People in cold climates will appreciate the adaptive remote start (standard on LTZ, optional on LT), which will turn on the front and rear defrosters, heated seats, and outside heated mirrors in outside temperatures at 45 degrees or lower.

New in 2016

Restyled front, including new chrome-accented dual-port grille and projector beam headlamps
LT and LTZ models get LED daytime running lights, side blind zone alert, rear cross-traffic alert
Rearview camera now standard on all models

title: 2016 Chevrolet Malibu
subTitle: An all-new version of the mid-size stalwart, plus a hybrid promising 48 mpg in town.
promoTeaserSmall: An all-new version of the mid-size stalwart, plus a hybrid promising 48 mpg in town.
