pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
Price range: $22,500 – $32,290 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: L, LS, LT, Hybrid, Premier
Engine: Turbocharged 1.5-liter four-cylinder, 160 horsepower; turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 250 horsepower; 1.8-liter four-cylinder with two-motor drive (Hybrid), total 182 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic (1.5-liter engine); eight-speed automatic (2.0-liter engine)
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/37 mpg highway (2.0-liter turbo); 48/45 mpg (Hybrid)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA): Not yet tested; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS): Not yet tested (2015 model was a Top Safety Pick)
Notable standard features: Cruise control, push-button start, stop/start fuel-saving technology
Notable options: OnStar with 4G LTE wireless hot spot; front pedestrian alert with automatic braking
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Hyundai Sonata, Toyota Camry

The Chevrolet Malibu is a car that feels to have been around absolutely forever. That's pretty much true, actually, The name dates back to the 1960s, with the current front-wheel-drive Malibu dating to 1997. Chevrolet unveiled a completely redone version of its long-lived Malibu at the New York Auto Show this spring, and it goes on sale by year's end, with a hybrid version coming in the spring. The all-new Malibu is bigger, sleeker-looking, and loaded with technological choices. The big news is more space inside, with 1.3 more inches of rear legroom and a four-inch improvement in the car's wheelbase. The other big news is a Malibu Hybrid, built on a version of the Chevrolet Volt's powertrain and its regenerative braking system, with a battery pack that can run the Malibu up to 55 mph on electricity alone. OnStar with a 4G LTE Wi-Fi hot spot is available on all models, and wireless smartphone charging is an option on upper-level models. The strong slate of active safety features includes automatic parking assist, rear cross-traffic alert, and forward collision alert. A new Teen Driver feature lets parents keep track of their children's driving habits and set maximum speeds using the car's infotainment system.

New in 2016

The Malibu is all new for the 2016 model year.

More about the Malibu

New York Auto Show: 2016 Chevrolet Malibu April 1, 2015

title: Roadside Assistance: Where to Get It
subTitle: These are the popular options to ensure a tow when you need one. Do you know what to get? Our guide.
promoTitle: Roadside Assistance: Where to Get It
promoTeaserSmall: These are the popular options to ensure a tow when you need one. Do you know what to get? Our guide.
promoTeaser: These are the popular options to ensure a tow when you need one. Do you know what to get? Our guide.
keywords: Roadside Assistance: Where to Get It
metaTitle: Roadside Assistance: Where to Get It - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: These are the popular options to ensure a tow when you need one. Do you know what to get? Our guide.

pageElements.text:
Very high up on the list of your automotive necessities is coverage for emergency roadside service. But what kind? The choices in auto club memberships, insurance policy add-ons, and miscellaneous service providers is truly mind-boggling. Certainly, you want to be able to call somebody if you get a flat tire at 2 a.m. on a deserted road, or if you need a serious jump start in February. (Or if your teenager or college student does.) But you don't want to needlessly pay too much for coverage that is duplicated somewhere else.

Emergency road service these days is offered by auto manufacturers, credit cards, even your phone company. All of them have exclusions, limitations, and exceptions you should check out thoroughly to make sure you're covered in a true emergency. The fact is, it's still a good idea to have the most inclusive road service you can afford, considering that none of them will break the bank.
Here's our handy guide to providers, divided by type, with pros and cons of each. Hope it helps!

Option 1: Dedicated Road Service Membership

AAA's is the best known, but there are others that give you a membership card just for emergencies that crop up.
Pro: A reasonable yearly charge gives you peace of mind.
Con: Something you may not know is that, with some exceptions, these plans are for the member (that's you or whatever family members are on the plan) in whatever vehicle you're in. They're not for the vehicle itself. That means you can call for a tow truck if you get stranded in a friend's car or a rental, even as a passenger, but your friend can't call for one using your card if he or she is stranded in your car and you aren't there.
And, of course, if you don't need any emergency road service all year, you've paid the fee for nothing, while if you need more than the maximum number of services, you won't be covered.

AAA
Membership types: Classic ($52/year), Plus ($78), Premium ($103)
Spouses and children: $28/year for each added family member
Other vehicles included: RV and motorcycle (with Plus or Premium membership); bicycle (in some regions)
Towing: Classic: 5 miles; Plus: 100 miles; Premium: one 200-mile tow, up to three 100-mile tows
Tow call limit: Four per year
Other services: Battery jump, emergency start, flat tire, fuel delivery, lockout, extrication/winching

AARP/Allstate
Membership types: Standard ($59/year), Premier ($84/year); must be AARP member
Spouses and children: Standard: $69/year for couple, $89/year for family; Premier: $94/year for couple, $114/year for family
Other vehicles included: Motorcycles included; RVs covered for an extra $25/year
Towing: Classic: 5 miles; Premium: 100 miles
Tow call limit: Four per year; five per year for couple; seven per year for family
Other services: Battery jump, emergency start, flat tire, fuel delivery, lockout, extrication/winching, up to $25 for lost key replacement

Allstate Motor Club
Membership types: Roadside Advantage $52/year; Deluxe $108/year; Platinum Elite $186/year
Spouses and children: Spouses and teens aged sixteen to eighteen, free
Other vehicles included: Motorcycles and RVs; $99.95/year for RV plan with unlimited towing
Towing: Pays up to $100, $150, or $250 in towing, tire change, lockout, or fuel delivery costs; guarantees response within 30 minutes of promised time
Tow call limit: Four per year
Other services: Battery jump, emergency start, flat tire, fuel delivery, lockout

Best Roadside Service
Membership types: Coverage of a single vehicle (with any driver) $65/year; Coverage of a single driver (in any vehicle) $79.95/year
Spouses and children: Total charge of $94.95/year for two members to $139.95/year for four members
Other vehicles included: Vehicles up to 12,500 pounds, including motorcycles
Towing: Up to 75 miles
Tow call limit: Six per year
Other services: Battery jump, emergency start, flat tire, fuel delivery, lockout, extrication/winching

Better World Club
This is a Portland, Oregon–based club that calls itself "green" in that there's a discount for hybrid owners, a surcharge for gas-guzzler owners, and one percent of fees is donated to environmental cleanup and advocacy efforts. There's also a roadside assistance plan for bicycles.
Membership types: Classic ($57.95/year), Premium ($92.95/year); one-time $12 signup fee (waived if member is leaving AAA to join)
Spouses and children: Classic: $35 for each additional member; Premium: $49 for each additional member
Other vehicles included: Bicycle roadside assistance is an extra $17/year; motorcycle coverage adds $17/year to Premium membership; RV coverage adds $43/year to Premium membership
Towing: Up to 5 miles (Classic); up to 100 miles (Premium); guarantees response within 30 minutes of promised time
Tow call limit: Four per year
Other services: Battery jump, flat tire, fuel delivery, lockout

BP Motor Club
Membership types:: Silver ($6.50/month); Premier ($8.99/month), Premier Plus ($9.99/month)
Spouses and children: Spouse free; add up to two children over age 16, $35/year
Other vehicles included: RVs included for jump start or fuel delivery only
Towing:5, 50, or 100 miles, depending on membership level
Tow call limit: Four per year; five per year if plan has an associate member
Other services: Battery jump, flat tire, fuel delivery, lockout, winching (up to 30 minutes)

Costco Road Companion by USAC
Membership types:: $69.99/year; must be a Costco member to join
Spouses and children: $114.99/year for family
Other vehicles included: RVs, motorcycles, camping trailers not included
Towing: Up to 100 miles to "destination of choice"
Tow call limit: Four per year
Other services: Battery jump, flat tire, fuel delivery, lcokout

Option 2: Insurance Policy Add-Ons

Look at your car insurer's offerings; many will let you add on a roadside assistance plan, rolling in the charge to your premium. Fees can be under $20 per year. Check with your insurance company.
Pro: One-stop shopping, and one company to deal with for all your car needs.
Con: Limitations on tow distances may be strict. Also, it's possible that a large number of service calls can have an impact on your future premium. Ask your insurance carrier before you commit to adding this coverage.

Information about specific insurers: Allstate, Geico, Liberty Mutual, Progressive, State Farm

Option 3: Apps and Subscriptions

We're all familiar with an on-demand app like Uber. This is the same idea; use it and pay via credit card at the moment a problem happens, without joining any clubs or paying any fees ahead of time.
Pro: If you have a reasonably new vehicle in good condition, roadside assistance will be less of a concern for you. In that case, you might choose to download a pay-as-you-go roadside assistance app if the unexpected does happen, leaving you with no up-front charges for something you might never need.
Con: Even with one service per year, the cost can be a lot steeper than a simple auto club membership would have been.

Allstate Good Hands Rescue
Membership types: Pay as you go via credit card using app; no membership required
Towing fees: $89 for up to five miles, $4.25 per mile after five miles
Other services: Tire change, fuel delivery, jump start $59; fuel delivery $59 (up to three gallons, plus cost of fuel)

Urgent.ly
Membership types: Pay as you go; no membership required
Towing fees: $99 up to 10 miles, $125 for 11-20 miles, $155 for 21-30 miles, $4 per mile for each additional mile after 30
Other services: Tire change, fuel delivery, locksmith services, jump start, $75 per incident

images.caption: Roadside assistance plans will get you towed out of danger.
Roadside assistance plans vary in how far you can be towed. Read the fine print.
Towing is especially appreciated in bad weather. credit: istock/Thinkstock
A classic shot of early road service from AAA.
Only Better World and (on a pilot basis) AAA offer bicycle road service. Credit: stockbyte/Thinkstock

title: 5 Reasons to Spring for Winter Tires
subTitle: If it gets below freezing where you live, consider putting winter tires on your vehicle. Here’s why.
promoTitle: 5 Reasons to Spring for Winter Tires
promoTeaserSmall: If it gets below freezing where you live, consider putting winter tires on your vehicle. Here’s why.
promoTeaser: If it gets below freezing where you live, consider putting winter tires on your vehicle. Here’s why.
keywords: 5 Reasons to Spring for Winter Tires
metaTitle: 5 Reasons to Spring for Winter Tires - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: If it gets below freezing where you live, consider putting winter tires on your vehicle. Here’s why.

pageElements.text: If you’re like most people, your vehicle has a set of all-season radial tires. If you ever had snow tires, it was years ago, before tire technology was as advanced as it is today. Right? It’s time to rethink that, now that winter tires are better than they’ve ever been. All-season tires are great, but, well, to quote the tire experts at mega tire supplier Tire Rack, they can be jack of all trades, master of none.

If you want to be at your safest and most confident all year round, your best bet is to alternate all-season tires in the warm months with winter-rated tires from late fall to spring. Even if you aren’t in the Snow Belt, but go skiing on weekends or occasionally encounter snowy conditions, winter tires are a good investment.
Here are five reasons why.

1. Winter tires remain more pliable in the snow. All-season tires are stiffer than winter tires. So, as the weather drops below 40 degrees and the roads get more frozen, an all-season tire becomes like hard plastic on the road. Winter tires are made of a softer compound, so they remain pliable at lower temperatures.

2. Winter tires are built right to push the snow out. On winter roads, your tires have to cope with a film of water over the road when it’s slushy, wet, or icy. Today’s modern studless ice and snow tires have aggressive tread patterns, with more sipes, or grooves, to take the fluid in and wick it back out. Winter tires have many sipes (deep cuts in the tread) to grab the snow and keep you in control. It’s like black magic.

3. No technology can improve your grip the way the right tires can. A front-wheel-drive or all-wheel-drive vehicle is more stable in the snow and ice. Anti-lock brakes and traction control will improve the car’s handling. But the tires are where grip comes from. Snow tires have more “bite” to grip the way you need them to on snow and ice.

4. On winter tires, you can stop, accelerate, and turn better. Stopping, going, and turn distance are all improved in slushy, wet, and icy conditions with winter tires. In a test on ice comparing all-season versus winter cars, Tire Rack found that the winter-tire-clad car stopped 18.5 feet quicker, could corner 3 mph faster without hitting cones on the course, and could accelerate from a stop 25 percent faster than the car with all-season tires. That’s reason enough to consider winter tires this time of year.

5. It’s not even more expensive in the long run. Tire Rack says alternating summer and winter tires “means having the best tires to overcome driving challenges all year round, and helps extend the combined years of service drivers get from both sets.” Rather than use a set of all-season tires all year round and replace them sooner, you can alternate winter with all-season tires and get longer life out of both sets. That switchover in spring and fall is totally worth it when you realize you’re driving with more confidence all year round.

title: 2016 Hyundai Veloster
subTitle: Another little spitfire in the tiny sub-$30,000 performance car class.
promoTeaserSmall: Another little spitfire in the tiny sub-$30,000 performance car class.
promoTeaser: Another little spitfire in the tiny sub-$30,000 performance car class.
metaDescription: Another little spitfire in the tiny sub-$30,000 performance car class.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
2016 Hyundai Veloster Rally Edition

Type: Four-passenger, three-door front-wheel-drive sport coupe
Trim levels: Veloster, Turbo, Turbo R-Spec, Rally Edition
Base price: $24,775 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $24,920
Engine: Turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 201 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual with B&M Racing sport shifter
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/33 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars http://www.safercar.gov/Vehicle+Shoppers/5-Star+Safety+Ratings/2011-Newer+Vehicles/Vehicle-Detail?vehicleId=10016; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Ford Fiesta ST ($21,845)
2016 Kia Soul ! ($23,015)
2016 Mazda 3 S Grand Touring ($26,265)

Fun-O-Meter: 8

The Hyundai Veloster looks different from other cars, and I mean that as a compliment. That is especially true of the limited-edition 2016 Veloster Turbo Rally Edition I tested, of which only 1,200 will be sold. In this and other guises, the Veloster is a member of a very small club of sub-$30,000 performance cocoons. It’s a little car with a cockpit and an aggressive seat designed to place you firmly in front of the steering wheel. The driver gets a door, and the front passenger gets two doors, but there is no room for anyone or anything in the back seat except your racing helmet.
I exaggerate, of course. But not by much.

Just one look at this crouching little coupe, and you know it’s going to be sporty, even as you are immediately aware it will be compromised in terms of space. The looks set up an expectation of a certain kind of driving experience. That was an experience that, for me, it did not deliver until it got a turbocharged engine for the 2013 model year, just a year after the car’s debut.
Once I started doing hot laps, I drew the attention of the then head of Hyundai, a man who had no confidence dilemma (nor do I), who was very competitive (as am I).

At that time, I attended the media introduction of the Veloster Turbo. It was held at Michigan International Speedway. The test did not include the track; instead, Hyundai set up a cone course in the parking lot so we could put the Velosters through their paces, including a few of the new Turbos. That’s when it all came together for me and the Veloster finally got my attention. Once I started doing hot laps, I drew the attention of the then head of Hyundai, a man who had no confidence dilemma (nor do I), who was very competitive (as am I). He inserted himself into the group of journalists waiting their turns trackside, no doubt planning on showing me his stuff. It was very satisfying to beat him soundly, and turning in the fastest time of the day in the offing. I can pretty much guarantee that it had nothing to do with his departure from Hyundai later that year.

It was also the first use of matte paint on a Hyundai. No only did they show the car at that press conference, there was also a supplier of special cleaning products you had to use to keep the matte finish from going all glossy. Car washes are a no-no. The Rally Edition Veloster has a special Marathon Blue matte paint finish that is, there’s no other word for it, spectacular. Hyundai told me that it’s still recommended to wash the car by hand, using a specialized matte-finish care kit, to maintain the matteness of the matte-finish paint. That sounds like a hassle, but one of the very best things about this car is the way the finish looks, so for the aesthetically inclined among us, it’s probably worth it.

The side profile of the 2016 Hyundai Veloster shows a steep rearward rake, a racy touch that looks great but takes out headroom and leaves behind pretty large blind spots to either side of you. There is no available blind spot detection on the Veloster, even as an option. But each side mirror has an inset mirror to help increase the view of what might be lurking back there. And when you are backing up, there is an extra-wide rearview camera image to help.

The standard engine in the Veloster is a 1.6-liter four-cylinder that makes 132 horsepower. Happily, we tested the Veloster Turbo, which makes a more enjoyable 201 horsepower, a nice amount of both power and torque (195 pound-feet) from a relatively small engine. It’s a little fireball, and it’s extra nice when merging into the freeway madness or passing. That’s the beauty of a turbo. There’s a smooth but noticeable power boost when the turbocharger winds up and kicks in. (If you want a visual image of what’s going on in there, imagine aiming a bellows at the fire in your fireplace and squeezing it a few times. No extra fuel, just an air blast making the fire burn hotter.)
The Rally Edition Veloster has a special Marathon Blue matte paint finish that is, there’s no other word for it, spectacular.

The engine is paired with a six-speed manual transmission and a B&M Racing sport shifter, which is absolutely critical to the fun.  It is quick, flawless, a precision instrument, a bit of perfection. In fact, it’s the perfect shifter for training a new driver: confidence-inspiring, no drama. But don’t let them have all the fun. Experienced drivers will love it, too.

Hyundai squeezed out extra performance from the four-cylinder engine and optimized the fuel economy by cutting weight and adding the turbo. Handling is more precise and the suspension is tastefully aggressive, with springs, dampers, and front stabilizer bar retuned for higher performance. The wheels are special lightweight Rays alloy wheels, spidery and black.
Additional weight is saved by getting rid of the Veloster’s panoramic glass roof and replacing it with metal.

The rearview camera image is displayed on a seven-inch touchscreen, standard on all models,  that is also the nexus of your entertainment system. Just below it are temperature controls that manage all HVAC functions except for the heated seats. Which we don’t happen to have. More’s the pity!

If there is any doubt of the buyer profile for the Veloster, there’s an integrated RCA cable and available 115-volt power outlet so you can plug in a gaming console and play Mario Kart on the seven-inch touchscreen—while the Veloster is parked, of course. Other than that, auxiliary plugs are a bit sparse. There are two 12V plug-ins (cigarette lighter sockets), one AUX jack, and one USB port. But then, this is a small car.

The cockpit has bolstered seats with leather faces and blue accents embroidered with the word TURBO on each. The car could lose the gaudy stitching, as far as I am concerned. The Mario Karters might dissent.

One small issue with the controls. When you adjust the rearview mirror’s old-school flip lever, you tend to brace your thumb against the bottom of the mirror. Right on top of the BlueLink button. Which calls BlueLink (Hyundai’s OnStar equivalent). A little disconcerting the first time when BlueLink asks you what you need. The second time it happens, you’ll be ready with a “CANCEL” command.

All turbo models have a feature that Hyundai calls Active Sound Design, which amps up the sound of the powertrain inside the cabin. Hyundai says it provides “richer in-cabin powertrain sound character.” Read: fake engine noise excitement. If you buy this car, you’ll want to know about it so you don’t get caught out on the fakeness of it by one of your friends. But don’t feel bad: Porsches (and others) have it, too.

The center console box has two levels. The first latch opens to a narrow tray that will hold a wallet, a set of keys, your phone, or some coins. Below it is a deep bin that is otherwise compromised in space. Think “saltine box.” Bring a small purse.

The rear wiper blade was fairly wimpy facing the snow melt on the glass this morning. The hatch is two panels of glass with a cross bar between them, letting in a lot of light. The rear cargo hold is also somewhat small in overall area, but the hatch allows you to jam a lot of soft-sided luggage, or an impressive number of grocery bags, if you specify plastic, not paper.
  
The $24,920 as-tested price included extra charges for only two small accessories: a cargo net ($50) and a set of mud guards ($95). That’s not very much money for a lot more fun and more interesting looks than you’ll get in most sub-$25,000 cars.

title: Gifts: JBL Trip
subTitle: THE holiday gift for the person who cares about sound quality and hands-free convenience in the car.
promoTeaserSmall: THE holiday gift for the person who cares about sound quality and hands-free convenience in the car.
promoTeaser: THE holiday gift for the person who cares about sound quality and hands-free convenience in the car.
metaDescription: THE holiday gift for the person who cares about sound quality and hands-free convenience in the car.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: If Santa is not flush enough to deliver a brand-new car to you this year, you can hope for the JBL Trip. This Bluetooth speaker will transform your non-Bluetooth-enabled vehicle into a rolling conference room. Hands-free technology for $99, even if you're driving a clunker.

Why is the speaker any different than every other Bluetooth speaker in the universe? First and foremost, the Trip is designed specifically for use in cars. A magnetic mounting system clips to the visor to easily attach the speaker. The speaker has buttons that face the driver to allow you to accept and end calls, adjust volume, and best of all access Siri and Google speech. I am swooning over the idea of bossing around Siri while driving down the highway in a 1957 Chevrolet Bel Air convertible. And this little pill-shaped speaker has noise-canceling technology to combat the wind when I choose to put the top down.

The speaker can be used to broadcast apps on your phone. I personally used Google Maps and Pandora simultaneously. If your car already has a great sound system, you can use the Trip for navigation while still rockin’ out to your factory-installed radio. It is charged via a micro-USB cord and delivers twenty hours of talk time and 800 hours of standby. It is annoying to have to charge a speaker, but if you talk for twenty hours straight, you will need to rest your voice for a while anyway.

The fun doesn’t have to stop when the navigation announces that you have reached your destination. Simply remove the speaker and walk away. I used mine to listen to books via the Audible app as I moved around my house cleaning.

My only disappointment, and it's a small one, is that there's no carrying bag to go along with the Trip. This product was just introduced this fall at a European technology fair, so an aftermarket carrying bag won't be long in making itself available.
So, if the only reason you want a new car is for Bluetooth technology, I just saved you tens of thousands of dollars. You’re welcome.
You can order the Trip online from Crutchfield ($99.95) or straight from JBL.

title: 2016 Chevrolet Malibu 1LT
subTitle: Welcome back to the front ranks of mid-size sedans, Chevrolet.
promoTeaserSmall: Welcome back to the front ranks of mid-size sedans, Chevrolet.
promoTeaser: Welcome back to the front ranks of mid-size sedans, Chevrolet.
metaDescription: Welcome back to the front ranks of mid-size sedans, Chevrolet.

pageElements.text:
2016 Chevrolet Malibu 1LT

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
Trim levels: L, LS, 1LT, 2LT, Premier
Base price: $22,500 (base model), $25,895 (1LT)
Price as tested: $29,685
Engine: Turbocharged 1.5-liter four-cylinder, 160 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/37 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Stop/start technology
Options I can’t live without: Teen Driver
Notable standard features on this model: Power driver’s seat, seven-inch touchscreen, radio, rearview camera, Apple Car Play/Android Auto, 4G LTE connectivity with wireless hot spot, cruise control, push-button start, LED daytime running lights
Notable options on this model: Sun and Wheels package (power sunroof, 18-inch alloy wheels, home remote), $1,500; Convenience/Technology package (remote start, auto-dimming mirror, 120-volt power outlet, MyLink radio, wireless charging with two rear seat USB ports, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob), $895; Leather package (heated front seats, power passenger seat, Bose premium audio), $1,395; Driver Confidence package (front automatic braking and front pedestrian braking, front and rear park assist, side blind zone alert, lane change alert, lane keep assist, following distance indicator, forward collision alert, rear cross-traffic alert), $1,195
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Hyundai Sonata, Kia Optima, Mazda 6, Nissan Altima, Toyota Camry, Volkswagen Passat

Like many models with a lengthy history—the name first appeared in 1964, as a Chevelle variant—the Malibu has gone through a dizzying number of identities in its eight generations. Now, with the all-new sixth-generation 2016 Chevrolet Malibu, it is adopting a very attractive new personality.

Over the years the Malibu has run from Type A—a 396-cubic-inch big-block V-8 model that rumbled onto the scene in the mid-1960s, the golden age of American muscle—to the forgettable models of the recent past, popular primarily with rental fleets.

That last is changing as we speak, thanks to this all-new Malibu, which is beginning to appear in the U.S. showrooms as we speak. Another bit of proof that it's a notable new model: It has just been named one of three finalists for the North American Car of the Year award, the winner of which will be named in January during the Detroit auto show. (The other two are the Mazda MX-5 Miata and the Honda Civic.)
Bigger, roomier, handsome, quiet, and eminently competent, the personality and presence of the 2016 Malibu gives Chevrolet a stronger entry in the mid-size-sedan segment.

Bigger, roomier, handsome, quiet, and eminently competent, the personality and presence of the 2016 Malibu is certain to give Chevrolet a stronger entry in the mid-size-sedan category. It addresses the key areas where the 2015 Malibu was particularly weak—eye appeal, rear-seat comfort—and adds interior sophistication, enhanced infotainment, more safety features, and a serious hybrid model.

Most contemporary make-overs include dimensional increases that barely merit mention. But two Malibu chassis statistics stand out. The wheelbase has been stretched four inches, an unusually big increase for a mid-size sedan. Overall, the Malibu is 2.3 inches longer, and there’s less of it extending beyond the front axle, a benefit to the car’s proportions.

Just as important, the longer wheelbase adds up to a 1.3-inch increase in rear-seat legroom. Don’t get too excited—you won’t confuse this with a limo. But with the exception of NBA players, adult knees will no longer rub against the front-seat backs. Although the rear center seating position is tenable for only short trips—unless it’s someone you don’t like—the outboard seats are good for long-haul comfort: Chicago to Minneapolis, say, or Omaha to somewhere west of Laramie.

An impressive footnote to the dimensional increases: in addition to adding inches, the design engineers managed to pare about 300 pounds from the Malibu’s curb weights, depending on trim level and feature content. Also impressive: the weight loss wasn’t achieved at the expense of structure. Chevy claims a 17 percent improvement in structural rigidity, the starting point for all vehicle dynamics. And the Malibu’s dynamic scorecard is very good.

It’s not inaccurate to characterize the outgoing Malibu as a bit dowdy, and the packaging for the new car makes that conclusion inescapable. With its more athletic proportions, sporty nose, and sculpted side panels, the new Malibu goes from wallflower to one of the most attractive entries in the mid-size sedan class, and yet it is still instantly recognizable as a Chevy.

Like most new interiors, the Malibu’s is distinguished by higher-quality materials, lots of soft-touch surfaces, and enhanced infotainment. A touchscreen dominates the center of the dashboard, seven inches in these early models (an eight-inch option is due in February), with big icons that make for a higher level of user-friendliness than some systems. And there are also conventional switches and knobs.

Chief engineer Jesse Ortega sums it up: “When a button will do the job, we give you a button,” a design philosophy that warms my heart, since my personal automotive history dates to the time when AM radio was the one and only infotainment option.

In addition to a wholesale upgrade of the Malibu’s features and furnishings, Chevrolet has also added a new trim level—Premier—with interior design and details that would not be out of place in an Audi.

There are two engine choices, both turbocharged four-cylinders. The standard powerplant is a new 1.5-liter, one of GM’s new high-efficiency small engines, generating 160 horsepower and paired with a six-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 27 mpg in the city, 37 mpg on the highway. For more urgency, the optional engine is a 2.0-liter version that makes 250 horsepower, sending thrust to the front wheels via a new eight-speed automatic transmission—22 mpg city/32 mpg highway, according to the EPA.

The 2.0-liter engine is capable of propelling the Malibu to 60 mph in a wink or two over six seconds, which is tolerably brisk, although to be candid V-6 versions of the Honda Accord and Toyota Camry are a little quicker. On the other hand, the new eight-speed is the personification of smooth, and how fast do you need to go?

If fuel economy is the top priority, stand by for the new hybrid, a gasoline-electric combo rated for total system output of 182 horsepower and capable of 48 mpg in the city, 45 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. Those are prodigious numbers for a mid-size sedan, and infinitely better than the "mild hybrid" version of the previous Malibu.
We’ll take a closer look at the hybrid when it becomes available early next year. Note to shoppers: Chevrolet is also continuing to offer the outgoing model, renaming it as the 2016 Malibu Limited.

In the meantime, based on a half-day of driving in northern California, we can say that the two non-hybrid versions are very pleasant traveling companions. Ride quality is smooth, quick directional changes are achieved without drama, tire adhesion seems better than average, brake performance seems even better than that, and the steering provides a stronger sense of what the front wheels are doing than most in this new age of electric power systems.

Power is respectable with the 2.0-liter engine, a notch or two better than adequate with the 1.5-liter, throttle response is prompt with both (some turbo engines still exhibit a little hesitation when the driver floors the throttle at low speeds), and the operation of both transmissions is commendably transparent.

Ride quality edges toward the softer side, although it’s far from pillowy, and pretty close to perfect by contemporary family sedan standards. If there’s any marginal mark on the dynamic scorecard it’s for interior noise levels. Though generally quiet, with zero wind sound, a bit of road noise can creep into the cabin on certain types of pavement. However, this is not an uncommon phenomenon.

The Malibu keeps pace in terms of contemporary safety features, including pedestrian detection and automatic braking, and adds something new to the mix. It’s called Teen Driver, and basically it allows parents to track how the car is being driven—speed, distance—as well as whether various passive safety systems, such as seatbelts, are engaged, and whether active systems such as antilock braking have been triggered. Teen Driver is programmed into the young driver’s key fob, and is activated by a PIN in the Settings section of the Malibu’s MyLink system, Chevrolet’s infotainment array.

Spanning five trim levels (L, LS, LT, Hybrid, and Premier), Malibu MSRPs range from $22,500 to $31,795, and there are a number of option packages. And as you’d expect, the pricing stacks up competitively with segment bestsellers like Accord and Camry.
Long an also-ran, Chevy’s thorough and thoughtful overhaul of the Malibu puts this enduring brand name back into front-running contention among a flock of very good mid-size sedans.

Remember the old Chevy theme song, made famous by Dinah Shore in the 1950s? See the USA, in your Chevrolet. Along with the Chevy Impala, the new Malibu is a car that will make you want to do just that.

title: 2016 Chevrolet Camaro SS: Road Trip!
subTitle: I restored my soul while hauling ass! Portland to San Francisco in the sixth-generation muscle car.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear-wheel-drive sport coupe
Trim levels: 1LT, 2LT, 1SS, 2SS
Base price: $42,295 (price includes destination charge)
This car: $45,385
Engine: 6.2-liter V-8, 455 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 20 mpg city/28 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
My favorite standard feature: Side blind zone alert
Notable standard features on this model: Apple CarPlay, OnStar 4G LTE with wireless hot spot, rearview camera, wireless phone charging, SS appearance package, Brembo brakes
Notable options on this model: Magnetic Ride Control, dual-mode exhaust, sunroof
You might also be considering:
2016 Ford Mustang GT Premium ($37,295)
2016 Ford Mustang Shelby GT350 ($48,695)
2016 Dodge Challenger SRT 392 ($51,190)

Can you believe that Chevy’s sixth-generation 2016 Camaro marks the nameplate’s forty-eighth year in existence? Just to remind us all, this fall Chevrolet invited what seems like every automotive journalist in the United States (including me) on their forty-eight-state launch celebration. For four weeks a herd of Chevy’s storied pony cars galloped across the country on a variety of roads in an attempt to jack up Chevy’s Find New Roads slogan. I chose the Portland to San Francisco route to do just that, since I’ve never been to this part of the country.
<iframe width="420" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/MYloxTqurfs" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

First, I grabbed my videographer, Paul Dzendzel, and then we drew keys out of a bag to discover which Camaro we’d get from the three available powertrain configurations. The LT comes standard with a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder that makes 275 horsepower. If you give up a little fuel economy, there’s a more powerful 3.6-liter V-6, making 335 horsepower. The mother of all Camaros, the SS, has the 455-horsepower 6.2-liter V-8 engine that was first introduced in the Corvette. All three engines can be paired with a six-speed manual or eight-speed automatic. We lucked out with an all-black SS with the eight-speed. Since we were looking at a 900-mile drive in thirty-six hours, I was happy to have all of that power and virtually none of the labor, unless I wanted to work the paddle shifters for my amusement. Win, win in my book.

The 2016 Camaro exterior styling is not shockingly different from the fifth generation, which made its debut as a 2010 model after an eight-year hiatus. It is lower, wider, and lighter than its predecessor. According to design director Tom Peters, “We’ve taken that iconic design and amplified proportions to reflect a more dynamic driving experience—like the T-shirt on a muscular physique.” It is clearly an American muscle car, and it looks damn good.

Paul rode shotgun in our four-passenger sport coupe, which sounds like we had a lot of extra room, right? It was a short trip, but we brought enough luggage for a family of four, which the trunk gobbled right up. But if you’re planning to travel with four people, the back-seat passengers may want to consult the Geneva Convention. We used the back to stow our day bags and coats, and even that was awkward to access. Only contortionists should even attempt to buckle a child into a car seat in this vehicle. Otherwise, the cabin is lovely.

Since I had never been to Portland, we darted around town to take in a few landmarks before we headed toward Crater Lake. The SS sounded amazing, and even the hordes of Portlandians—trendy and otherwise—took notice as we growled by. The black on black truly is badass, although it made for a tough photo model. Our first stop was the famous Voodoo Doughnuts for a maple bacon doughnut. Yum.

Driving a car you have never driven in an unknown city is a good test for usability. The blind spots are the stuff of legends. The 2SS we were driving gets side blind zone alert and rear cross-traffic alert as standard. (Those safety features come optionally on the 2LT model, part of the $2,800 Convenience and Lighting package.) Buyers should strongly consider either the 2LT or the 2SS for that reason alone. Fortunately, a rearview camera is standard across all trim levels. It’s still not my favorite vehicle for tight traffic and quick lane changes.

The interior design is very clean and modern. Nothing remains of the garish American muscle cars of the Eighties and Nineties. The dash is minimalist chic, with a large eight-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay compatibility. The climate controls are built into the large center-mounted circular air vents. Think Madonna’s cone bra, or Austin Powers’ Fembots. The center console has two cupholders, an automatic parking brake, and a small storage area. Tucked behind the console is a wireless charging pad that slightly intrudes into the rear cabin. It's standard on the 2SS and part of the same Convenience and Lighting package as the active safety features on the 2LT. This is a throwaway for me, because I would need a special case for my iPhone to be compatible.) I immediately connected to the onboard 4G LTE for wireless connectivity, and via USB to the Apple CarPlay. I could have used some more spots to stash my gear; my phone especially longed for a home.

Once we were out on the highway, we pushed the OnStar button and had our destination of Klamath, California, sent directly into our vehicle. I think most users would use their connected phone, but OnStar is a great alternative, especially if you are driving in an area with sketchy service. The turns showed up in the touchscreen as well as in the optional head-up display. As usual, once I popped on my polarized sunglasses, I could barely see the HUD. I sorely missed having the actual map on the display and felt a bit discombobulated only knowing my next turn.
The straight highway was no match for the Camaro SS as we gobbled up the miles, whipping past the mild-mannered Oregonians.

The straight highway was no match for the Camaro SS as we gobbled up the miles, whipping past the mild-mannered Oregonians. The seats were fabulous, bolstered perfectly for comfort. I turned on the heated seat and steering wheel, both standard on the 2SS, to improve my comfort level. I was very excited to reach Crater Lake, which I mistakenly believed was the deepest lake in the world. You can hear me showing my joy on the video, but I didn't find out until later—while doing an Isaac Asimov trivia quiz back in the office—that it's actually only the deepest lake in the United States. Still, 1,932 feet, people.

Once we neared Crater Lake and started to ascend the mountain, I began to appreciate the car’s agility and road manners. The roads were extremely twisty, and they were also ice covered in spots. Which gave me a chance to test out the drive modes: Snow, Ice, Tour, Sport, and Track (the last of those is only found on the SS). When the rear started to break loose, I selected Snow mode, and it settled right down. For a powerful rear-wheel-drive vehicle, it managed the slippery conditions amazingly well.

The 2016 Camaro SS is 223 pounds lighter than the fifth generation. According to Camaro chief engineer Al Oppenheiser, “The performance of the Camaro 2.0L Turbo will challenge many of the iconic muscle cars from the 1960s, while the Camaro SS’s performance—including 0.97-g cornering—makes it one of the most capable two-plus-two coupes on the market. The performance numbers only tell half of the story, because the lighter curb weight also makes the new Camaro feel more responsive and agile behind the wheel. It brakes more powerfully, dives into corners quicker, accelerates faster, and is more fun to drive than ever.” Agreed, especially the corner diving.

We quickly took in the majesty of Crater Lake, then scrambled down the twisty road. It was pitch black by 5:30 p.m., so a great deal of the drive west to Klamath, California, was in darkness. We took the opportunity to play with the optional spectrum lighting. We had a veritable rainbow of colors to choose from. It can even be programmed to change with the driving mode selected. For those who prefer a techno concert vibe, it can actually roll through the rainbow to signal to other drivers that you are having more fun than they are. I’m looking at you, Ford Mustang. When we reached Klamath, I fell asleep with visions of redwoods dancing in my head.

We hit the road early so we could make both Highway 1 and the redwoods while delivering our car to the San Francisco airport before nightfall. The Camaro SS was a great car to take in, and through, the magnificent redwoods. These giants can live up to 2,000 years and can weigh over a million pounds. I half expected to see a dinosaur in the distance. The highlight was driving right through a tree. Tourists have been doing this since the Great Depression. I honestly wanted to skip the remainder of the road trip and spend a lovely afternoon in the shady woods. But like Cinderella I needed to turn in my slipper, so off we went in search of the salty ocean.

As we took the serpentine Highway 1 out to the coast, I wound down the windows and listened to the engine as breathtaking views opened in front of us. It helped to keep my mind off plummeting to our deaths. The flat-bottomed steering wheel was comfortable, and the steering was well connected and responsive. There is a reason that the best performance cars use Brembo brakes: they do not fade under hard use, even extended hard use. I was relieved to have both excellent steering and brakes as I danced along the crushingly beautiful Pacific Ocean coastline. I don’t experience roads like this in southeastern Michigan, but I'm damn happy to know the SS has the chops when called upon.

Once we made it back to the 101, we were racing the clock. Luckily, California drivers have hot shoes, too. I was glad to be off the twisty roads and kept the needle between 80 and 90 mph until we neared  the outer reaches of San Francisco traffic. Unfortunately, we timed our Golden Gate Bridge crossing for just after sunset. We relied on Google Maps via Apple CarPlay to quickly usher us through rush hour traffic in this unknown city. I was surprised at how easily I managed to navigate the city in the inky night.

When we reached the airport I was sad to hand over the keys. I definitely wanted to walk on my own legs for a few hours, but then I would have happily hopped back into the car and continue to explore California. I was amazed at how much I enjoyed driving the Camaro SS, but I am not convinced that I would want it for my daily driver. The convertible version arriving soon may convince me, since without a top, the visibility will improve immensely, and after all my nest is empty so I don’t even need a back seat.

title: A Monitor for the Child Seat
subTitle: Packaged for gifting, this is it: the product that tells parents if they've left a child in the car.
promoTitle: A Monitor for the Child Seat
promoTeaserSmall: Packaged for gifting, this is it: the product that tells parents if they've left a child in the car.
promoTeaser: Packaged for gifting, this is it: the product that tells parents if they've left a child in the car.
keywords: A Monitor for the Child Seat
metaTitle: A Monitor for the Child Seat - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Packaged for gifting, this is it: the product that tells parents if they've left a child in the car.

pageElements.text: If you have any new babies on your shopping list for the holidays, or any friends or relatives about to go back to jobs after maternity leaves, here is a brilliant idea that isn't yet another receiving blanket or onesie set. The Driver's Little Helper car seat monitor is an attractively packaged gift set. There's a cute little story book (shown here), and it comes in a stylish presentation box, but the heart of the matter is the monitor that sits inside the child's car seat. Interfacing with it is a smartphone app that ensures the child never gets left in the car seat by mistake.

The $79.99 price of the set may sound expensive, but if you've ever read about well-meaning parents who accidentally left a child strapped into a car seat, you know that this is a long-overdue and valuable product, even for those who never think they will need it.

The setup is quite simple. There's a soft plastic sensor pad that you place under the fabric seat cover of the child's car seat. That attaches with a connector cord to a battery-operated power pack that hooks onto the back of the car seat or on the seatbelt. Thus installed, the Driver's Little Helper communicates via Bluetooth with your smartphone. It will give you alerts about the temperature where your child is sitting and, most important, will send you a notification about the presence or absence of a child in the seat when the vehicle stops.

Using it is a simple matter of downloading the Driver's Little Helper app on Google Play for Android or the App Store for iPhone. You can enter up to three cell phone numbers for text alerts plus an email address for emergency notifications, and you can choose the time interval before a reminder is sent in increments from one to five minutes.
This strikes me as very similar to the Life Alert for older people. No matter how unlikely it is that an emergency will happen, the peace of mind is completely worth it.

My eighty-seven-year-old father has a Life Alert that notifies me and my siblings, via phone call, if he has had a fall or other emergency. No matter how likely or unlikely it is that it will happen, the peace of mind is completely worth it. This strikes me as a very similar product. You don't think you'll ever get out of the car and leave your baby strapped in, alone in the back seat. But people do, and it's the worst of tragedies. Here is a product that I have been hoping somebody would make, and one that's very attractively designed and packaged, too. Kudos!
You can order the package directly from Driver's Little Helper. Before you do, a quick look at the App Store or Google Play description will give you a quick preview.

title: 2016 Mazda CX-3 Touring AWD
subTitle: More car than ute, but what about that zoom-zoom?
promoTeaserSmall: More car than ute, but what about that zoom-zoom?
promoTeaser: More car than ute, but what about that zoom-zoom?
metaDescription: More car than ute, but what about that zoom-zoom?

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive compact crossover
Trim levels: Sport, Touring, Grand Touring FWD and AWD models
Base price: $27,120 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $27,670
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 146 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with Sport mode
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/32 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Buick Encore AWD ($25,385)
2016 Mini Cooper Paceman S All4 ($29,950)
2016 Nissan Juke AWD ($22,925)

Fun-O-Meter: 8

Before you read this review of the all-new 2016 Mazda CX-3, you should know this: I am predisposed to like Mazdas. I own a 2004 Mazdaspeed Miata, which I dearly love, and I believe fervently in Mazda’s evocative and enduring tagline, “zoom-zoom.” As Mazda so simply explains, “All children instinctively know it. A few adults still remember it. One unique car company refuses to outgrow it.”

Being a twelve-year old boy trapped in the body of an adult woman, I also refuse to outgrow my love of zoom-zoom. I have been looking forward to driving the new Mazda CX-3 since I saw it in concept form a year ago at the 2014 Los Angeles Auto Show.

The first thing you notice, even before you drive it, is what the Mazda CX-3 looks like. Call it step one in establishing your zoom. Simply stated, the CX-3 is the coolest-looking subcompact SUV on the market, as interesting in its final production sheetmetal as the concept version that  took the L.A. show by storm. Design is important to me, and Mazda’s design department has consistently overdelivered in the past few years, making its line of SUVs as interesting to look at as its cars.

Carved like a crouching animal in profile, the CX-3 carries on the Kodo design “soul of motion” language that Mazda first introduced in the 2012 CX-5. It is taut, exciting, with a short rear overhang and one of the longest hoods in this category, making it look every bit the sports car it is not. It’s a teensy, tinsy subcompact SUV. And in this case, it’s heavy on the sport, but very light on the ute.

The 2016 CX-3 has just about the amount of cargo room that you’d expect, which is not exactly an overabundance. In fact, quarters are tight in general. The CX-3 is rated to hold five passengers, but if all five are my size, at least three of us will be grumpy about it. In fact, any medium-size human riding in the back seat will have a time fitting legs in there, too. There wasn’t enough space for my large briefcase to fit on the floor behind the driver.
You can make better use of the 60/40 split-folding rear seat by flipping it down. That will almost quadruple the cargo volume, from 12.4 to 44.5 cubic feet.

Up front, it’s tight enough that driver and passenger will feel like they’re sitting cheek to cheek, and I do mean that in every sense of the word. There’s a single flip-down armrest between the two seats, and like the one you’ll find on an airplane back in coach seating, it is not really shareable. Tucked partway under that armrest is the multifunction controller for the seven-inch center console infotainment screen. The controller manages audio, home screen with apps, and the navigation function.
Compact quarters aside, our CX-3 Grand Touring AWD test car’s cabin was lovely: a very simple, elegant interior with the minimum of distractions.

Compact quarters aside, our CX-3 Grand Touring AWD test car’s cabin was lovely: a very simple, elegant interior with the minimum of distractions, and a maximum amount of rich leather and suede in a combination of dark grey, maroon, and parchment (off-white). The dash is set up horizontally, with parchment leather trim running from the left of the steering wheel to the right-side door, which sets up a clean appearance. Vents and their controllers are fitted along that horizon, adding to the simple elegance, with the center information screen up above it for easy access by the driver.

Leather also covers the steering wheel, the gearshift knob, the brake handle, and all “five” seating positions. The seats are extra luxe, with perforated suede inserts. The fronts are heated. All of this and much more (like a rearview camera, rear cross-traffic alert, blind spot monitoring, keyless entry, Bluetooth hands-free phone and radio, a nav system, and power moonroof, for instance) is included in the base $27,120. In fact, the only option added was Mazda Mobile Start for $550. Although we didn’t test it, the Mazda Mobile Start app looks pretty cool, allowing you to access a variety of remote features from your smartphone: locking and unlocking your car, starting it from anywhere in the world (okay, whatever), finding your car in that holiday mess of a parking lot, and more. Not sure about that price, though.

And I’m not sure if I’d give the CX-3 two “zoom”s. Maybe more horsepower, something I find myself saying about almost every Mazda I drive. Even 20 hp more would do it. But Mazdas are engineered and designed with all hands operating as one, with the intent to create a vehicle with maximum efficiency, weight savings, and power output, and to achieve the optimal balance of performance, fuel economy, and emissions. Hard to argue with that.

The CX-3 AWD weighs in at an amazingly low 2,952 pounds (the front-wheel-drive version is only 2,809 pounds). In comparison, the curb weight of the Nissan Juke AWD is 2,981 pounds, the Mini Paceman All4 is 3,260 pounds, and the Buick Encore AWD is 3,358 pounds. Weight matters, in both fuel economy and overall performance.

The CX-3 only really disappointed in initial acceleration—more labored and noisy than I would personally like. But once up to speed, the CX-3 was fully engaged. Here in Michigan, where curvy roads are as rare as smooth pavement, there are those who use freeway on- and off-ramps at speed to test cornering capability, a practice referred to fondly as “ramping.” In a little bit of impromptu ramping, the CX-3 handled like a dream, helped by a small button at the base of the automatic gearshift lever. Put that button on Sport, switch from automatic to manual shifting via the paddle shifters mounted in perfect position just behind the steering wheel’s cross spokes, and suddenly the CX-3 finds its zoom-zoom.

For the past twenty-five years, Mazda has set itself up as the car company for people who love to drive. The CX-3 may not be a pure performance play, but it’s fun, it’s balanced, and it’s emotionally pleasing to drive. It’s a beautiful car in terms of handling, steering, suspension, brakes, and its ability to go through a turn at a fairly decent clip. It is more sporting than the average compact SUV, because being fun to drive has always been a critical part of Mazda’s DNA. It matters so much that Mazda’s new tagline is...Driving Matters.
But if you’re shopping for a crossover for more practical reasons, this may not be what you’re looking for.

title: Be Smart about Smart Cruise Control
subTitle: 7 things to know about the feature that lets your car watch out for what’s in front of you.
