pageElements.text: How do you maintain an appropriate following distance from the car in front of you? I prefer two seconds; here’s what I do. I pick a fixed point on the side of the road, like a signpost, and when the car in front of me passes it, I begin counting “one one-thousand, two one-thousand.” If I get to the signpost before I’m done, I’m too close. I repeat that exercise until I have a very good visual in my mind of how far two seconds is. One second is not far enough, if you ask me. And, sadly, three seconds gives too much space for the impatient idiot on your right to jam in.

My signpost method is the idea behind “smart,” or adaptive, cruise control. This is an active safety feature that is increasingly available on a wide range of new vehicles. Using radar or cameras that point forward, the system monitors and corrects the distance between your car and the one ahead of you. Many have low-speed functionality for traffic jams and bumper-to-bumper traffic, while others don’t kick in until you’re going around 25 mph.
Manufacturers are calling this technology by various names, but all of them are a great supplement to your own personal signpost-counting ritual, and they can make driving easier to do well.
Why would you spend the extra money to get a safety package that includes adaptive cruise control? Let us count the ways.
Manufacturers are calling this technology by various names, but all of them supplement your own personal signpost-counting ritual and can make driving easier to do well.

1. If you like cruise control, you’ll love adaptive cruise control. It helps you maintain a set speed. No car in front of you? You’re cruising along at your chosen speed, just like with regular cruise control. But it goes one better and also continuously scans the traffic ahead of you, using front-mounted cameras or radar. Then it adjusts your speed to what traffic is doing in front of you.

2. No more canceling and restarting, canceling and restarting your cruise control as other traffic comes and goes. Don’t you hate that? Adaptive cruise control will slow you down when traffic in front requires it, and speed you up again when there’s room to do so. You spend less time adjusting. What’s that worth in your daily commute?

3. You’re still driving the car. Set it, and forget it, or you can shut it off, so there’s nothing “autonomous” about it. You’re still totally in control. You can also choose to use “regular” cruise control and set a speed for your car but not a following distance. That’s still available on cars with the adaptive cruise control capability.

4. Feel confident about your following distance all the time. You have control over the time interval between you and the next car. Volvo has a choice of five distance intervals; BMW, Hyundai, and Ford have four. Generally this is displayed on your car’s information screen (or, as on some Hyundai models, on the head-up display), and you can choose how many "bars" of distance separate you. As an example, using Hyundai’s Smart Cruise Control, if your set cruise control speed is 56 mph, Distance 4 is 170 feet and Distance 1 is 82 feet from the car in front of you.

5. A growing number of systems will work at very low speed, so your nerves are spared in traffic jams. Well, you’re not off the hook entirely; you still have to pay attention, but tech packages such as Acura’s Low-Speed Follow, BMW’s Stop & Go, Chrysler’s Adaptive Cruise Control-Plus with Full Stop, and Audi’s Traffic Jam Assist (coming on the 2017 Q7) will maintain a safe following distance down below 25 mph, such as in bumper-to-bumper situations.

6. Look carefully to identify adaptive cruise control, since it goes by many names. Some of its other monikers are: Distronic Plus (Mercedes-Benz), Active Cruise Control (BMW), Smart Cruise Control (Hyundai), and Intelligent Cruise Control (Nissan and Infiniti).

7. And the big question, how much does it cost? Look for adaptive cruise control as a standard feature on higher-end cars, including the Hyundai Equus and the Volkswagen Touareg Executive. It’s generally part of a safety or technology package on other models. Examples: It’s part of the $1,750 Ultimate package on the 2016 Hyundai Sonata Limited, part of the $1,800 Convenience package on the 2016 Volvo XC90, and part of the $2,885 Driver Assist package on the 2016 Cadillac ATS. With the adaptive cruise control, you’ll generally get such other useful features as automatic braking and lane departure warning.

The next frontier is definitely autonomous. We can all see it coming. Cadillac has announced it’s bringing out Super Cruise on the 2017 CT6, which will be a hands-off, feet-off experience. Whether or not you’re ready to go there, adaptive cruise control is a safety feature worth trying, if only to give your nerves a bit of a rest on the highway.

title: 2016 Chevrolet Corvette
subTitle: The one and only, in Stingray and Z06 form.
promoTeaserSmall: The one and only, in Stingray and Z06 form.
promoTeaser: The one and only, in Stingray and Z06 form.
metaDescription: The one and only, in Stingray and Z06 form.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear-wheel-drive sport coupe or convertible
Trim levels: Stingray: 1LT, 2LT, 3LT; Z06: 1LZ, 2LZ, 3LZ
Price range: $56,395 — $81,390
Engines: 6.2-liter V-8, 455/460 horsepower (Stingray); supercharged 6.2-liter V-8, 650 horsepower (Z06)
Transmissions: Seven-speed manual or eight-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 6.2-liter, manual: 17 mpg city/29 mpg highway; 6.2-liter, automatic: 16/29 mpg; 6.2-liter supercharged, manual: 15/22 mpg; 6.2-liter supercharged, automatic: 15/22 mpg
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Power-folding convertible top
Notable standard features on this model: Color head-up display (2LT and higher)
Notable options on this model: Corvette Museum Delivery that includes a Corvette Museum logo plaque personalized with your name
You might also be considering: Audi R8, Jaguar F-Type, Porsche 911, SRT Viper GTS

There is a reason the Corvette is the stuff of legends. In either 450-horsepower Stingray or supercharged 650-horsepower Z06 form, this is a car meant to be driven fast and intensely. It's also desirable to look at, particularly the convertible version with an electronic remote-opening top and a removable carbon fiber roof panel that fits under the hatch. Like other Chevrolets, the Corvette has OnStar with a 4G LTE wireless hot spot, plus the excellent MyLink infotainment screen, now connected to your smartphone via Apple CarPlay. In the realm of active safety, all Corvettes get a rearview camera, but the nannying ends there. That's not what you're after when shopping for a sports car like this.

The Z06 is ready for the track, with a Performance Data Recorder to record HD video and round out your quantified life. The optional Performance package ($7,995) comes with a Z07 performance suspension with magnetic selective ride control, a set of carbon-ceramic Brembo brakes, nineteen-inch front and twenty-inch rear summer tires, and carbon fiber ground effects and splitter. Adding to the street cred are optional red brake calipers and a performance "aggressive sound" exhaust.

For a thrill of a different sort, you can add a $5,000 Engine Build Experience and watch your Z06's supercharged LT4 engine being built at the Bowling Green, Kentucky, assembly plant.

New in 2016

Curb-view front parking camera (optional, Stingray 2LT/3LT)
Magnetic Ride Control (optional, some Stingrays)
Enhanced Chevrolet MyLink with smartphone projection technology and Apple CarPlay
Three new design packages (Twilight Blue, Spice Red, and Jet Black Suede), plus two new tintcoat exterior colors (Racing Yellow and Long Beach Red Metallic)
New carbon fiber hood option
Flat-bottom steering wheel

More about the Corvette

Fast Women: Interview with Corvette designer Helen Emsley

title: 2016 Chevrolet Tahoe
subTitle: When a crossover really won't do the job for you, there's the Tahoe.
promoTeaserSmall: When a crossover really won't do the job for you, there's the Tahoe.
promoTeaser: When a crossover really won't do the job for you, there's the Tahoe.
metaDescription: When a crossover really won't do the job for you, there's the Tahoe.

pageElements.text:
Type: Seven-to-nine-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive full-size sport-utility vehicle
Price range: $48,195 – $65,805
Trim levels: LS, LT, LTZ
Engine: 5.3-liter V-8, 355 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: FWD: 16 mpg city/23 mpg highway; AWD: 16/22 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Heated and ventilated perforated leather front bucket seats and heated steering wheel (LTZ)
Notable standard features on this model: Up to twelve charging locations, including up to six USB ports
Notable options on this model: Theft Protection package ($410, LT and LTZ) includes glass-breakage sensors, interior motion detectors, and an inclination sensor that measures tilt of the vehicle
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Suburban, GMC Yukon, Ford Expedition, Toyota Sequoia

If you have a taste for a big, capable full-size sport-utility vehicle, the Chevrolet Tahoe is a strong contender, second only in hugeness to the Suburban in Chevy's lineup. Chevrolet is proud to say the Tahoe is the favorite of police K-9 units, and if it's tough enough for them, it's tough enough for just about anything you can hand out. Available as rear- or all-wheel drive, the Tahoe is not just a capable utility vehicle—although it is; it's quite luxurious as well, seating up to nine with heated and ventilated seats in fine perforated leather, a heated steering wheel, and a power liftgate that responds to your foot moving under the rear bumper.

There's a full slate of safety features, particularly on the top LTZ, but also available, mainly optionally, on the LS and LT. These include adaptive cruise control and a plethora of alert and safety assistance features: automatic emergency braking, lane keeping assist, side blind zone alert, lane change alert, rear cross-traffic alert, forward collision alert, and a safety alert seat that vibrates a warning if you stray from your lane.

Yes, fuel economy tops out at 23 mpg on the highway (22 mpg for the all-wheel-drive model), but you can tow up to 8,600 pounds and carry a maximum of 94.7 cubic feet of cargo.

New for 2016

The Tahoe was all new for 2015, so changes are few. The base LS gets an Enhanced Driver Alert package ($695) that includes forward collision alert, lane keeping assist, and GM's vibrating driver alert seat that lets you know when you're straying from your lane.
The LTZ gets a head-up display and an enhanced driver information center with an eight-inch display ($875).
There are two new colors: Siren Red Tintcoat and Iridescent Pearl Tricoat.

title: Pro/Con: Roundabout or 4-Way Stop?
subTitle: Molly and the experts approve of roundabouts. Laura prefers a four-way stop. Whose side are you on?
promoTeaserSmall: Molly and the experts approve of roundabouts. Laura prefers a four-way stop. Whose side are you on?
promoTeaser: Molly and the experts approve of roundabouts. Laura prefers a four-way stop. Whose side are you on?
metaDescription: Molly and the experts approve of roundabouts. Laura prefers a four-way stop. Whose side are you on?

contributors.displayName: Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

pageElements.text:
Laura Says: Give Me a Good Old Four-Way Stop or Even a Stoplight Anytime

I'll admit something to you: I go out of my way to avoid roundabouts. Not all the time, really; mainly at rush hour, school dropoff or pickup time, and any other time I have good reason to worry about the other people who will be taking that up-to-360-degree spin with me. Four-way stops have their own issues, which in fact are the same issues that bother me in every kind of driving: selfish drivers who don't honor the social contract to take turns. All those people who zoom ahead in the lane that's about to close, then want to forcibly insert themselves in front of you. All those people who don't realize the light has changed because they're texting, holding up everyone behind them. All those people who assume it's their turn every turn. Now put them all into an endlessly spinning circle and see whether they yield when you expect them to.

I know that the roundabout holds a scientifically proven advantage for both safety and efficiency. I know that the reason is because cars can keep moving through an intersection in a nice, smooth pattern; and yet I admit, I am not totally comfortable with the idea that cars will just keep moving through complex intersections. I  like to see a brief stop required from all those oblivious texters, all those aggressive me-firsters, and all those perfectly nice people who just need to scope out the intersection and think about what they're doing for a minute.
If I had my way, I would prefer stoplights at any intersection with moderate to heavy traffic or any kind of complexity.

I mean, you can cite statistics that traffic moves more smoothly through roundabouts, or that more cars get through in the same amount of time, but a roundabout in my town was named this spring as the site of the most accidents of any intersection in the state of Michigan. Really, if I had my way, I would prefer stoplights at any intersection with moderate to heavy traffic or any kind of complexity. They were good enough for my Midwestern grandparents, and they're good enough for me.

Molly Says: Get with the 21st Century and Embrace the Traffic Circle

Honorable Laura Brown, I wish to disagree with you. No surprise there. If you saw my video Mastering the Roundabout, you know I'm in favor of them.
Since humans are flawed and can’t seem to stop blabbing on their phones or even worse, texting, let's all welcome the added safety of roundabouts.

When your grandparents were born, those crazy Wright brothers were flying gliders at Kitty Hawk. The first electric traffic light had yet to be installed. They adapted along the way to many advances in vehicle safety throughout their lives: freeways, mandatory seatbelts, and safety glass, for instance. All of these advancements have saved lives and the roundabouts that have long been common in Europe have burst onto American soil to save our lives with an added benefit of reducing traffic congestion.

The roundabouts are here to stay, so it is time you stopped avoiding them and start to embrace them. I wholeheartedly agree they are a bit daunting at first. I especially dislike the double roundabout just north of Ann Arbor at the freeway interchange. I once accidentally re-entered the freeway when I was trying to go to a restaurant. My daughter, then ten years old, was starving and sobbing in the back seat as the restaurant receded in the background. We could see the food; we just couldn't get to it. But since that time I have boned up on proper usage, and I have slayed the double roundabout.

When vehicles enter a roundabout, their speed is reduced, and the counterclockwise flow of traffic eliminates head-on, left turn, and angle collisions. These facts alone make it a no-brainer to install them in areas where traffic is heavy. Every single day, I witness cars speeding through intersections after the light is red. I can’t imagine there are very many drivers who have not witnessed a car blatantly running a red light. Since humans are flawed and can’t seem to stop blabbing on their phones or even worse, texting, let's all welcome the added safety of roundabouts.

So in closing, dear Laura, these advances in vehicle and traffic safety are marching forward. Unless people live in the sticks, they are going to need to deal with roundabouts. So let's promote proper usage and a positive attitude toward our new best friend, the roundabout.

title: 5 Packing Tips for Holiday Trips
subTitle: Family drives over the river and through the woods will be more fun if you go into them prepared.
promoTeaserSmall: Family drives over the river and through the woods will be more fun if you go into them prepared.
promoTeaser: Family drives over the river and through the woods will be more fun if you go into them prepared.
metaTitle: 5 Packing Tips for Holiday Trips - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Family drives over the river and through the woods will be more fun if you go into them prepared.

pageElements.text: Going on a long drive on the way to holiday festivities? Road trips are a different story in December than in August. Back then, you packed light: bathing suits, sunglasses, a cooler to keep drinks chilled. In the winter, you might be headed for the sun, but in many parts of the country you’ll also face the possibility of bad weather and resulting driving challenges. Add in the traffic snarls that are a risk in all parts of the country during the holiday season, and you know you’d better prepare yourself for anything.

As veteran road trippers—and Northerners—we are experts on the subject. We also travel with dogs and children regularly, so we’ve worked out a plan to make our drives easier. Here are our top five tips for everyone heading out to Grandmother’s house this Christmastime.

1. Keep your road-management supplies accessible. If there’s any chance of snow, have a shovel, a bag of kitty litter for traction, and a good ice scraper on board. Pack them last, so you don’t have to take all your luggage out of the car to get to it when you need it. Another tip that we hope you won’t need: ensure you have a spare tire on board. You’d be surprised how many newer cars don’t come with them. Again, make sure it’s accessible without unpacking the whole car. Last but not least, have a road service plan, and bring the membership card and phone number to call if you need it.

2. Have weather-appropriate gear for everybody who is riding in the car. It doesn’t matter that it’s not snowing and the roads are clear; things can change quickly. If you’re in a colder climate or headed to one, everybody in the car needs to have a coat, boots, gloves, and a hat. If you don’t ever need them, no big deal. If you need them desperately and don’t have them, that could become a very big deal.

3. Expect something to go wrong, and be ready for it. Blankets, a basic first aid kit, flashlight and batteries, and bottled water make up the bare minimum of supplies you should have in the car in the winter. Even better, bring along nonperishable foods for everyone, including for any pets who are riding along. Granola and chocolate bars aren’t damaged by the cold and give a quick energy boost. If you are lucky enough to be traveling with small children, don’t forget extra baby formula, foods they can eat, and utensils to feed them with.

4. Keep control of your chargers, batteries, and electronic equipment. There’s nothing worse than arriving at your destination and realizing you don’t have a phone charger with you—unless it’s being stuck in a traffic jam for hours, while realizing you didn’t bring a phone charger. If you’re traveling with several family members, a communal tech bag is a good way to make sure cords and batteries don’t get misplaced during the journey and make it home with you at the end.

5. Remember what you’re in the car to do. It’s easy to get caught up in the stress of holiday travel and forget that, presumably, you are traveling with your loved ones and heading out to see other people you care about. Don’t let the pursuit of the destination make you forget that. Take advantage of the time you’re confined together in the car, and try to enjoy one another’s company. Sometimes the best thing to pack is a sense of humor. Leave enough time to work around unavoidable delays on the road, plan for problems, and bring your patience. Everyone’s holiday will be better if you do, especially yours. And it will leave you in the right frame of mind to start planning next summer’s road trip early in the New Year.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive compact sedan
Trim levels: SE, SXT, Aero, GT, Limited
Base price: $20,195 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $24,115
Engine: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 184 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with Powertech manual mode
Fuel economy: 23 mpg city/35 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated (2015 model was a Top Safety Pick)
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Ford Focus SE Sedan ($19,390)
2016 Honda Civic EX Sedan ($21,875)
2016 Mazda 3 iSport Sedan ($20,015)

Fun-O-Meter: 6

Are you looking for a comfortable compact sedan that seats four people, at a price that hits right around the $20,000 mark? You’re in luck; there’s a boat load of those. Why would you pick this one, other than to buy into an authentic American muscle-car brand? Well, the 2016 Dodge Dart offers a decent-size trunk and room for adults in the back seat, for the price of a cramped subcompact. And, for its surprisingly low price, the Dart looks pretty good. But make no mistake. The Dart is a long way from a Dodge Challenger SRT Hellcat.

After a hiatus of almost four decades, the Dart name reappeared in 2013, attached to a car that was kind of tinny and not impressive in any way. It was an inauspicious launch for a car with such a classic name: one that dates back to 1960 and, for people of a certain age, brings back fond memories. It has been an uphill sales climb since then. Although 2015 Dart sales are up five percent compared to 2014, the car has set no sales records. With 80,661 sold in 2015 through November, the Dart is nowhere near competitors like the Honda Civic, which sold 302,588 in the same time period.
The Dodge design team has cleaned up the hood to make it look a touch sportier. To really add some zing, you need to check out the optional packages.

Not much has changed, although the base Dart SE is $500 more than last year, at $17,990, including destination charge. Otherwise, the 2016 Dart is a carryover, still a stubby-nosed, front-wheel drive car. It can be tricky to make front-drivers look sexy, but the Dodge design team has cleaned up the hood to make it look a touch sportier. To really add some zing, you need to check out the optional packages.

Our test car, an SXT, which is second in the five-level lineup of Darts, starts at $20,390 and adds two optional packages I would call crucial to your self-respect—Rallye and Blacktop—and neither breaks the bank.

The Blacktop package adds some more badass attitude for a very reasonable $295. Actually, that’s super cheap when you consider you’re getting eighteen-inch five-spoke aluminum gloss black wheels, blackened foglamp bezels, and exterior mirrors with a gloss black finish. All that blackety-black really changes the exterior, giving it a little bit of menace, a little like an undercover cop car.

The Rallye appearance package is an extra $595 and adds even more black to the outside, along with chrome dual exhaust tips, a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, front and rear floor mats, and a Rallye badge. But interestingly, it’s not just an appearance package: there’s also a touring suspension and a rear stabilizer bar. I hate to imagine what the ride quality and handling would be without those, because the Dart as equipped is a kind of bangy thing with a little roll in turns on two-lanes and on rough road. Electronic roll mitigation probably keeps it from rolling any more than the slight but noticeable amount it was rolling, which I noticed around the same time I was hearing the suspension slapping around behind me.

There are three engine choices in the Dart lineup. The base model has a 2.0-liter four-cylinder making 160 horsepower, while the Aero gets the same horsepower from a 1.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder. The SXT we tested had the top engine, a 2.4-liter four-cylinder that makes 184 horsepower.

The six-speed Powertec automatic transmission ($1,250) with Power Stick shifter allows you to operate in manual mode, and it shifts very well. Otherwise, leave it in automatic mode. You’ll find the transmission is a little edgy around 1,500 rpm as if unsure what gear it wants to stay in. Either use the manual mode or just drive a little faster to smooth things out, I say. (Always my go-to position.)

Inside the car, there is a lot that seems like carryover from another era. It’s fairly plastic but clean and nicely detailed. When adding on to the 2016 Dart, one must-have is the Touchscreen Group ($595), where you get the rearview camera and the generously sized 8.4-inch touchscreen display. These are standard on the Aero and GT models. It is a bit incongruous to see the big touchscreen alongside the dot-matrix-print information center on the dash, which takes you back to the 1990s in a hurry. Another throwback is the single-disc CD player.

Where the center console meets the dash, there’s a pair of rotary dials for radio and climate control functions. These controls are also accessible inside the touchscreen,  which is way more annoying than just using the controls in front of you. For example, you can’t adjust the mode to modulate the air blowing on your face or your feet unless you go into the touchscreen. Here is another indication that this car has one foot in the past and one in the present.

The seats, front and rear, are comfortable. Between the front seats, you’ll find a lidded bin that is padded to serve as an armrest. The bin is deep, but its dimensions are saltine-box-like. On the other hand, the glove box is fairly deep and big, with a built-in bin in the lid to hold the owner’s manual and a plastic clip to hold an envelope with your insurance and registration papers. Those handy features leave you with a big, open bin where you can put a small soft purse.

At the base of the shifter, there’s a little kickup that meets the center console. In Volvos and a few other vehicles, that’s a pass-through where you can put your purse down below. It’s a solid piece in the Dart, but they’ve cleverly done little cutout niches, one for the passenger and one for the driver, that will hold maybe a wallet or some coins, a good use of otherwise wasted space. You would want to consider its proximity to the accelerator pedal before you just jam a bunch of stuff in it.

As for seating, the back seat really will hold two average-size adults, although the center seat, as in most back seats these days, is not comfortable for the big’uns except in a pinch. The trunk is really big at 13.1 cubic feet, and the rear seats flop down to increase the space, although it’s not a full-width opening.

For active safety features that are becoming common on a growing range of vehicles, you’ll have to go up to the Dart GT or Limited (starting at $23,090 and $25,390, respectively), and pay an added $1,095 for the Technology package. It includes HID headlamps, rear cross-path detection, rear park assist, blind spot monitoring, and rain-sensing wipers.
This is a heavily contested segment with a lot of players, and the Dart is not a head-to-head competitor with any of the important cars in the compact-sedan segment.

In 1960, the entry-level Dart was by far the top seller in the brand’s lineup. Not so these days. Let’s face it, the Dart is long in the tooth. This is a heavily contested segment with a lot of players, and the Dart is not a head-to-head competitor with any of the important cars in the compact-sedan segment.

If you’re shopping in this price range, you’d be well served to look at all the usual entry-level suspects in the under-$20,000 range: a Kia Forte, a Mazda 3, a Ford Focus. Until there’s a new Dart, it will get its clock cleaned by new offerings such as the brand-new Honda Civic and Nissan Altima. It’s easy to name about a dozen compact and subcompact cars that are sexier, fresher, and have newer equipment.
But if you are a Dodge boy, and there are plenty, Dodge is a storied brand, and there are still people who want to buy American cars. Maybe you’re one of them, and there’s nothing wrong with that.

promoTeaser: Urban runabout with a dash of practicality.
metaDescription: Urban runabout with a dash of practicality.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive subcompact crossover
Price range: $21,195–$27,625
Trim levels: LS, LT, LTZ
Engines: Turbocharged 1.4-liter four-cylinder, 138 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: FWD: 26 mpg city/34 mpg highway; AWD: 24/31 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good in five areas; front crash prevention information not available
Our favorite standard feature: Rearview camera, ten air bags
Notable standard features on this model: 4G LTE with Wi-Fi hot spot standard on all models for three months or 3 GB
Notable options on this model: Heated front seats (LTZ)
You might also be considering: Honda HR-V, Jeep Renegade, Kia Soul, Nissan Juke

The Trax is a member of a relatively new variety of vehicle, the subcompact crossover, which has a 100.3-inch wheelbase—only an inch or two longer than a Honda Fit or a Ford Fiesta—and the tall body of a sport-utility vehicle. Its mere existence is a tribute to the fact that people are increasingly swapping out their sedans for practical, high-riding vehicles with available all-wheel drive. There's no denying that the Trax, all new in 2015, is an attractive choice in this category. It's nominally a five-passenger vehicle, but you wouldn't really want to be the person in the middle of the back seat. With that back seat folded, there are 48.4 cubic feet of cargo space. For comparison purposes, the Honda CR-V, a more traditionally sized compact crossover, offers 70.9 cubic feet with its rear seat down. So the Trax may not be the big-stuff hauler, if that's what you are looking for, but if you want an adorable urban runabout, it has much to recommend it.

For example, there is a standard rearview camera, available park assist, and a seven-inch touchscreen with OnStar and 4G LTE with a wireless hot spot on board. Siri Eyes Free, too, which is a novelty in this price range.

New for 2016

The Trax was all new in 2015.
There are four new metallic paint colors: Crimson, Sable, Cyber Gray, and Champagne Silver.

More about the Chevrolet Trax

13 Orange Cars: 2016 Chevrolet Trax in Orange Rock Metallic

subTitle: Better-looking and yet greener.
promoTeaserSmall: Better-looking and yet greener.
promoTeaser: Better-looking and yet greener.
metaDescription: Better-looking and yet greener.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive gasoline-electric hybrid compact hatchback
Price range: $33,995—$39,830
Trim levels: LT, Premier
Engine: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 180 horsepower, and two electric motors
Transmission:Electrically variable direct drive
Fuel economy: 42 mpg city/highway combined, 106 MPGe
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: Regen(eration) on Demand
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, heated leather seats, leather-wrapped steering wheel, 8.0-inch infotainment screen, Bose eight-speaker premium audio, five-year OnStar service
Notable options on this model: Chevrolet MyLink with navigation ($495), Driver Confidence 1 package: blind spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, lane departure alert ($495); Driver Confidence 2 package: lane-keeping assist, low-speed automatic braking, forward collision alert, auto-dimming headlights ($495)
You might also be considering: BMW i3, Ford C-Max, Lexus CT Hybrid, Nissan Leaf, Toyota Prius and Prius V

It has been on the market since 2010, but this year Chevrolet has rolled out an all-new model. The 2016 Chevrolet Volt looks a whole lot more like a "normal" five-passenger car and less like some kind of futuristic fantasy of the 1990s, and that is a very good thing. It wasn't a big seller in its original incarnation (fewer than 80,000 sold in the five years on the market), even though it has the advantage over plug-in hybrids of being seamless, switching from all-electric to gasoline power with no human intervention. On all-electric power, you can go 53 miles, and it has a 420-mile range between trips to the gas station. That's up 40 miles from the previous model.

The 2016 Chevrolet Volt has a 20 percent larger battery pack (which lives under the floor near the center of the car) and a more powerful, yet lighter gasoline engine. The car as a whole weighs 200 pounds less than the outgoing model, a good thing if you're interested in fuel economy—and surely you are, if you're considering the Volt. It also has more space in the back seat—you can even seat five now, but only in a pinch. The Volt isn't luxurious inside, but it's comfortable, and you can geek out on the mileage and fuel economy details on readouts. A steering wheel paddle switch called Regen on Demand increases the Volt's battery regeneration to extend electric range.
The 2016 Volt has limited availability; for a full nationwide rollout, you'll wait until the 2017 model year, Chevrolet says.

More about the 2016 Chevrolet Volt

For a full report, see our October 7, 2015, review of the 2016 Chevrolet Volt Premier.

pageElements.text:

Price range: $28,090 – $41,085
Trim levels: WT, LS, LT, LT Z71, LTZ, LTZ Z71, High Country
Engines: 4.3-liter V-6, 285 horsepower; 5.3-liter V-8, 355 horsepower; 6.2-liter V-8, 420 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic, eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/24 mpg highway (4.3-liter V-6); 16/23 mpg (5.3-liter V-6); 15/21 mpg (6.2-liter V-8)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good in moderate overlap front test; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: OnStar with Directions and Connections
Notable standard features on this model: Locking tailgate, seven-inch touchscreen with Chevrolet MyLink (except base model)
Notable options on this model: Enhanced Driver Alert Package (includes lane-keeping assist, forward collision alert, front adn rear park assist, safety alert seat); 12,000-pound maximum trailering capability with Max Trailering package ($2,140)
You might also be considering: Ford F-150, GMC Sierra, Ram 1500

Shopping for a pickup truck is one of the most complex of pursuits, with the variety of engine sizes, body types, seating configurations, bed lengths, and towing packages. The full-size truck market is highly competitive, with Chevrolet fans and those who favor another brand. If Chevrolet is your brand, and you are in the market for a full-size truck, you already have a clear idea of your needs. The Silverado lineup can satisfy them, no matter what they are, with a regular-cab model with a standard or long truck box; a double-cab model with a short box; or a crew cab with either short or standard box length. You can also get the Silverado with rear- or all-wheel drive and in a choice of seven trim levels. The base WT dresses up with a Black Out Edition this year ($1,595), which should appeal to young entry-level buyers with its 20-inch black-painted wheels, blacked-out grille surround, front bumper and grille, and even black Chevrolet bowtie emblems. At the opposite end of the price scale is the dressy High Country version, with its heated and ventilated leather seating, an eight-inch touchscreen with navigation, park assist, wireless phone charging, a remote locking tailgate, and chrome wheels and grille.

New for 2016:

Lighting changes: LED head- and taillights (LTZ, High Country); HID projector headlamps with LED signature (WT, LS, LT)
Grille design varies by model
Remote locking tailgate (optional) and power-articulating assist steps (optional on High Country)
Eight-speed automatic transmission (optional on 5.3-liter V-8 versions of LTZ and High Country)
New front designs with bold horizontal elements, sculpted hood and LED signature lighting Apple CarPlay and Android Auto capability
Wireless phone charging (on all models with front bucket seats)

title: 7 Ways to Thrive in a Traffic Jam
subTitle: Emerge victorious over the bottleneck, construction, or just overcrowded highway! Here's how.
promoTitle: 7 Ways to Thrive in a Traffic Jam
promoTeaserSmall: Emerge victorious over the bottleneck, construction, or just overcrowded highway! Here's how.
promoTeaser: Emerge victorious over the bottleneck, construction, or just overcrowded highway! Here's how.
keywords: 7 Ways to Thrive in a Traffic Jam
metaTitle: 7 Ways to Thrive in a Traffic Jam - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Emerge victorious over the bottleneck, construction, or just overcrowded highway! Here's how.

pageElements.text: These days, the cars, trucks, and SUVs we drive are more helpful than ever before. They can show us what is behind us or in our blind spot. They work with our smartphones so we can use maps and apps to our heart’s content. They have navigation systems that will get us from Point A to Point B and even find a restaurant along the way. And yet, one thing they can’t provide is a smooth, lightly traveled roadway whenever we want one. In a traffic snarl, you need your wits about you. Here are our top seven tips for ways to conquer the all-too-common traffic jam. Please share your own ideas!

1. Make sure your car is ready for what might happen. This starts with keeping an eye on the gas tank and not letting your fuel level get too low. In winter, this is even more important, but you don’t want to be stuck on the freeway for hours or unexpectedly sent on an obscure detour when you have an eighth of a tank. And while we’re at it, have something to eat and drink in the car at all times, just in case you spend a lot longer out on the road than you planned. Your passengers will be much more pleasant company, and so will you.

2. Know your terrain; don’t have turn-by-turn tunnel vision. Regular commuters in traffic-heavy areas have this one down pat, but it works for anyone. Don’t just count on Google or your car’s nav system to tell you when to turn left and right; figure out the roads you plan to take, but also understand some potential alternate routes. You might even consider (gasp) having old-fashioned paper maps in the car.

3. Use your car’s technology to help you, not take over for you. We are big fans of active safety technology—things like blind spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert. If you’re lucky enough to have one of the growing number of new cars with adaptive cruise control with stop-and-go capability, you’re in luck next time you hit a traffic slowdown. This technology uses radar sensors to watch the road ahead of you and will adjust your car’s speed automatically in line with what the traffic ahead is doing, often at speeds all the way down to 0 mph, saving your right leg from that constant dance between the brake and the accelerator. The Audi A6 and up, BMW 5 Series and up, and the Tesla Model S are some of the vehicles that offer this kind of intelligent cruise control. Whether or not you have this kind of help, it’s up to you to drive the car and keep a safe following distance as traffic patterns change for the worse or better. Which leads us to the next item on our list:

4. Be a mentally present, focused driver, even when traffic is stop-and-go—or stopped. We have seen alarming advice to get out the phone to send texts, or even to read a book, when you’re stuck in stopped traffic. Say what? Don’t do it. Hang up and drive the car, because truly long-time stopped traffic is rare, and you don’t know when it will start and stop.
Pick your lane and stay with it. You’ll get where you are going just as quickly and without endangering your nerves or the other cars in line.

5. Don’t bob and weave. When traffic does start—and stop, and start again, over and over—avoid the urge to jackrabbit your way through it, impatiently weaving from lane to lane. Pick your lane and stay with it. You’ll get where you are going just as quickly and without endangering your nerves or the other cars in line. A famous study using computer simulations and referencing the notoriously clogged roads of metropolitan Toronto proved that it’s not true that drivers in the next lane are getting there quicker than you are.

6. Look behind you. Okay, so you are watching the cars in front of you, the exit coming up, the lane changers all around you. The most important thing to watch out for? The person behind you, who for all you know is texting or eating an egg-salad sandwich and isn’t realizing that traffic is about to stop. Be predictable so that driver can respond appropriately. Always leave space between your car and the one in front, and put on your brake lights in time for the car behind you to react. If a stoppage is sudden and unexpected, put your emergency flashers on to really give the guy behind you a heads-up. Be prepared to aim for the shoulder if the car behind you doesn't look like it's going to stop.
Google Maps' handy “Typical Traffic” predictor that inspects your planned route, then tells you how heavy traffic is expected to be by days of the week and times of day.

7. Expect and plan for delays, and if they come, keep your wits about you. Apps, the best-known of which are Waze and INRIX, are available for Android and iOS phones for free, and they’ll estimate travel time as well as alert you to tie-ups on your chosen route. Even if you have no advance warning of trouble, you should always give yourself extra time to get where you’re going, especially at the holidays when everyone’s out on the road—and in bad weather, when traffic snarls are extra dangerous. Choose a time of day that’s least likely to offer up a traffic jam. (Google Maps will help you, with its handy “Typical Traffic” predictor that inspects your planned route, then tells you how heavy traffic is expected to be on different days of the week and times of day.) Plan enough time to take bathroom, food, and rest breaks, if the route is long. In short, do everything you can to anticipate bottlenecks, be ready for them, and not let them stress you out. Because you know there’s already enough stress this time of year.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear-wheel-drive luxury sport sedan
Base price: $85,990 (prices include destination charge and $1,000 gas guzzler tax)
This car: $91,690
Engine: Supercharged 6.2-liter V-8, 640 horsepower, 630 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic transmission with launch control, performance algorithm shifting, and paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 14 mpg city/21 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good in four categories, Marginal in small overlap front test
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Audi S6 $76,225
2015 BMW M5 $99,595
2015 Mercedes-AMG E63S Sedan $102,625
Fun-O-Meter: 9

The 2016 Cadillac CTS-V has finally done what no American luxury car has been able to do since, well, since Cadillac did it once before, back when the Earth’s crust was cooling. In this watershed year for the General Motors brand, the CTS-V has taken on the greatest luxury performance-car nameplates in a very American fashion, with all the horsepower (640) you could hope for and a top speed (200 mph) that you wouldn’t have dreamed of from a Cadillac.

Cadillac has been wandering in the wilderness for virtually my entire lifetime as an automotive journalist. Back in the mid-1980s, Braz Pryor was a tall, funny, silver-haired Texan who had the unenviable position as Cadillac’s general sales manager. Between an onslaught of sleek European luxury cars and debilitating GM strikes, Cadillac had fallen, and it couldn’t seem to get up. Pryor had a great way of making light of the relentless aging of the Cadillac customer base, almost perfectly in lockstep with the aging of the Cadillac dealer base.

“I know this Cadillac dealer down in Texas who has a shoebox full of cards on all his customers,” he told me. “Every year, he’d get out that shoebox and call everyone on those cards and remind them that they hadn’t bought a new Cadillac in a year, and that’s how he’d make his sales. He told me last week, ‘Braz, the older I get, the fewer cards I have in the box. I sure hope I die before those cards run out!’ ”

He had another story about a car dealer in New Orleans. “He put up this big old billboard with a Cadillac hearse on it, and a sign above it that said, ‘You’ll be riding in one someday, why not buy one today!’ ”

Somehow, Cadillac limped through those tough times (remember the ill-conceived V-6 Cimarron?) but didn’t really find its mojo until a sparky young Cadillac marketing executive named Kim Kosak used Led Zeppelin’s “Rock and Roll” anthem to back the first CTS commercial at the 2003 Super Bowl. Hearing Robert Plant shriek “been a long time” gave me goosebumps and made my hair stand on end. And I wasn’t the only one. That ad ramped up Cadillac sales 16 percent that year. The way was paved in gold for the CTS-V. And it had a manual transmission.

About the only thing the 2016 Cadillac CTS-V does not have in its arsenal of overachieving performance equipment is a manual transmission. What it does have is an eight-speed automatic that you can shift with magnesium paddle shifters. Boom! Welcome to 21st century high-performance driving.

The heart of the car is the Chevrolet Corvette Z06’s powertrain, a massive beast of a V-8 with 640 horsepower and 630 pound-feet of torque. It’s supercharged, not turbocharged. The difference is that the power boost comes the minute you step on the accelerator; no waiting for the exhaust to fire up a turbocharger. There are no words left that haven’t been used up by every red-blooded enthusiast journalist who has tested this car. Of course, they’ve all tested it on a racetrack, because that’s what this car is all about. Not that that’s a bad thing. For red-blooded enthusiast journalists.

The CTS-V has suspension settings that go from Touring to Sport to Track to Snow/Ice. Going down the road, I found the car to be so uncomfortable in Touring mode that I bumped it up to Sport mode, which battened down the suspension settings and reset the shift points to bring it closer to track ready. To signal the change, the tachometer display went from black to white. In Sport, the CTS-V was much more comfortable in its own skin. As a longtime speed demon, it’s hard for me to resist this car in Sport mode, when it is completely devoted to delivering perfectly precise steering, killer braking, and...speed.
After reading this, you may question why the Fun-O-Meter is at 9 and not 10. That’s because there’s something “not my car” about this car.

But I can’t drive like that out on the road every day. After reading this, you may question why the Fun-O-Meter is at 9 and not 10. That’s because there’s something “not my car” about this car. There’s something incongruous about this very American sedan. From the outside, it looks exactly as you would expect it to drive. You see that shovel-nosed front end of the car that’s unique to the V version of the CTS, and all the sharp, mean edges to the design, and the vertical blades of the lights front and rear, all of which says this car is going to be a handful.

There is no doubt I loved driving the CTS-V, but I didn’t necessarily enjoy being inside it. I have to admit I prefer a little more run silent, run deep when it comes to high performance and luxury. I really like to drive hard and fast, but most of the time, I like the European style of high-end luxury when it comes to clothing, furniture, shoes—and cars. Especially when they’re made in America.

The interior of the CTS-V is conflicted. European cars have not only inspired Cadillac to achieve performance greatness; they have inspired well-heeled people who love performance to aspire to European standards of low-key taste and style and to eschew showiness. Alcantara and suede, muted colors, and perforated leather are the standard of luxury these days, and the CTS-V has all of that. But from the driver’s seat, the view is anti-Germanic: shiny and celebratory in a way that is also distinctly American, all piano black and brightly colored dials splashed across the Cadillac’s dashboard. You might call it vulgar in a nice way, proudly stating its Americanness in a way that many people won’t like.

The CTS-V I tested had the optional Recaro high-performance seats ($2,300). If you’re going to use the launch control—the ultimate boy-racer thrill, which allows you maximum acceleration from a dead stop while managing wheel spin—you might as well spring for the seats. Another racing-oriented option is the Performance Data Recorder ($1,300), which measures your awesome track times. Just pointing out that a reality check could save you $3,600.

Maybe I’d like the CTS-V’s interior better if the Cue infotainment system was easier to use; although it has improved, it is still a little idiosyncratic and fiddly. The problem with it is information overload, with so many choices presented that take your eyes off the road. You can ameliorate the situation by reconfiguring the dashboard screen in front of your face to bring in some of the touchscreen functions. Another good thing is Cadillac’s exceptional voice recognition system, which removed a lot of my Cue angst by allowing me to direct most of the things I wanted to happen by just telling it to do so. By the way, the system is redeemed by offering the absolute best voice-activated navigation system on the market—something that you can also find on more affordable GM products, like the 2016 Chevy Impala.

One extra-cost item I am in favor of is the Red Obsession Tintcoat for an additional $500. This is really one of the best paint jobs I have ever seen on a car. Every time I walked up to the CTS-V, I actually stroked the hood. By the way, that hood is a big, expensive expanse of carbon fiber.

I can see the track-oriented items being an option, but I can’t see why some other things are. Our test car included a Luxury package ($1,600), which added a split-folding rear seat, a sunshade, heated rear seats, a 110-volt power outlet, and tri-zone climate control. These should all should be standard, in my humble opinion, given the $85,990 price of the car before options. To be fair, the CTS-V is massively loaded, but why the $1,600 squeeze? That’s a whole lot of nickels and dimes.

In the real world, do you really need 640 horsepower and a 200-mph top speed? Do you need launch control, race-car plumbing, the big Brembo performance brakes—or a gas-guzzler tax—in your daily life? Not to be heretical or anything, but here’s the deal. Cadillac needed to make this car more than most people will need to access its full capabilities, because they have suffered for nearly three decades from being a luxury dinosaur while the Europeans have come in with cars of extraordinary performance wrapped in the most exquisitely tasteful packages.
Bravo, GM and Cadillac! You kicked Europe’s ass under the hood, and for $10,000 less than most of its head-to-head competitors.

Bravo, GM and Cadillac! You kicked Europe’s ass under the hood, and for $10,000 less than most of its head-to-head competitors. With the Z06’s parts bin at its disposal, Cadillac had exactly what it needed to get the brand back out in front.  Now that the question of need is settled, it’s a matter of want. Before you answer that, you should take one for a spin.

title: The Year at Jean Knows Cars
subTitle: Celebrating One Entire Year of Jean Knows Cars in Chelsea, Michigan! And More...
promoTitle: The Year at Jean Knows Cars
promoTeaserSmall: Celebrating One Entire Year of Jean Knows Cars in Chelsea, Michigan! And More...
promoTeaser: Celebrating One Entire Year of Jean Knows Cars in Chelsea, Michigan! And More...
keywords: The Year at Jean Knows Cars
metaTitle: The Year at Jean Knows Cars - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Celebrating One Entire Year of Jean Knows Cars in Chelsea, Michigan! And More...

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Jean Knows Cars, with backing from mighty Tribune Publishing, moved into 318 North Main, a 1915 annex to Chelsea’s historic Clocktower, in January 2015. We’d been working out of a Panera restaurant, a local Ann Arbor vegan restaurant called Seva, Molly Jean’s kitchen table, and Laura Sky Brown’s kitchen table for several months, so it was a Big Deal. We had no time to celebrate. In fact, we’d just thoroughly covered the North American International Auto Show in Detroit, and were thrilled to finally have a home. We worked on card tables until our desks arrived, and borrowed Wi-Fi for a month from Dr. Paula Koch’s Cherry Optometry next door to us until we bullied ATT for a microcell.
Howdy Holmes, former IndyCar driver and CEO of the towering Jiffy Mix mill across the street, called to say, well, “Howdy!”

Our property manager, Andy, hung my Soap Box Derby Car of Damocles from the ceiling above my head and declared us his “new hands-down favorite tenants.” We plugged in a coffeepot and hit the ground running, following the Detroit show with Chicago, Geneva, New York, and Los Angeles. We’ve published more than 100 car reviews and nearly fifty video reviews, including designer walkarounds of the most important new concepts at the major car shows.

We’ve flown more than 100,000 miles this year (and easily driven that many as well) to walk auto shows, to test drive new cars, to judge concours d'elegance (our new favorite is the Hilton Head Island Motoring Event), and to speak (to the students at McPherson College in Kansas, to women in Las Vegas at the SEMA Show, to diehard car fans in Chicago at Cooper Technica Restoration, among my favorites), and to visit old friends, including Dan and Evi Gurney at All-American Racers; Walker Evans, Parnelli Jones, and Linda Vaughn at the Motorsports Hall of Fame induction of Walker; and most important, my heroine, racing driver and extraordinary driver Denise McCluggage at her home in Santa Fe, three days before she passed away at the age of 88, leaving a void that will never be filled. I had to stop a moment before I wrote that.

If you’ve not noticed our three most recurring bylines, let me point you to the wit and wisdom of our executive editor, Laura Sky Brown. The quirky musings and excellent artistic eye of our creative director, Molly Jean. The erudite and deeply informed test drive analyses (aka Swan Drives) of our token “old car guy,” Tony Swan, former editor in chief of Motor Trend magazine. He has a 1954 Mercury sedan. What’s not to love?

Here are just a few of my favorite stories over the past difficult, glorious year:

Giving My Dogs a Day, Subaru Style
I imagine a dream vacation for each of my (spoiled) dogs.

Old Friends and a New Volkswagen
Between the Motorsports Hall of Fame party and Ford's new-tech meeting, I found time to buy a new car.

Jean's Driveway: 2016 Nissan Maxima SR
The newest version of the four-door sports car was worth the wait.

Car Repair? How to Talk to the Shop
Five ways to tell the service department what's wrong with your car in terms they'll understand.

6 Things to Never Ever Do in a Car
You don't do any of these things. Right?

5 Reasons to Spring for Winter Tires
If it gets below freezing where you live, consider putting winter tires on your vehicle. Here’s why.

Pro/Con: Roundabout or 4-Way Stop?
Molly and the experts approve of roundabouts. Laura prefers a four-way stop. Whose side are you on?
Now. What are you missing? Yearning for? Sick of? Need desperately? Please write. We read every email.
Happy New Year! Share the joy, aim for the light.

Love,
Jean

Happy one-year birthday to Jean Knows Cars in its new Chelsea home.

pageElements.text:
2016 Chevrolet Impala 2LTZ
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive full-size sedan
Base price: $27,970 (base LS model); $36,365 (2LTZ)
This car: $39,825
Engine: 3.6-liter V-6, 305 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/29 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good in two areas, Superior in front crash prevention
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Hyundai Azera ($34,995)
2016 Nissan Maxima ($33,245)
2016 Toyota Avalon ($33,845)

Fun-O-Meter:  8

The 2016 Chevrolet Impala may have completely evaded your attention as you shopped for a new full-size car. Such an easy car to ignore. As a nameplate, Impala has been around since Eisenhower. It fell off the face of the earth pretty much from 1990 until it was totally redesigned for the tenth time, in 2013, as a 2014 model. And it has been a long time since the Impala’s looks evoked the sleek animal for which it was named.

But don’t walk past this one without a closer look. The exterior of the 2016 is the 2014 Impala, true enough, and there is still beauty in its elegance, simplicity, and proportion. The creases along the big sedan’s shoulder add tension and reduce visual mass, and the upper has a laid-back sweep that feeds into the Impala’s high tail and bulged rear wheel arches. The only part of this look that is dated at all are the now prosaic front and rear lights, a hot area for experimentation with light “signatures” among the world’s most fashionable car designers. Chevy might do something there while waiting for the next ground-up redesign, expected in 2017.

There have been few, but good, upgrades to the 2016 Impala that will help keep it fresh until then. Most noticeable on our black-over-jet-black Impala LTZ test car was the Midnight Edition package ($1,195), offered for the first time on the LTZ, a cool blackout treatment that includes a black rear spoiler, blackwall tires on black nineteen-inch wheels (twenty-inchers are also available), and a sinister black bowtie front and back.
The Impala LTZ’s cabin is equally up to date. Leather is in abundance, on seats, across the dash and doors, and wrapping the steering wheel.

The Impala LTZ’s cabin is equally up to date. Leather is in abundance, on seats, across the dash and doors, and wrapping the steering wheel. A mix of materials and surfacing give it a rich, upscale feel. Front seats can be heated or cooled.

An asymmetrical dash wraps around the driver, presenting information and controls clearly and cleanly. A center stack holds the excellent eight-inch MyLink touchscreen display, operated with swipe and click to access information. There are also old-fashioned pushbuttons and rotary switches grouped below the screen for quick radio and climate control. This is not the cockpit of a fighter jet. There are no vast banks of tiny switches lighting up the night. There are, however, a couple of whimsical teal light bar swoops to keep you company. It is enough.

As in all Chevrolets, the voice recognition is exceptional, making phone calls quickly with virtually no false starts, and allowing navigation commands while you’re driving, asking for the complete address all at once and then providing directions, instead of engaging you in some dysfunctional relationship where you find yourself shouting, “No! No! That’s not what I said!” into thin air. At no one.

After joining the bulk of Chevy’s line-up last year with three months of free 4G LTE Wi-Fi, the Impala now has Apple CarPlay, the ultimate in connectivity—seamless, hands-free connection to your phone, your contacts, your music, maps, and some of your favorite apps, presented in a super eight-inch MyLink touchscreen display. An AndroidAuto software update appears in March for seven and eight-inch MyLink screens. (While we’re singing praise, let’s not forget OnStar, one of the pioneers of connectivity.)

Icing on the cake: a wireless charging pad, although my ridiculously massive year-old iPhone 6 Plus is too big to fit the pad. Not that I’m whining. This could be my excuse to buy the much cooler 6S. Meanwhile, there are device ports galore, from USB to an Aux input, and a couple of 12V outlets to boot.

Last year, Chevy discontinued the mild hybrid version, leaving two gasoline engines, a 2.5-liter four-cylinder (with a new start-stop feature that helped push its EPA highway rating to 31 mpg) and lovely 305-horsepower 3.6-liter V-6, both with a six-speed automatic transmission. There are still three trim levels—LS, 1LT, 2LT, 1LTZ, and 2LTZ.  The number “1” indicates the four-cylinder, and “2” signifies the V-6.

I can’t imagine driving a full-size sedan with a four, not when this V-6 is so robust, with best in class horsepower. It is such an easy car to drive, with an engine that responds instantly when you ask for more power, and at any speed. It sounds much better than a four-cylinder, too. And I can’t imagine owning any Impala but the 2LTZ, the only level that has rearview camera and rear park assist, Rear Cross-Traffic Alert, Lane Departure Warning, and blind spot alert as a basic suite of standard safety features.

The 2016 Impala is still a power player in its class, the sign of its good bones and a smart product team, which knew exactly how the pieces—a powerful V-6 engine, an excellent six-speed automatic transmission, strong brakes, precise steering, a well-sorted suspension, and a magic-carpet ride—were supposed to go together.

Someone on this team also knew that if the fuel economy of the V-6 wasn’t going to do better than 19 mpg city/29 mpg highway, than it would need that 18.5-gallon fuel tank to make up for (or at least mask) the fuel economy deficit with range.
How great it was to spend time in a car that put nothing irksome in my face. No wall of impossible-to-read buttons. No clunky voice interface pretending to be high tech.

The first time I drove the Impala, I was charmed. I felt immediately at ease behind the wheel. What an easy, pleasant car, I thought. And then I immediately thought what a simpleton I was. And then I went back to thinking how great it was to spend time in a car that put nothing whatsoever irksome in my face. No wall of impossible to read buttons. No clunky voice interface, pretending to be high-tech. When you step on the gas, the Impala goes. When you step on the brakes, it stops on a dime. Nothing too crazy about it. Really nicely done. I can see any number of drivers who are not pretentious but do appreciate being treated with respect in terms of what they want and need, liking this Impala a lot.

I’m betting that plenty of you will, too. And if you don’t need Apple CarPlay or wireless phone charging, if you don’t care about the black bowties, you might save yourself some money on a 2015 Impala 2LTZ still hanging around the lot with everything you need and looking just as sharp.

title: 5 Cool Things from the Consumer Electronics Show
subTitle: Our new favorites from BMW, Cadillac, Ford, Volkswagen, Volvo, and their tech partners.
promoTitle: 5 Cool Things from the Consumer Electronics Show
promoTeaserSmall: Our new favorites from BMW, Cadillac, Ford, Volkswagen, Volvo, and their tech partners.
promoTeaser: Our new favorites from BMW, Cadillac, Ford, Volkswagen, Volvo, and their tech partners.
keywords: 5 Cool Things from the Consumer Electronics Show
metaTitle: 5 Cool Things from the Consumer Electronics Show - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Our new favorites from BMW, Cadillac, Ford, Volkswagen, Volvo, and their tech partners.

pageElements.text: Good news if you like lots of technology with your new car. Maybe your very next vehicle purchase won't have the kind of smartphone-integrating, autonomous-enabled, gesture-recognizing technology these manufacturers are showing off—but maybe it will, and there's little doubt we'll all find ourselves in cars featuring this tech eventually. Here are our five favorite new developments from the humongous Consumer Electronics Show, happening this week in Las Vegas.

1. Better Connectivity from Ford.
Ford, following in the footsteps of General Motors, is going to put 4G LTE wireless on board, but its better idea is making it free for five years. Ford’s already much improved Sync system becomes Sync Connect on the 2017 Escape, coming out this spring, and will be rolled out to the full lineup after that. You’ll be able to use Sync Connect to remotely lock, unlock, and start your vehicle from anywhere, locate your parked car on a map, and look up fuel, battery, and tire pressure information, all from your smartphone. Ford targets getting Sync Connect in more than 10 million Fords worldwide by the end of the decade.
Imagine a highway full of autonomous cars with their occupants sitting back watching their favorite TV shows in high definition," Volvo's Anders Tylman says.

2. Volvo Says, Sit Back and Watch a Movie.
A show like CES is an occasion to reflect about the future. Is it possible, as the latest study from McKinsey projects, that the future will see autonomous vehicles in the majority, leading to daytime car sharing on a massive scale and cutting down the urban traffic scene by 80 percent? No more parking lots filled with stationary cars? Volvo has an intriguing project with Ericsson known as Intelligent Media Streaming. It will deliver interruption-free, high-definition video while your car drives you. "Imagine a highway full of autonomous cars with their occupants sitting back watching their favorite TV shows in high definition," Volvo's Anders Tylman says. We'll leave it to you to decide if that's a dream or a nightmare. And Volvo is planning public-road trials of autonomous vehicles in the next few years, so it's probably coming sooner than you think.

3. Delphi Connects Your Vehicle to Everything, Starting with a Cadillac.
Meanwhile, powerhouse automotive supplier Delphi is focusing on communication between your car and its environment, with its V2E technology (which stands for Vehicle to Everything). Delphi's automated vehicle at CES is showing off its combination of radar, smartphone chips, and short-range communication technology to tell your car when pedestrians are chatting on smartphones and about to walk into your path, anticipate when a light is about to turn yellow or red, and alert you when someone's about to change lanes. It will even tell your friends and family where your vehicle is so they can ask you for a ride—assuming that's something you want, of course.

If you want to see this on a real car, Delphi's vehicle-to-vehicle technology is coming out on the 2017 Cadillac CTS as Super Cruise, which will be capable of limited autonomous operation. (Here's more about this and other forms of "smart" cruise control.)

4. BMW Re-Envisions the Rearview Mirror and Gives Your Hands New Power.
This whole camera thing is reaching its logical conclusion now, as the BMW i8 is appearing at CES without any mirrors, only cameras. No more blind spots! Plus, the system will warn you if the cameras spot an approaching danger. Images from three cameras are combined on a display where you'd expect a rearview mirror to be. Meanwhile, the smaller i3 gets a slightly more conventional setup that adds images from a roof-mounted camera to the rearview mirror.

Still more intriguing is Air Touch, which will let you wave your hands meaningfully to make things happen—meaning you can use the features of your touchscreen without actually reaching over and touching anything. This is an expansion on the Gesture Control already available on the BMW 7 Series.


At CES, BMW showed AirTouch on a good-looking concept, the i Vision Future Interaction, with a high-resolution twenty-one-inch panoramic display that recognizes movement. There's lots more interesting technology on board, including three selectable drive modes to take you from Pure Drive (what we'd call normal), through Assist (active safety features) to Auto Mode.

5. Volkswagen and Others Point to an Affordable EV Future.
Volkswagen announced the all-electric, 373-mile-range Budd-E at CES on Tuesday. With a large 101-kWh battery and some up-to-the-minute tech features including gesture control and Smart Home connectivity, it's not your hippie great-aunt's VW Microbus, yet in styling and feel, it kind of is.

At 181 inches in length, it's bigger than the Golf and more the size of a Chevrolet Cruze or a Toyota Corolla. You've got to love the way the information display is organized, into Drive, Control, and Consume sections. What else is there, after all? VW has promised "a new era" of affordable long-distance range, which starts with the Budd-E, and it sure looks appealing.

Meanwhile, the subcompact 2017 Chevrolet Bolt EV, first seen at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit last year, is making its production debut at CES, and Chinese-backed startup Faraday is reportedly introducing a 1,000-horsepower electric car concept during the show. So, whether you're going for electric technology for reasons of nostalgia, economics, or Tesla envy, CES has something worth looking at this year.

See our related story: 5 Cool Things from the Consumer Electronics Show (CES)

title: Kia Launches Self-Driving-Car Brand
subTitle: If you still doubt that autonomous driving is coming, the Drive Wise initiative should convince you.
promoTeaserSmall: If you still doubt that autonomous driving is coming, the Drive Wise initiative should convince you.
promoTeaser: If you still doubt that autonomous driving is coming, the Drive Wise initiative should convince you.
metaDescription: If you still doubt that autonomous driving is coming, the Drive Wise initiative should convince you.

pageElements.text: Do you believe in the autonomous car? There's one company that clearly does: Kia has just announced it's launching the dedicated Drive Wise sub-brand, with a $2 billion investment, to develop and roll out self-driving cars. That was the announcement at CES in Las Vegas this week, and Kia has obtained permission to road-test autonomous Kia Soul EV cars in Nevada. Next up will be partially autonomous cars, going into production by decade's end, and then the first fully self-driving Kia in the showrooms by 2030.
The Emergency Stop System, or ESS, will pull your car over to the side of the road and stop if it feels you aren't paying close enough attention to the road. Hmm.

This sounds a little...gradual, but Kia's Drive Wise sub-brand has big plans. At CES, the Korean automaker is showing both highway and urban autonomous driving technologies, using radar, camera, GPS, and sensors to let the vehicle operate with driver input or without it. A really fascinating one is the Emergency Stop System, or ESS, which will pull your car over to the side of the road and stop if it feels you aren't paying close enough attention to the road. Hmm. Enhanced lane keeping (Kia calls it Preceding Vehicle Following, or PVF) lets the car calculate its path relative to the vehicle in front, even when road markings aren't visible. There's more, but how about this: Autonomous Valet Parking. Just get out of the car and let it park itself remotely. Human-to-vehicle communication will be improved with gesture recognition and the car's ability to recognize each individual driver by fingerprint or smartwatch, and set up their favorite music, preferred temperature, and instrument panel settings. Kia demonstrated this part at CES with an i-Cockpit simulator display, pointing out how useful it will be to change settings while driving without needing to take your eyes off the road.

These driver assistance systems aren't too far afield from technology being developed and rolled out by many automakers around the world. What's exciting about this is how far it brings automated-vehicle R&D into the mainstream. Kia intends to put this technology in place across its lineup.

See our related story: Kia's New Self-Driving-Car Brand

Kia put this I-Cockpit simulator out for testing at CES.
Valet parking becomes autonomous using a smartwatch as controller.
Kia Soul EV, self driving, a harbinger of Kia's autonomous-car future.
With the Kia Soul EV testing Drive Wise technology.
