title: 2016 Dodge Viper
subTitle: Detroit exotic.
promoTeaserSmall: Detroit exotic.
promoTeaser: Detroit exotic.
metaDescription: Detroit exotic.

pageElements.text:
Type: Two-passenger, rear-wheel-drive sport coupe
Price range: $92,490 – $123,390 (prices include gas guzzler tax and destination charge)
Trim levels: SRT, GT, GTS, ACR, GTC
Engine: 8.4-liter V-10, 645 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 12 mpg city/21 mpg highway
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA): Not rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS): Not rated
Notable standard features: Chrysler Uconnect infotainment with 8.4-inch touchscreen, three-mode electronic stability control, rearview camera, 12-speaker Harman Kardon audio system
Notable options: Driver-selectable two-mode suspension, including Bilstein shock absorbers with Street and Track settings; five-mode Electronic Stability Control System with launch control
You might also be considering: Audi R8, Chevrolet Corvette, Porsche 911

The Dodge Viper, built in Detroit and now in its fifth generation, is a very particular kind of car for a very particular buyer. It's a high-performance car, a head turner, ready for the track but good for street use as well. If you're shopping in the $100,000 region, it will return that investment with 645 horsepower and an analog speedometer that reads up to 220 mph. The Viper is highly customizable. Wheels, exterior packages featuring lots and lots of carbon fiber, a variety of Brembo brake choices, and several Sabelt leather seating levels are among the ways you can make yours feel individual. For an even wider personalization portfolio, the new GTC Viper is claimed to be available in more than 25 million unique combinations of features and add-ons including custom stripes, hand-painted exterior colors, interior trims, suspension choices, and aerodynamics packages. These "1 of 1 Viper" models will also get a personalized badge on the instrument panel.

New for 2016

Matte paint is now available on every trim level.
American Club Racer (ACR) model is back (it was last sold in 2010 model year); billed as the fastest street-legal Viper track car yet.
Viper ACR gets carbon-ceramic brakes and specially designed high-performance tires; optional Extreme Aero package ($6,000) adds an adjustable carbon fiber rear wing that provides almost a ton of peak downforce at maximum speed, plus a red carbon fiber diffuser, a special SRT hood with removable louvers, and more.

More about the Viper

Manual-Transmission Cars You Can Buy Now July 22, 2015

title: Mitsubishi Focusing on Crossovers
subTitle: By adding a third crossover and EV versions, Mitsubishi makes its way back up the ladder of success.
promoTeaserSmall: By adding a third crossover and EV versions, Mitsubishi makes its way back up the ladder of success.
promoTeaser: By adding a third crossover and EV versions, Mitsubishi makes its way back up the ladder of success.
metaDescription: By adding a third crossover and EV versions, Mitsubishi makes its way back up the ladder of success.

pageElements.text: Things looked very rosy for Mitsubishi once...back in 2002, its peak year in the United States. By six years later, the automaker saw sales dive by 80 percent. But Mitusubishi thinks it has the formula to succeed again: focusing on crossovers and committing to electric vehicles.

"We're going to be laser focused on the CUV," said Ken Konieczka, Mitsubishi's North American sales chief, at an event in Detroit this week. That was made clear by fresh new versions of the seven-passenger Outlander and five-passenger Outlander Sport, which rolled out in mid-2015. So far, the approach appears to be working, with the company showing its first operating profit in seven years, and a 23 percent increase in year-over-year sales. This has been a good year for auto sales in general, but still, you can see why Mitsubishi is optimistic about its chances.

In Detroit on Thursday, Mitsubishi showed off the 2017 Outlander PHEV, a battery-electric version of the big crossover that has already been successful in Europe. It's expected to go on sale by late summer here after making its debut at the New York Auto Show in the spring. Reps for the automaker had very few details about the U.S. version—such as price, fuel economy, range—but a quick look at the European model's specs is encouraging. It boasts thirty-two miles of electric-only range, and 541 combined miles between fill-ups. Compare that with the 2016 Chevrolet Volt, which offers a fifty-three-mile all-electric range and 420 miles between fill-ups. What the Outlander loses in its transition to plug-in hybrid status is its third row of seats. The batteries take up that space, and it becomes a five-seater.
The Outlander is getting bigger, longer, and wider in 2019; Outlander Sport will be smaller in 2020, with an EV variant. An all-new crossover will fit in between.

The Outlander PHEV will go on sale in the United States in late summer, at the same time as the 2017 Outlander and Outlander Sport. Since we know, now, that crossovers are going to be so important to Mitsubishi's future, it's good to know that the Outlander is getting bigger, longer, and wider, starting with the 2019 model year, while the Outlander Sport is getting smaller as of the 2020 model year and will have an all-electric version. That leaves room for an all-new crossover in early 2018 that sits between the two. It was previewed in the electric eX Concept shown here, which was introduced at the 2015 Tokyo Auto Show.

images.caption: Mitsubishi eX Concept from 2015 Tokyo Auto Show.

title: 7 Things to Look for at Detroit
subTitle: Concepts and production cars we're looking forward to from Acura, Volvo, Chrysler, and more.
promoTitle: 7 Things to Look for at Detroit
promoTeaserSmall: Concepts and production cars we're looking forward to from Acura, Volvo, Chrysler, and more.
promoTeaser: Concepts and production cars we're looking forward to from Acura, Volvo, Chrysler, and more.
keywords: 7 Things to Look for at Detroit
metaTitle: 7 Things to Look for at Detroit Auto Show - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Concepts and production cars we're looking forward to from Acura, Volvo, Chrysler, and more.

pageElements.text:
1. Acura Precision Concept
The upscale Honda division has been showing off this teaser photo since December, part of a 2016 plan that includes the launch of an all-new NSX in the spring. This one, though, is more Integra than supercar. It's intended to signal what the next generation of performance/luxury sedans will look like.

2. 2017 Chrysler Town & Country
It's not the end of the minivan, no matter what the plethora of crossovers on your local streets is telling you. In fact, an all-new version of the minivan that started it all is coming from Chrysler. The 2017 Town & Country will be the sixth generation of the classic family carrier. Details will be out before breakfast on Monday morning, but meanwhile, it's expected to have one of those foot-operated door openers for the side and rear doors, and it's also expected to go on sale in the second quarter of the year.

3. 2017 Honda Ridgeline
For mid-size-pickup buyers, the Ridgeline was unconventional-looking. According to the partial view here, it won't be anymore when the 2017 model makes its debut in Detroit next week. In place of the somewhat odd-looking unit body, the new Ridgeline appears to be more traditional-looking. It will be interesting to see how it performs against the popular competitors from General Motors, the Chevrolet Colorado and GMC Canyon.

4. Kia Telluride Concept
A little more soul from the maker of the Soul seems to be coming with this sport-utility vehicle concept. The teaser image of the concept, which was developed in Kia's California design facility, looks squarish and muscular. Kia released an image of an all-digital dashboard on Friday along with the concept's name. It's going to have some of the latest active safety features. That lines up with Kia's just-announced Drive Wise sub-brand initiative, which aims at getting semi-autonomous cars into the showroom within a few years.
It also gets 3D-printed components on the dashboard, steering wheel, and door panels and "health and wellness technology" in the cabin. Take your blood pressure while you drive?

5. 2017 Lincoln Continental
It has been fifteen years since the last Lincoln Continental rolled American roads, but the Continental Concept (pictured) shown at the New York Auto Show last spring made it clear that it's coming back. At Detroit next week, the big Continental sedan will make its debut, reportedly with a twin-turbo V-6 engine and enough plush luxury to appeal to both American buyers and the important China market.

6. Lexus LC500
The follow-up to the LF-FC Concept (pictured here) shown at the Tokyo Auto Show this fall, this LC is a high-end, V-8-powered luxury coupe to compete against the Mercedes-Benz SL and its ilk. Expect it to be gorgeous, with an ultramodern drivetrain and a high price.

7. 2017 Volvo S90
Volvo is going full speed ahead into autonomous and semi-autonomous driving features, and this all-new big sedan is no exception. Although Volvo design chief Thomas Ingenlath acknowledges that S90 buyers are in a "rather conservative segment," this is an innovative car. It will have plug-in hybrid power and Pilot Assist, which manages your steering to keep the car in its lane at speeds up to 80 mph. More than that, it is marking the world debut of large animal detection, which can spot animals such as horses and moose, or more likely in North America, deer, that might get out in front of your vehicle.

title: 5 Ways Your Car Will Do More for You
subTitle: The Consumer Electronics Show showcased tons of tech that will bring self-driving and connected cars into the showroom. Here are our five favorites.
promoTitle: 5 Ways Your Car Will Do More for You
promoTeaserSmall: The Consumer Electronics Show showcased tons of tech that will bring self-driving and connected cars into the showroom. Here are our five favorites.
promoTeaser: The Consumer Electronics Show showcased tons of tech that will bring self-driving and connected cars into the showroom. Here are our five favorites.
keywords: 5 Ways Your Car Will Do More for You
metaTitle: 5 Ways Your Car Will Do More for You - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The Consumer Electronics Show showcased tons of tech that will bring self-driving and connected cars into the showroom. Here are our five favorites.

pageElements.text: How do you feel about self-driving cars? How about using your smartphone to control your car? Much of the new technology is in its infancy, but you’d better get ready: it’s all coming to your local showroom eventually. With it, you’ll be offered more and better safety features, more ability to personalize your time in the car, and more ways to control and manage your driving experience.

At this week’s Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas, the world’s biggest technology showcase was full of announcements of autonomous technology and connectivity features for cars. Here are our five favorites, from five different car companies and their technology partners. Which one will touch your life first? You might be surprised.

image.altText: Kia Soul EV Autonomous Valet Parking

pageElements.text:
1. Kia: Self-Driving Cars that Valet Park Themselves.
Kia has just announced it's launching the Drive Wise sub-brand, with a $2 billion investment, to develop and roll out self-driving cars. Kia has obtained permission to road-test autonomous Kia Soul EV cars in Nevada. Next up will be partially autonomous cars on sale by decade's end, and fully self-driving Kias in the showroom by 2030.

At CES, the Korean automaker is showing both highway and urban autonomous driving tech, using radar, camera, GPS, and sensors to run the car safely with driver input or without it. The Emergency Stop System will pull your car over to the side of the road and stop if it feels you aren't paying close enough attention to the road. There's more, but how about this: Autonomous Valet Parking. Just get out of the car and let it park itself remotely, using your smartphone. No tips required.

2. Ford and Amazon: Talk to Your Car.
Did you get Amazon.com’s Echo home automation device for a gift this year? Millions did. This cylindrical computer’s voice is Alexa, who listens and obeys your commands to play music, adjust lights, and look things up for you at home. Ford announced it’s partnering with Amazon to make it work with your future Ford vehicle. Using it, you’ll be able to start your car remotely and get the heat going, as well as set temperature, seat control, and entertainment features, all using voice controls, before you even get in.

Ford will start giving you greater connectivity options with Sync Connect this spring on the 2017 Escape SUV, and soon afterward to the full lineup. It will let you remotely lock, unlock, and start your vehicle from anywhere, locate your parked car on a map, and look up fuel, battery, and tire pressure information, all from your smartphone. Ford targets getting Sync Connect in more than 10 million Fords worldwide by the end of the decade.

3. BMW: A Simple Swipe of the Hand; No Need to Touch.
You probably make hand gestures occasionally while driving. Now there’s Air Touch from BMW. It will let you wave your hands meaningfully to make things happen—meaning you can use the features of your touchscreen without the distraction of reaching over, finding a control, and touching it. This is an expansion of the Gesture Control feature already available on the BMW 7 Series.

At CES, BMW showed AirTouch on the i Vision Future Interaction, a concept car with a high-resolution twenty-one-inch panoramic display that recognizes hand movement. There's lots more interesting technology on board, including three selectable drive modes to take you from Pure Drive (what we'd call normal), through Assist (active safety features) to Auto Mode. Yes, the self-driving BMW is coming eventually.

4. General Motors: Your First Self-Driving Car May Be a Ride Share
Lyft, a ride-sharing service that often takes a back seat to the more famous Uber, made its own headlines this week as GM announced a long-term partnership. GM will be spending $500 million toward building a network of self-driving cars you can order up with your smartphone. GM chairman Mary Barra announced that the 2017 Chevrolet Bolt, an all-new electric car, will have the smartphone technology on board to make it a centerpiece of this ride-sharing plan. Intriguing! For its part, Lyft will build a network of autonomous cars, while GM will set up national rental hubs where Lyft drivers can pick up non-autonomous vehicles to drive for pay. That’s right, the vision is that eventually you’ll be able to do everything from commuting to earning cash as a driver yourself, all without owning your own car.

5. Volvo: High-Def Video While the Car Drives You
Volvo has an intriguing project with Ericsson known as Intelligent Media Streaming. It will deliver interruption-free, high-definition video that you can watch as the car pilots itself down the road. You’ll even be able to choose from a customized menu of available shows, tailored by length to how much autonomous-driving time the car offers on your commute. "Imagine a highway full of autonomous cars with their occupants sitting back watching their favorite TV shows in high definition," Volvo's Anders Tylman says. We'll leave it to you to decide if that's a dream or a nightmare. And Volvo is planning a major public-road trial of autonomous vehicles in 2017, so it's probably coming sooner than you think.

images.caption: Kia Soul EV autonomous valet parking
General Motors President Dan Ammann (center) with Lyft Inc. co-founders John Zimmer (right) and Logan Green (left)

title: Buick Avista Concept
subTitle: As the jewel of a coupe made its debut, we met the guys behind that Dark Sapphire Jewel paint job.
promoTeaserSmall: As the jewel of a coupe made its debut, we met the guys behind that Dark Sapphire Jewel paint job.
promoTeaser: As the jewel of a coupe made its debut, we met the guys behind that Dark Sapphire Jewel paint job.
metaDescription: As the jewel of a coupe made its debut, we met the guys behind that Dark Sapphire Jewel paint job.

pageElements.text:
Type: 2+2-passenger, rear-wheel-drive sport coupe concept
Engine: Twin-turbocharged 3.0-liter V-6, 400 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
What's most interesting: Flowing center console, elegant lines

General Motors design chief Ed Welburn had good reason to be smiling as he introduced the Buick Avista concept, which was a bit of a surprise introduction at the GM division's event in Detroit's Eastern Market on Sunday night. For the second year in a row, Buick was showing off an extremely attractive concept—last year, it was the Avenir, which led to the all-new LaCrosse that goes on sale this summer. This year, it's the gorgeous Avista two-plus-two sport coupe, powered by a twin-turbo engine, that captured all the attention.

The Dark Jewel Sapphire paint color set off the sinuous lines of the Avista to great effect. Jean took one look and called that color "candy blue." We were lucky enough to shake the hands of the actual guys who made it happen: Matt Ayers and Gene Guenther, a pair of experimental laboratory paint technicians from the GM Tech Center's color design department. They and David Bolognino, director of GM Design Fabrication, told us about the creative process involved in creating a show-ready paint job. "It's a one-off special color," Ayers told us, mixed to the specifications of Sharon Gauci, Buick's director of design for global color and trim. Ayers and Guenther spent hundreds of hours preparing and thirteen hours painting the Avista concept, and that hard work definitely paid off.
The Avista concept shows off some of the luxury features a Buick might be expected to carry, such as ionic air purifiers, aromatherapy, and noise cancellation technology.

The Avista concept shows off some of the luxury features a Buick might be expected to carry, such as ionic air purifiers, aromatherapy, and noise cancellation technology. The swoopy center console has "a future vision" of the already good IntelliLink infotainment system with a wide screen and touch controls.The door and seat trim have 3D-printed elements. The powertrain also features cylinder deactivation and stop/start technology to save fuel.  But the twin-turbocharged V-6 engine and magnetic ride control show the sporting aspirations for this luxury concept.

Buick also showed the 2017 Envision premium crossover, which is intended to sit between the compact Encore and the mid-size Enclave. Buick sold 147,000 Envision vehicles in China last year, and since the Encore and Enclave make up 60 percent of U.S. Buick sales, it makes sense for the Envision to come here, too.

Two more Buicks on display in Detroit will reach dealers this year. First, the Cascada convertible, which made its debut at Detroit a year ago, will reach dealers within the next few weeks. Buick global sales chief Duncan Aldred noted that dealers have already requested ten times the initial production run of the Cascada before a single one has been delivered. The 2017 LaCrosse goes on sale this summer. Altogether, Buick will have seven new or revised models on sale by 2018.

images.caption: GM design chief Ed Welburn with the Avista concept.
The team behind that great paint job.

title: 2017 Chevrolet Cruze and Bolt
subTitle: Two small wonders get a Detroit introduction.
promoTeaserSmall: Two small wonders get a Detroit introduction.
promoTeaser: Two small wonders get a Detroit introduction.
metaDescription: Two small wonders get a Detroit introduction.

pageElements.text:
2017 Chevrolet Cruze Hatchback

Type: Five-passenger, five-door front-wheel-drive compact hatchback
Release date: Fall 2016
Estimated price range: Starting under $20,000
Competes against: Ford Focus, Honda Civic, Mazda 3
What's most interesting: Good cargo space (42 cubic feet) with rear seat folded
The North American International Auto Show had good news for small-car fans when Chevrolet rolled out both the 2017 Chevrolet Cruze hatchback and the all-electric 2017 Chevrolet Bolt.

The Cruze Hatch, as they're calling it, is the same size as the sedan but gets wraparound taillights and an attractive roof spoiler on the liftgate. A chief advantage, other than cuteness, is that you can make use of 42 cubic feet of storage capacity once you fold the rear seat. (There's 18.5 feet with the seat in place.)

Global Chevrolet brand chief Alan Batey pointed out that Chevrolet sells a lot of Cruzes. It's their bestselling passenger car worldwise, with some 3.8 million sold, and particularly valuable in that a third of Cruze buyers are new to the Chevrolet brand. He also points out that small hatchbacks have seen a nine percent uptick in the past year. So it is a logical move to bring a hatchback version to the U.S. market, like the one Ford already has in the Focus.

It's a stylish move as well, and many viewers (this one included) are likely to prefer the rakish good looks of the Cruze Hatch over the sedan version. Prices weren't announced, but there will be LT, Premier, and sporty RS versions of the hatchback.  Among the desirable features are stop/start technology for fuel savings, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, and a turbocharged 1.4-liter four-cylinder engine as standard. Options include heated seats and steering wheel, LED signature lighting, a Teen Driver feature that lets you monitor your child's driving, and active safety features including lane keeping assist, side blind zone alert, rear cross-traffic alert, and park assist.

2017 Chevrolet Bolt

Type: Five-passenger, four-door front-wheel-drive compact electric sedan
Release date:Late 2016
Estimated price range: $30,000 after federal tax credits
Competes against: Ford C-Max Energi, Nissan Leaf
What's most interesting: 200 miles of range on a charge

You knew the Bolt was coming—it made a splashy debut at last year's Detroit auto show, and the 2017 production model was shown at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas several days ago. It was still important for General Motors chairman Mary Barra to appear in Detroit and introduce the electric car, which is tipped to sell for about $37,000, which will be reduced to around $30,000 after federal subsidies. And speaking of impressive numbers, how about 200 horsepower, 200 miles on a charge, 0 to 60 mph in under seven seconds? (A full charge will take nine hours using the standard on-board charger and a 240-volt outlet, while you can charge enough to get 90 miles of range in a half-hour, Barra said.)

The styling is that of a compact (very compact) crossover, featuring SUV-style tall seating positions. What about the room for batteries in such a small car? you ask, and you should. In the Bolt, the battery pack is flat and mounted under the floor, there's 94 cubic feet of passenger room. That's roughly the same as the Honda Fit, a car often praised for its roominess inside.

Apple CarPlay and Android Auto are on board, as is a 10.2-inch touchscreen infotainment system. Among the available features are a bird's-eye surround-view camera and a wide-angle rearview mirror camera, other features that put us in mind of the Honda Fit. We're really looking forward to trying this out once it goes into production near the end of the year.

title: 2017 Chrysler Pacifica
subTitle: FCA shows its deep respect for the family-car buyer with an all-new minivan that actually looks good.
promoTeaserSmall: FCA shows deep respect for the family-car buyer with an all-new minivan that actually looks good.
promoTeaser: FCA shows deep respect for the family-car buyer with an all-new minivan that actually looks good.
metaDescription: FCA shows its deep respect for the family-car buyer with an all-new minivan that actually looks good.

pageElements.text:
Type: Eight-passenger, front-wheel-drive minivan
Release date: Spring 2016; Pacifica Hybrid: late 2016
Estimated price range: Not yet announced
Trim levels:LX, Touring, Touring-L, Touring-L Plus, Limited, Limited Platinum
Competes against: Honda Odyssey, Kia Sedona
What's most interesting: The fact that there's an eight-passenger hybrid version


If you're one of those people who scoff at the minivan, your scoffing days might be over now. Chrysler, the original minivan maker from way back in 1984, has introduced nothing less than a whole new way of looking at this family-friendly vehicle. It seats eight full-size people, it comes in a hybrid version that will go thirty miles on electric power alone, and it's equipped with a 3.6-liter V-6 engine and a nine-speed automatic transmission, yielding 28 mpg on the highway for the non-hybrid model and 80 MPGe for the hybrid.

Plus, just look at it. The Pacifica recycles a name that used to belong to a crossover that was sold in the mid-2000s, but it is the new Town & Country, only much better. It's twice as stiff as the outgoing minivan, while losing 250 pounds and adding active noise cancellation. It has crossover-like good looks and mega-minivan practicality. It also has a full complement of active safety features.

There's a new Uconnect Theater entertainment system with an 8.4-inch touchscreen in front and a pair of ten-inch rear-seat touchscreens so your back-seat riders can watch movies or play built-in games or stream Internet content.
The killer app for me is the kid-friendly animated navigation. This is going to amaze and amuse kids and their parents on a large scale. What a great idea.

The Stow 'n Go seating gets a redesign—it has been around for a decade, so it was time—and now features an Assist feature that moves the front seat up while you're trying to fold down the second-row seat, then puts the front seat back in place. Hands-free doors and a liftgate that opens when you kick under the bumper doors are now offered, and there's an integrated vacuum cleaner, in imitation of the Honda Odyssey's HondaVac.

More than 14 million people have owned a Chrysler minivan since 1984, and I will admit to having been one of them, back in the day. Chrysler's passenger-car chief, Tim Kuniskis, told media at the Detroit auto show press conference that this new Pacifica is "the future of the Chrysler brand" and urged us to "forget everything" we've heard about the minivan in the past. I actually think it's easier to like the modernized silhouette and new features of the 2017 Pacific if you remember the old minivans, both for their excellent practicality and for some of the things that needed to be modernized.

title: NAIAS: 2017 Honda Ridgeline
subTitle: An inspiring survival story comes to Detroit.
promoTeaserSmall: An inspiring survival story comes to Detroit.
promoTeaser: An inspiring survival story comes to Detroit.
metaDescription: An inspiring survival story comes to Detroit.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-engine, all-wheel-drive mid-size pickup truck
Release date: Early summer 2016
Estimated price range: $30,000 - $39,000
Competes against: Chevrolet Colorado, GMC Canyon, Nissan Frontier, Toyota Tacoma

Here’s a rare survival story. Unveiled at the 2005 Detroit show, the Ridgeline was hailed for its innovation—a pickup truck on a front-drive unitbody chassis that traced its lineage to the Odyssey minivan and Pilot SUV. However, critical acclaim didn’t translate into sales, and Honda pulled the plug on production in 2014.

But the Ridgeline is back, and the second generation will begin appearing in showrooms next summer as a 2017 model. Aside from hard core pickup truckers who viewed the unitbody design as heresy, the biggest rap against the original Ridgeline was its unique styling. The new truck addresses that with a much more conventional look, although it continues to defy pickup convention with its foundations, shared with the new Pilot. It also shares the Pilot’s 280-hp 3.5-liter V-6 engine, a 30-horsepower boost over the first generation.

Whether the new engine will address the biggest complaint of first gen owners—fuel economy—remains to be seen. The previous Ridgeline had a five-speed transmission, whereas the new one will likely mirror the Pilot’s choice of six- and nine-speeds, as well as the new all-wheel drive system.

While the look is more conventional, with a bigger cargo bed and the biggest front end logo ever to adorn a Honda, the Ridgeline retains two of its unconventional—and most popular—features: its two-way tailgate and lockable in-bed trunk. Like fuel economy ratings, pricing remains to be seen, but we expect a base of about $30,000.

title: Kia Telluride Concept
subTitle: What is missing from the Kia lineup? Maybe this: a hybrid SUV with all-wheel drive and aromatherapy.
promoTeaserSmall: What is missing from the Kia lineup? Maybe this: a hybrid SUV with all-wheel drive and aromatherapy.
promoTeaser: What is missing from the Kia lineup? Maybe this: a hybrid SUV with all-wheel drive and aromatherapy.
metaDescription: What is missing from the Kia lineup? Maybe this: a hybrid SUV with all-wheel drive and aromatherapy.

pageElements.text:
Type: Seven-passenger, all-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle concept
Release date: N/A
Estimated price range: N/A
Competes against: Cadillac Escalade, Land Rover Range Rover, Mercedes-Benz GL-Class, Volvo XC90
What's most interesting: Commitment to passenger comfort

If there's any doubt that Kia Motors is expanding its lineup in an upscale direction, it should vanish for good with the appearance of this full-size SUV concept, which brings both a fresh look and a very American-focused approach to the Korean automaker's lineup.

The Telluride is 4.4 inches taller, 4.7 inches wider, and 9.5 inches longer than the Sorento. At 196.9 inches in overall length, it's about the size of the Range Rover or the Lexus GX and a few inches shorter than the Mercedes-Benz GL-Class and Chevrolet Tahoe. The Telluride has full-time all-wheel drive and a combined 400 horsepower from the 3.5-liter V-6 and electric motor, or would if there were plans for production, which Kia says there aren't at this time.

Kia did briefly market a large SUV in the U.S., the Borrego, in 2009, but discontinued sales after a year in favor of an all-new Sorento, making its debut in 2011 with an optional third row. This concept, though, is unabashedly for the luxury-SUV buyer who would be shopping for Lexus, Mercedes, and Range Rover products. It has a set of four black leather captain's chairs, each with smart sensors to capture and display health information on their occupants. Those in the second row have folding footrests and therapeutic lighting "to improve the passengers' energy levels." They also have Swipe Command so they can scroll through media choices and make selections by swiping their hands. Those in the third row are not so lucky: they get a bench seat. Another interesting feature is the 3D-printed cabin materials, a technique that's sure to become more common as the technology improves.

Kia's commitment to forward-looking technology was made evident earlier this week, with the launch of the Drive Wise sub-brand. This program intends to put semi-autonomous safety technology throughout the Kia product line, culminating in autonomous Kias within a decade or so. Kia's ambitious future plans are also likely to include some version of this upscale SUV. As the automaker said in Detroit, "This is anything but a utopian fantasy."

title: 2016 Lexus RX350
subTitle: Taking chances with the breadwinner.
promoTeaserSmall: Taking chances with the breadwinner.
promoTeaser: Taking chances with the breadwinner.
metaDescription: Taking chances with the breadwinner.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive luxury crossover
Trim levels: RX350, RX350 F Sport
Base price: $43,800 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $54,755
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 295 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 20 mpg city/28 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Audi Q5 Premium ($40,900)
2016 BMW X3 sDrive 28i ($39,945)
2016 Lincoln MKX ($39,185)
2016 Mercedes-Benz GLC300 ($40,800)
Fun-O-Meter: 5

It’s possible that you will never get used to the look of the 2016 Lexus RX350. The side profile looks like it was in a sword fight. The way the sheetmetal wraps around that crazy front spindle grille looks like Darth Vader’s helmet, held in the grip of a stag beetle’s mandibles. The floating roof (an optical illusion where the C-pillar is blacked out so the roof panel appears to be floating above the glass) works better on the Nissan Murano, but I like it. Overall, though, you could say that the all-new fourth-generation RX350 is a work of origami that does not turn the sheetmetal into a swan, but I admit that after a week on the road with one, I became fond of its polarizing design.

The RX has been paying Lexus’s light bills from its beginning in 1998. It is the perfect size, has always had a juicy V-6, and offered the right luxury sensibility at a reasonably competitive price. Worldwide sales of the RX have topped 2.2 million. The hybrid RX400h, launched in 2005 as the first hybrid Lexus model, distinguished itself by accounting for well over half of all Lexus hybrids sold by the end of 2012. The RX is everywhere. Everywhere.

You have to admit, it’s an astonishing move for Lexus to give its breadwinner such a polarizing face. But it’s clearly in line with what Toyota chairman Akio Toyoda wants to accomplish with Lexus: to move it upmarket from Toyota and make it something special. Mission accomplished on the design. You’re either going to love it or hate it, but you’ll definitely have a strong opinion.

The interior is another story altogether. It’s stunningly beautiful, luxurious in a Danish furniture kind of way. The horizontal dash layout that has been rolled out in Toyota and Lexus models for the past few years in this car is a layering of exquisite leather, sweeps of satin-finish metal, and wide swaths of trim pieces that look like wood with aluminum pinstripes, but are actually laser-cut aluminum with inserts of sapele mahogany.

The chocolate-colored semi-aniline leather (which means it retains more of the natural grain of the leather) is edged in red stitching and used on all the touch surfaces, and it’s perforated on the seat surfaces. The seats in our loaded test car were heated and ventilated. I believe the only hard plastic surfaces I could hunt down were on the underside of the dash and the steering column.
During our week-long round trip from Michigan to New Orleans, the first thing noticed by every person who looked at our car was the massive 12.3-inch information screen.

During our week-long round trip from Michigan to New Orleans, the first thing noticed by every person who looked at our car was the massive 12.3-inch information screen floating in the center of the long dash. It. Is. Huge.

It is also beautiful and a welcome option, especially on a long road trip where navigation tends to become the center of your adventure. A map sprawled across the RX’s screen is nearly as big as an old-school paper map. It’s so big and clear, you can pretty much  catch every direction it maps out with just the farthest corner of your right eyeball.

Voice recognition wasn’t fond of my Midwestern accent, which forced me once or twice to pull over and pick through the digital keypad and spell out my destination. Hated that. The mouse-style controller on the center console was jumpier than I remember, although its “haptic” feedback is pretty strong. The base of the controller has a redundant switch on each side to enter commands instead of pressing the mouse.

The center console also holds a double cup holder. You can put a tall, deep cup in each of them, but it will swallow a little cup unless you hit the PUSH button, which raises the floor inside one of the cupholders up like a little tiny dumbwaiter.

The rear seats are 60/40 one-touch folding, which I love. We flipped down the left passenger’s seat and packed everything we owned in the cargo hold, optimistically leaving the right rear (heated) seat open so that I could lounge back there and watch movies using the Bluetooth headphones that come with each of the massive 11.6-inch headrest-mounted rear screens while my husband drove.
Never happened. Someday I’m going to be a back-seat passenger.

This car is as quiet as any Lexus I remember. When you put the windows up and down at a stop, you have to visually check that the windows are going up and down; that’s how quiet it was. I loved the one-touch panoramic roof, and the overhead light switches, which are as close to proximity touch as you can be. It knows you’re coming, and you don’t have to search for it. Just get your hand up anywhere on that surface and the light goes on. Other features include rain-sensing wipers and keyless entry, which is as sensitive as the overhead light switches. Put your hand through the door handle, and it unlocks. It’s a beautiful thing when you never have to take your key out. On the other hand, waving your hand past the Lexus logo on the hatch produces the slowest power-opening moment in existence. Soooo slow.

The Lexus Safety System Plus was an option package, priced at $635 on our model. (You can also get the safety package with adaptive front lights for $1,050, or with LED headlamps for $2,250.) Basic Safety System Plus includes four features: intelligent high beam, lane departure alert with steering assist, pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, and all-speed dynamic radar cruise control. I have come kicking and screaming to smart cruise control, but I prefer it for heavy traffic, not the long-distance interstate cruise. You can switch to fixed-speed cruise control in the RX, but you have to cycle through the ignition to return to the dynamic radar cruise control mode.

A long trip like this showed off the lovely pairing of 295-horsepower V-6 engine and eight-speed automatic transmission. Driving to Louisiana through Kentucky and Tennessee was an opportunity to drive on hilly roads, which we don’t have a lot of in Michigan. The eight-speed automatic shifts more than I’m used to because of the hills, but the shifts were seamless, clean and quick, almost unnoticeable. (You have to watch the tach needle.)
We averaged 22.2 mpg on the long trip from Michigan to Louisiana and back, going 70 to 80 mph. The 19.2-gallon fuel tank was the minimum size you’d want for a long trip.

Unfortunately, all that driving did nothing to improve the RX’s reputation for having uninterested steering feel, numb handling, and excessive body motions over rough roads and through turns.

There are three drive modes: Eco, Normal, and Sport. I went right for Sport the minute I realized that in Normal and Eco modes, the handling requires constant peripheral attention with firm hands on the wheel. It’s like keeping a slightly wayward child in line. This is a vehicle that needs a little more attention than most people want to pay on a long-distance drive. In Sport mode, it settles down, but the ride is still a little floaty.

Sport mode was acceptable, but Normal was not. The problem is, every time you turn the car on and off, it reverts to Normal mode. Then you remember that it doesn’t ride the way you’d like, and you have to reset it to Sport mode. There is an F Sport version of the RX350, with standard all-wheel drive, but I haven’t driven it yet, so the jury’s out.

The hedonist in me says the RX350 brings a lot to love, the world’s most beautiful nav screen at the top of my list. The materials used in the cabin and the craftsmanship exhibited are exquisite. And despite being more pricey than some formidable competitors, the RX scores points for its dramatic new presence.
But it’s going to need to push that Fun-O-Meter up a couple of notches to win me over. Maybe I will find it all in the F Sport.

subTitle: You may see more SUVs than cars on the road, but sedans and coupes dominated at the Detroit show.

pageElements.text:
Every year, Detroit’s auto show is an eagerly anticipated bright spot in the grayness of Michigan in January. This year’s media preview was a tiny bit less glittery in that several luxury brands—Bentley, Jaguar Land Rover, Maserati, Rolls-Royce, and Tesla—chose not to participate. In their place, the attention was grabbed by some new models that may be less aspirational but are no less appealing.

The North American International Auto Show is open to the public Jan. 16-24. In the meantime, here are the eight introductions we found hardest to resist.
This chiseled coupe had the cheekbones of Cate Blanchett in the movie Carol and, for that matter, was painted in her cherry-red lipstick color.

1. Acura Precision Concept
This chiseled coupe had the cheekbones of Cate Blanchett in the movie Carol and, for that matter, was painted in her cherry-red lipstick color, but the Precision Concept had none of her icy cool. It was red hot. The Precision Concept is a four-door sedan that may look as expensive as the $150,000-plus NSX supercar, but it actually is the harbinger of the near future for Acura’s more consumer-friendly lineup. Design chief Dave Marek promised that the “diamond pentagon” grille treatment in particular is going to be seen sooner rather than later. Precision Crafted Performance is the Acura mission, and it’s a slogan that fits in this case.

2. Buick Avista Concept
This sensuous coupe was a bit of a surprise introduction at the GM division's event in Detroit's Eastern Market on Sunday night. For the second year in a row, Buick rolled out an extremely attractive concept—last year, it was the Avenir, which led to the all-new LaCrosse that goes on sale this summer. This year, it's the drop-dead gorgeous Avista two-plus-two sport coupe that captured all the attention, with its sexy sheetmetal shown to perfect advantage by a startling deep blue paint job. The Avista concept shows off some of the luxury features a Buick might be expected to carry, such as ionic air purifiers, aromatherapy, and noise cancellation technology. The swoopy center console has "a future vision" of the already good IntelliLink infotainment system with a wide screen and touch controls.The door and seat trim have 3D-printed elements. The powertrain also features cylinder deactivation and stop/start technology to save fuel. But the twin-turbocharged V-6 engine and magnetic ride control showed off sporting aspirations that seemed almost un-Buick-like.

3. 2017 Chevrolet Bolt EV
You knew the Bolt was coming—it made a splashy debut at last year's Detroit auto show, and the 2017 production model was shown at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas a week ago. It was still important for General Motors chairman Mary Barra to appear in Detroit and introduce the electric car, which is tipped to sell for about $37,000, reduced to around $30,000 after federal subsidies. And speaking of impressive numbers, how about 200 horsepower, 200 miles on a charge, 0 to 60 mph in under seven seconds? (A full charge will take nine hours using the standard on-board charger and a 240-volt outlet, while you can charge enough to get 90 miles of range in a half-hour, Barra said.) The styling is that of a compact (very compact) crossover, featuring SUV-style tall seating positions. Because the battery pack is flat and mounted under the floor, there's 94 cubic feet of passenger room. That's roughly the same as the Honda Fit, a car often praised for its roominess inside. Apple CarPlay and Android Auto are on board, as is a 10.2-inch touchscreen infotainment system. Among the available features are a bird's-eye surround-view camera and a wide-angle rearview mirror camera, other features that put us in mind of the Honda Fit. We're really looking forward to trying this out once it goes into production near the end of the year.

4. 2017 Chrysler Pacifica
It's not the end of the minivan, no matter what the plethora of crossovers on your local streets is telling you. In fact, this might be the start of a rebirth, now that we’ve seen the swoopy Pacifica, an all-new product that replaces the long-serving Chrysler minivan that started it all. We never agreed with people who made fun of “family haulers,” and this well-thought-out Pacifica shows that Fiat Chrysler Automobiles has as much respect for the family-car shopper as we do. The 3.6-liter V-6 engine makes 287 horsepower and is teamed with a nine-speed automatic transmission, yielding 28 mpg on the highway. A hybrid version comes out in the summer, promising 80 MPGe and 30 miles of range on electric power alone—not bad for a vehicle that seats eight. The pair of ten-inch fold-down screens, with Wi-Fi, will keep back-seat passengers happy, complete with a child-friendly “Are We There Yet?” navigation app. Just kick your foot under either rear sliding door or the back liftgate, and it will open for you, hands-free. There’s much more on the features list, and we predict strong interest from people who previously thought they wanted an SUV.
Honda is known for innovative packaging, and the Ridgeline is no exception: there’s a locking in-bed trunk, something only Honda has, plus an in-bed audio system.

5. 2017 Honda Ridgeline
It’s not like they were ever gone, but trucks are definitely back in style, as shown by the positive reception the mid-size Chevrolet Colorado and GMC Canyon pickups have received. Honda’s Ridgeline used to be a little odd-looking, but the all-new 2017 Ridgeline is much more traditional in appearance, even if it has a more carlike unit-body structure. The engine is a 3.5-liter V-6 that should make around the same 280 horsepower as in the Honda Pilot SUV. If you think the front half of the Ridgeline looks a lot like the new Pilot, that's because they are built on the same platform and share a lot of parts; in fact, they will be built at the same Alabama plant. Honda is known for innovative packaging, and the Ridgeline is no exception: there’s a locking in-bed trunk, something only Honda has, plus an in-bed audio system. It also has a bed that’s wide enough at 48 inches between wheel wells to allow a sheet of plywood to lay flat. The Ridgeline will be on sale by summer, just in time for picnics, tailgating, and of course construction projects.

6. 2017 Lexus LC500
The LC is a high-end, rear-wheel-drive, V-8-powered luxury coupe to compete against the Mercedes-Benz SL-Class and its ilk. It’s expected to go on sale in about a year’s time. To win over demanding shoppers in the premium luxury segment, the Lexus had to be a stunner, which it is, and powerful, which it also is, featuring a 5.0-liter V-8 making 467 horsepower and teamed with a new ten-speed automatic transmission. The LC500 reaches into sports-car territory with options like an active rear spoiler and a carbon fiber roof. The enormous mesh grille on this and other Lexus cars is a love-it-or-hate-it proposition, but on this car, it really works well. The LC500 was awarded Best Production Car and Best-Designed Interior by the prestigious EyesOn Design group at the Detroit show, selected by judges representing the cream of the automotive design community.

7. 2017 Lincoln Continental
It has been fifteen years since the last Lincoln Continental rolled on American roads. This all-new luxury sedan is intended to please not only the high-end U.S. market but also the chauffeur-loving customers in the important China market. The 2017 Continental is effortlessly elegant, albeit a bit sedate-looking. Its twin-turbocharged 3.0-liter V-6 engine makes 400 horsepower. Its seats, inspired by those on private jets, adjust to 30 settings and can be had with heating, cooling, and massage features. An optional Revel audio system (we tried it) makes the Continental into one of the world’s finest concert halls. And the Continental features what might be the most interesting use of LED lighting since Disney World: as you approach the car with your key, the LEDs begin to turn on in a hypnotic sequence, first the front, the taillights, then the headlamps, then to light up the pavement around the doors, then, subtly, in the interior. And check out the E-latch door handle, hidden almost imperceptibly into the body side below the windows. Jeeves-like and unobtrusive, just like the Continental. It goes on sale this fall.

8. 2017 Volvo S90
Volvo is going full speed ahead into autonomous and semi-autonomous driving features, and this all-new flagship sedan is no exception. Although Volvo design chief Thomas Ingenlath acknowledges that S90 buyers are in a "rather conservative segment," this new Volvo sedan is as innovative as it is pure in its design. It will have plug-in hybrid power and Pilot Assist, which manages your steering to keep the car in its lane at speeds up to 80 mph. More than that, it is marking the world debut of large animal detection, which can spot animals such as horses and moose, or more likely in North America, deer, that might get out in front of your vehicle. It will be available with front- or all-wheel drive, with a 240-horsepower turbocharged four-cylinder or a turbocharged and supercharged version making 316 horsepower. You read that right. No more Volvo V-6s or V-8s. A hybrid version is also coming. The S90 goes on sale in the summer.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive compact sport-utility vehicle
Trim levels: SL, SLE-1, SLE-2, SLT, Denali
Base price: $24,900 (SL, front-wheel drive) (prices include destination charge)
This car: $36,850
Engine: 3.6-liter V-6, 301 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 16 mpg city/23 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: 2016 Top Safety Pick
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Ford Escape Titanium AWD ($31,890)
2016 Hyundai Santa Fe Sport AWD ($27,595)
2016 Jeep Cherokee Limited 4x4 ($31,890)
2016 Mazda CX-5 Grand Touring AWD ($30,350)

Fun-O-Meter: 5

GMC, the General Motors division that brands itself as Professional Grade, can be excused for being a little hard around the edges. If you’re shopping for a GMC sport-utility vehicle, you probably know that already and are OK with it. From the Terrain—the smallest of the three SUVs in the GMC lineup—to the popular full-size Sierra pickup, GMC makes tall, boxy, chrome-laden, ruthlessly efficient work vehicles.

But GMC also appeals to upscale crossover buyers, including in the heavily competitive compact segment. The Terrain was first introduced in the 2010 model year and has been modestly upgraded for 2016. It’s the second most popular GMC vehicle after the Sierra pickup, and it also has the highest number of female buyers of any GMC product, at 44 percent. The Denali name is given to the top-end version of GMCs, and you’ll find a Denali version of the mid-size Acadia and full-size Yukon SUV as well as the Sierra pickup.

Therefore, the 2016 GMC Terrain Denali that I tested is the most luxurious Terrain model. If you’re expecting buttery leather and soft-touch surfaces, though, you should look elsewhere. The Terrain looks like a member of a truck lineup and feels like one.

The front end was redone for the 2016, with the freshened model making its debut at the 2015 New York Auto Show. A revised grille, LED daytime running lights, and C-shaped lower chrome trim were all added. Many of the changes for 2016 favor people who want to buy a mid-range model rather than spring for the Denali. The SLE and SLT models add several cosmetic upgrades, including an optional Saddle Up leather interior on the SLT, premium cloth interior now standard on the SLE, and chrome-accented grilles for SLE and SLT.

The standard engine on the Terrain is a 2.4-liter four-cylinder, but I wouldn’t go there, even if it does claim better fuel economy, with the all-wheel-drive model getting 20 mpg in the city and 29 mpg on the highway. The Terrain Denali has the 3.6-liter V-6 with an EPA mpg rating of 16 city/23 highway, while making 301 horsepower. With it, you can tow up to 3,500 pounds. With either engine, you get a six-speed automatic transmission. Neither the V-6 engine nor transmission, however, could be called amusing.

I expected more from the V-6, but it didn’t much like the 4,200-plus pounds it was moving around, and the transmission huffed and puffed through the gears in a bit of a snit. It makes me anxious when I drive a vehicle with a cheesed-off powertrain that doesn’t much want to be there. We all feel better when we lose a little weight.
The Terrain is the second most popular GMC vehicle after the Sierra pickup, and it also has the highest number of female buyers of any GMC product, at 44 percent.

The interior is also a little disappointing, featuring a lot of hard plastic of different colors. The only softness comes from a leather pad on the dashboard, surrounded by hard plastic around the center console. There were some rough spots, notably a gaping space in the steering column sheathing around the adjustable steering wheel release knob. My searching fingers plunged right into the gap, and I thought a major piece of plastic trim was missing. But it wasn’t so. They might want to reconsider saving money in that particular area.

General Motors has a lot to offer in the connectivity/infotainment area, and the Terrain Denali is no exception. GM’s excellent IntelliLink infotainment screen comes with OnStar and 4G LTE that makes the Terrain into a wireless hot spot. I personally had trouble getting IntelliLink to understand my voice commands. The touchscreen feels far away, and the controls are hard to read, even in the daylight. A hood over the center screen shades it from glare, which is one saving grace.

The 2016 Terrain has keyless entry, but no push-button start. A programmable liftgate is also standard on the Denali, a feature that is very much appreciated by shorter people (I’m not one of those) because you can program how far up it opens to fit your garage or your arm reach. That’s available on the SLT model as an option.

Active safety features are something that crossover buyers will increasingly expect to have on board. The 2016 Terrain Denali, as the top Denali trim level, has a full set:  forward collision alert, lane departure warning, side blind zone alert, and rear cross-traffic alert are all standard. There’s also a standard rearview camera. The only one I truly noticed was the blind spot monitoring, which was not obtrusive. Side blind zone alert and rear cross-traffic alert are now options on SLE and SLT models.

GMC sold over 100,000 Terrain SUVs in 2015, which represented almost 20 percent of the division’s total sales. That’s still only about a third of the annual sales of the Ford Escape or the Honda CR-V, though.

This is an SUV that’s holding on another year until the big fabulous redesign. The 2016 Terrain is certainly acceptable, but it’s out of sync with the competitive set new-model cadence. I can come up with five small utes off the top of my head that are more modern, more fun to drive, and less expensive. So until the 2017 Terrain arrives (we’re hoping the rumors are true and it will be soon), make sure you do your homework and take your favorites for a test spin before deciding.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/64XIN09SzwA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

The previous Honda Ridgeline had its critics, especially those who didn't like the way the front end looked and the fact that it was a one-box vehicle. Honda took care of that with this all-new Ridgeline. You might recognize the look of the new Honda Pilot when you’re looking at the front. And at the back….what is that? As you can see in the video, there’s a very sharply designed crease between the cab and the truck bed that’s sleight of hand — a crease with a heavy black gasket pressed in behind it, which is totally a visual design device to make the truck look like it has a separate bed from the cab. It did make me raise one eyebrow when I realized that.

I’m one of the people who loved the old Ridgeline, so I didn’t need that black piece of rubber for my eyes to see it as more than a pickup truck. It doesn’t matter, anyway, whether this truck will appeal to the big-pickup-truck people, because that’s not their customer. Those people are going to buy a Ram, a GMC, or a Ford pickup. The Ridgeline is a play truck, not necessarily a work truck.

People may not have liked the old Ridgeline’s visual statement, but they liked everything else. And the 2017 Ridgeline still has all the cool things we liked about it. It has functionality for people who want a very light truck that will drive and handle well. And now, it conforms more to a traditional visual.

James Jenkins, Honda Trucks product planning manager, showed me the changes here on the Honda stand at the 2016 North American International Auto Show in Detroit.

Type: Five-passenger, front-engine, all-wheel-drive mid-size pickup truck
Release date: Early summer 2016
Estimated price range: $30,000 - $39,000
Competes against: Chevrolet Colorado, GMC Canyon, Nissan Frontier, Toyota Tacoma

pageElements.text:
I've known Ralph since he joined Chrysler, and to see his growth as a leader in the design community has been very gratifying. This has been recognized by Fiat Chrysler Automobiles; he was just promoted to the position of global design chief of the FCA Group, succeeding the formidable Lorenzo Ramaciotti.

One of the things I like most about Ralph is that he also really knows how to enjoy himself and his vehicles. He has a very large following on Twitter because he's out at tracks, he's driving Vipers at club events, in the woods Jeeping, or with Jay Leno doing an episode of Jay's show. All this and the auto show, too.

title: 9 Brightest Looks in Lights
subTitle: The traditional headlamp is an endangered species as light design becomes an essential part of the look of new vehicles.
promoTeaserSmall: At the North American International Auto Show, these were the headlight stylings we noticed most.
promoTeaser: At the North American International Auto Show, these were the headlight stylings we noticed most.
metaDescription: At the North American International Auto Show, these were the headlight stylings we noticed most.

pageElements.text: It’s so much fun to look at cars on the brightly lit stands of an auto show, and the Detroit show, happening right now, is no exception. It’s almost as much fun as watching cars go down the road—during the day, anyway. Recently, the trend toward LED headlamps and taillights has made car spotting almost as much fun at night. The headlamp design has become even more essential as part of the overall look and feel of a new vehicle, and that was very apparent in the new models on the show stand.

The North American International Auto Show is open to the public Jan. 16-24. President Obama was there on Jan. 20. If you can’t get there, or even if you can, enjoy our choices for the most interesting light treatments at the show.

1. Acura Precision Concept
Acura calls its front fascia design “Jewel Eye,” which is nowhere more apparent than in the Jewel Eye Constellation headlamps on this concept coupe. Can a car exude sex appeal in the dark? This one could.

2. Audi H-Tron Quattro Concept
The H-Tron Quattro appeared at Detroit as a showcase for autonomous driving technology that will show up on the next Audi A8, but also for lighting of the future. On this concept, it’s a full set of matrix laser organic LED (OLED) lights, the kind often used on large light displays. It breaks down the light into hundreds of thousands of pixels, giving you a high-resolution image of the road ahead but not blinding the people coming toward you. In back of the H-Tron concept, there’s a staggered layout of nine light units as taillights and three more units below. Matrix Laser OLED lighting is also used for instruments in the cockpit. Some of this is intended to make its way into upcoming production Audis. All very futuristic, but may we also compliment the horizontal lines on the headlamps and the way they carry the grille design all the way to the edges of the H-Tron.

3. 2016 BMW X5
The X5 SUV is an example of how BMW integrates up-to-the-minute lighting choices into its traditional front design with the double kidney-shaped grille and two pairs of round headlamps. That BMW look is now available 24 hours a day. Adaptive Xenon headlamps are standard, as on this top model, the xDrive 50i, and they’re surrounded by LED accent rings that are flat on the bottom and overlap at the top. LED front foglamps are standard, too. Optionally, you can get adaptive LED headlamps with automatic high beams, which dim automatically when a car is coming toward you. You can tell the difference by looking for horizontal lights in the center of the light rings on the LED version.

4. 2017 Cadillac XT5
One great thing about Cadillac’s current product lineup is its sense of fun. Not content to be cutting edge, which they are, these cars and SUVs have charisma and confidence, too. A little well-placed frivolity really adds excitement to a luxury vehicle, don’t you think? Witness the signature LED “light pipes” that make the front end pop on this all-new luxury crossover, by day or by night. Full LED headlamps are an option.

5. 2017 Chrysler Pacifica
Chrysler’s all-new take on the minivan features what the automaker is calling “face-of-Chrysler headlamps.” Their teardrop shapes undulate smoothly on either side of the grille, with the lower foglights as counterpoint. True to the functional personality of a minivan, rather than wearing dressy LED lights, they are high-intensity-discharge (HID) lamps that produce about three times as much light as traditional headlamps. LEDs serve as accents on the Pacifica, in the form of fog lamps and taillamps.

6. 2017 Genesis G90
Hyundai is nothing if not ambitious, and the Korean automaker has really gone for it by starting up its own high-end brand, Genesis. In place of the Hyundai Equus, the flagship now becomes the Genesis G90, and like the European and Japanese luxury sedans it’s squaring off against, it has LED headlamps as part of its design. The top V-8 model gets a full set of LED headlamps that compete with the massive grille for attention in front. Even more sparkling are the standard LED daytime running lights on the lower front. The back has vertical LEDs as well.

7. 2017 Infiniti Q60
Do these headlamps look like eyes to you? That’s intentional: they are “designed to emulate the shape of the human eyelid,” Infiniti says. Infiniti was going for an “in motion” look with this new sport coupe, and the LED headlamps help with that, featuring Light Guide technology that spreads the lighting evenly across the road as you drive. Blink!

8. 2017 Lincoln Continental
The headlamps on this ultra-luxurious sedan, along with the Lincoln-logo grille, are said to represent the future of Lincoln design, indicating a future that is clearly elegant but understated. They’re not the end of the LED drama, either. The “Lincoln Embrace” is the mood lighting that detects you’re approaching the car and turns on front and rear LED lights, the area around the front doors, and then the interior in a flowing, gradual progression. Classy.

9. Nissan Titan Warrior Concept
LED light design is for more than the luxury-sedan market. The boomerang-shaped LED headlamps are so important to the design of the Titan Warrior concept truck that they were the first part anyone saw, shining through the cover even before this off-roading design study was revealed at the Detroit auto show. The custom LED lights up front are joined by a set of integrated LED off-road lights on the roof.

pageElements.text:
The Telluride is a concept for a future full-size, three-row sport-utility vehicle. It brings a fresh look and a very American-focused approach to the Kia lineup. I walked around it with Kia's U.S. design chief, Tom Kearns, who, by the way, races motorcycles!

While filming, we ran into Kia vice-chairman Hank Lee, who was admiring the Telluride from the driver's seat. I encouraged him.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear-wheel-drive luxury sport sedan
Trim levels: ATS-V
Base price: $61,460 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $75,835
Engine: Twin-turbocharged 3.6-liter V-6, 464 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual with active rev matching and no-lift shift
Fuel economy: 16 mpg city/24 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Audi S4 Prestige ($57,975)
2016 BMW M3 ($64,495)
2016 Mercedes-AMG C63 S ($74,175)
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Cadillac’s current design language can be polarizing, but there’s no question that it’s distinctive. And the most distinctive are those in the high-performance V-series, like this ATS-V sedan I just tested. This is a personal sport sedan, which is a beautiful thing to live with.

I used the ATS-V to commute to the North American International Auto Show in Detroit last week, where I parked right downtown in front of hotels. Every time the valet would bring me my car, at least one person, if not two or three, on the street stopped to look at it and asked me, What is this Cadillac?

You can get the ATS-V for 2016 in either coupe or sedan versions. The twin-turbo engine and the choice of transmissions are also new for 2016. All of those are even more reasons to look at the ATS-V this year.

Let’s not mince words: the ATS-V looks hot. The little points on it make it look like a folded airplane. It hangs together front to rear because there’s not as much between the two ends as on the larger Cadillac CTS-V.
But enough about the looks. Let’s talk about that powertrain.

The 2016 Cadillac ATS-V features the highest-output V-6 in the segment—464 horsepower—and its engine is also notable for being the very first time Cadillac has turbocharged a V-series model. This turbocharger is exceptional. The power comes on instantaneously, there’s a big roar out the back, and it’s viscerally and emotionally rewarding. The monster Brembo brakes are rewarding, too.

The twin-turbocharged V-6 in the ATS-V is one of GM’s more modern engines, technologically speaking. The point of two turbos is that one overlaps the other, so when you step on the gas you don’t get lag. The smaller turbo spins up faster to bridge the gap until the second turbo kicks in, so you have the seamless delivery of power, and there’s a lot of it.

The ATS-V was so exciting to drive that, between the power of those two turbos and the noise coming out of the exhaust, I became the hooligan I really am, hitting the gas over and over again to hear a roar and feel myself get thrown back in the seat while the exhaust was booming behind me. Loved it.
When you’re not doing that, the car is perfectly behaved. You don’t feel like it’s anxious or edgy in any way.
Between the power of those two turbos and the noise coming out of the exhaust, I became the hooligan I really am, hitting the gas over and over again to hear a roar.

The transmission on the car I tested is an eight-speed automatic with beautiful long, slender magnesium paddles behind the spokes of the wheel. I don’t usually use paddles, but I loved using these because they feel like real controls, not some bastardized version or some push button. I found them very satisfying to use. While you’re driving, you can reach up with your fingers to up- or downshift, and it is a beautiful, instantaneous shift quality. Of course, I most enjoy downshifting, because that’s when the sound and the fury come together.

Having said that, I would have loved to have tested the ATS-V with the standard six-speed manual transmission with Active Rev Match, which makes you feel like a driving genius and makes your track day ever so much more exciting. That would have saved $2,000, the price of the optional automatic transmission. It also would have added no-lift shifting new for 2016, which means you can shift without trying to figure out your feet.

Even though you might not care about 0-to-60-mph times, in this car, it’s 3.9 seconds. That is lightning fast. That literally is a matter of, hit the gas and your head will be slammed right into the seat. The top speed of this car is 189 mph, which explains why everyone was collecting around it everywhere I parked. You can’t beat a car that’s still turning heads and causing people to stop on the sidewalk even though it has been on sale for months.

Having driven the bigger CTS-V recently— the first V-series in 2004—it was interesting to compare, and I found that everything about the design that seemed overwhelming on the CTS-V looks better on the ATS-V.

When I drove a regular CTS, I felt a little cramped, and yet the ATS feels perfect, because the ATS-V is very simple inside. The scale seems better, minus about 80 percent of the bells and whistles, but with all the fun. Including a track setting, by the way, should you be so inclined. And if you’re looking at the V, you probably are.

Everything that felt a little garish about the CTS-V is dialed down in the ATS-V. You still have the shiny piano black and red, white, and blue color graphics for the gauges and controls, but there’s a lot less of it.

Let me talk for a minute about Cadillac’s Cue infotainment system. General Motors already has the excellent IntelliLink system on its other vehicles. I know Cadillac wants to be more fabulous, but if the Chevrolet Spark has a better infotainment system, that’s a sad commentary.

Cadillac’s Cue looks slick, but it’s not so slick to use it, starting with an uncomfortable interface between finger and dashboard controls. I don’t know if I’m supposed to make things happen by  tapping on the screen, resting my finger on the tiny metal bar under the screen, or actually moving the bar. Controls that should be simple, like setting the temperature, will change so slowly, you always have to look at it to figure out what’s going on.

Some of this is probably my fault. The Cue system works better if I don't pound on it like I’m playing Rachmaninoff. The lightest touch, almost like a proximity sensor, works very well. I can be such an animal.

As for voice recognition, it went out four days into my test period, so I couldn’t make calls while driving. One of the problems with all these controls is that, when they don’t work, you don’t know if it’s user error or something more serious. In the end, the electronic gremlin in voice recognition was fixed the way we fix most electronic glitches--I shut the ignition off, then I turned it back on, and it started to work again.

I’m sure if I lived with this car long enough, I would learn what it took to make that thing work, but its lack of intuitive operation is a bit much. Carmakers need to take that seriously, not only to make things easier on their customers, but because non-intuitive controls can seriously affect J.D. Power and Consumer Reports scores. Cadillac should follow Ford’s lead, throw in the towel, and move on. After years of problems with its Sync system, Ford now has a great Sync 3. They figured out that it has to be simple and clear. Don’t reinvent the wheel.
The way the whole interior is put together is first-rate. Someone knows what they’re doing in the interior design department.

Now the rest of the interior: gorgeous. This ATS-V had great Recaro sport seats that match the exterior design vibe. The way the whole interior is put together, from the carbon fiber strips to the nappy black pig suede materials, is first-rate. Someone knows what they’re doing in the interior design department. The use of the materials exudes beautifully executed luxury. The seats evoke the exterior’s folded-airplane design, and they’re super comfortable and very supportive.

The Cadillac ATS-V we tested carried $14,000 worth of options. The reason the paddle shifters feel so good is that they’re magnesium, and they’re part of the eight-speed automatic $2,000 option that comes with adaptive remote start.

The $6,195 Track Performance package has little to do with actual performance. It has an extra, low-mass battery, and everything else in the package is about cutting weight. The package deletes floor mats, tire sealant and inflator kit, and a tow hook. It adds carbon fiber front splitter, air extractor, and rear diffuser, plus composite black rocker extensions and a body-color rear spoiler. None of that has anything to do with the engine or brakes; it’s a primarily visual package with two extra pieces that have something to do with lowering weight. The ATS-V does look awesome with this package, but I don’t know if it adds $6,200 worth of awesome. But if you’re spending $60,000 already….

As for the other options, the Recaro seats would be hard to give up, even though they are priced at $2,300. The spectacular Red Obsession Tintcoat paint job adds $995. The wheels are polished but have red Brembo calipers behind them, which is an extra $595 but it actually means something: not only are they really cool-looking in red, they’re the hottest brand of brakes that make the difference between performance and non-performance cars. A Corvette wouldn’t be caught dead without Brembo brakes.

Cadillac Cue with Bose surround sound and navigation adds $1,085. If you want nav, you have to get Cue. As everyone should know by now about GM products, the OnStar five-year basic plan is included as standard, and so is the 4G LTE hot spot with a limited data trial.

The Verdict

Between the ATS-V and the CTS-V, Cadillac really has something to take to the track and to the performance competition from Europe. The CTS-V is a little less comfortable to me on a day-to-day basis.

The first ATS was more of a Lincoln competitor, although it had BMW 3 Series aspirations, as do all cars in this class. Now, this ATS-V comes right nose to nose with it, and is the car you can take to your neighbor’s BMW M3 as a worthy competitor.
It draws Cadillac right alongside BMW M and Mercedes AMG, the first American car to do it. And it is an all-American car, right down to the graphics of its red, white, and blue gauges.

If you’re one of those people who think a BMW equals jerky stockbrokers on Wall Street, this is definitely your car. If you were considering a BMW, Audi, or Mercedes-Benz, make sure you look at this car. It has a much fresher design, an American feel, a powerful engine, and a highly attractive interior. This is America’s first true head-to-head competitor against the cars the car enthusiasts have been holding up as the bar.

How fun is this car? So satisfying that I hated giving it back. If you like a high-performance car, appreciate luxury, can afford it, and don’t want what everyone else is having; if you’re looking for the next cool thing? This is it.
