At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The Ford GT was a surprise (a very pleasant surprise) introduction at the 2015 North American International Auto Show in Detroit last year. At this year's show, the Ford stand featured the GT in white with a gorgeous interior that Amko Leenarts, Ford's global interior design chief, tells us about in this video.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/z8t3aKKtNyo?list=PLDtKaZSQcnJCZY-Ge8vAaMITVtB0ZsrMJ" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Orders haven't yet started, Ford tells us, but they will soon, and the GT is expected to be priced in the same stratosphere as the Lamborghini Aventador, which starts near $400,000.

Release date: Orders to start early 2016; first deliveries by end of 2016
Estimated price: $400,000
Engine: Twin-turbocharged 3.5-liter V-6, 600 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed dual-clutch automatic
What's most interesting: Orange-accented interior on 2016 Detroit show version

More to Read

title: 2015 Volkswagen Touareg
subTitle: A refined conservative.
promoTeaserSmall: A refined conservative.
promoTeaser: A refined conservative.
metaKeywords: 2015 Volkswagen Touareg; Volkswagen; VW; crossover; SUV; sport-utility; sport-ute; German
metaDescription: A refined conservative. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: SUV/crossover
Price range: $45,615–$67,905 (includes destination)
Trim levels: V-6, TDI, Hybrid
Engines: 3.6-liter V-6, 280 horsepower; 3.0-liter turbo-diesel V-6, 240 horsepower; 3.0-liter supercharged V-6/electric hybrid, 380 horsepower
Transmission: 8-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): V-6: 17/23; TDI: 20/29; Hybrid: 20/24 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: good; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Premium touchscreen infotainment system
Notable standard features on this model: All-wheel drive, 18-inch alloy wheels, adaptive HID headlamps, LED running lights, power front seats, iPod hookup, LED tail lamps, post-collision braking
Notable options on this model: 19- and 20-inch wheels, leather seats, wood-trimmed interior, adaptive cruise control, forward collision avoidance, lane assist, blind spot warning, towing package, panoramic sunroof, around-view camera
You might also be considering: Acura MDX, Jeep Grand Cherokee, Mercedes-Benz M-class

Much effort has gone into refreshing and improving the 2015 Volkswagen Touareg. Note if you will the four-bar grille and new lighting clusters that distinguish the Touareg’s face. The wheels on all models are new, and the rear-end features LED tail lamps. Inside, the lovely cabin is appointed with LED lighting, trimmed with chrome, and accented with wood. Buttons and switchgear are new as well. Outside and inside, the Touareg is simple and uncluttered, if a bit conservative. There are three powertrains. The 3.6-liter V-6 has to motivate the nearly 4700-pound vehicle (which increases to 5260 pounds in Hybrid form). We would prefer the TDI, which gets 406 pound-feet of torque from the turbo-diesel, direct-injection 3.0-liter V-6. For one thing, it would perform much better when equipped with the towing package that enables the Touareg to pull a 7700-pound trailer. Under best conditions, the TDI has a 765-mile range. Every model, even the Hybrid, has the same advanced eight-speed automatic transmission with manual gear control. The Hybrid can reach a speed of 31 mph in electric driving mode, and it gains efficiency from stop-start technology and regenerative braking. The luxurious Executive V-6 has a heated steering wheel and rear seats, a 10-speaker audio system, and a 360-degree exterior camera.

New for 2015

Updated exterior and interior, new wheels, interior appointments, Hybrid model gets supercharged engine.

title: 2015 Volkswagen Tiguan
subTitle: Sporty and premium.
promoTeaserSmall: Sporty and premium.
promoTeaser: Sporty and premium.
metaKeywords: 2015 Volkswagen Tiguan; Volkswagen; VW; SUV; crossover; sport-utiilty; sport-ute; German
metaDescription: Sporty and premium. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: SUV/crossover
Price range: $27,120–$40,490 (includes destination)
Trim levels: S, SE, SEL, R-Line
Engine: 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 200 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): FWD: 21/26; AWD: 20/26 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: good (moderate overlap front, side, roof strength, head restraints & seats), marginal (small overlap front); National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 overall rating
Our favorite standard feature: Satellite radio
Notable standard features on this model: Roof rails, automatic transmission, rearview camera
Notable options on this model: All-wheel drive, HID headlamps with LED running lights, panoramic sunroof, premium audio, leather seats
You might also be considering: Ford Escape, Honda CR-V, Toyota RAV4

Positioning the 2015 Volkswagen Tiguan as the most premium and sporty compact crossover may be a good idea, but we just see it as being an expensive choice. It certainly does take the premium approach in powertrain, with a turbocharged, direct-injection 2.0-liter four cylinder engine generating 200 horsepower and giving solid thrust with 207 pound-feet of torque. The six-speed automatic transmission has a sport mode for snappy performance. The main addition this year is an improved standard infotainment system, which includes an iPod connection, rearview camera, satellite radio, and premium audio. The Car-Net connected services smartphone app allows remote sending of commands and monitors functions and vehicle location. Emergency assistance is also part of the app. The other notable change for 2015 is the new rear bumper on the Tiguan R-line. This is the sportiest, best-equipped model, and it climbs over the $40,000 barrier. The R-line has paddle shifters, 19-inch wheels, a sport suspension, leather upholstery, and a roof-mounted spoiler. Towing capability for all models is 2200 pounds.

New for 2015

Improved standard infotainment system, restyled bumper for the R-line model.

title: 2015 Volkswagen Passat
subTitle: Midsize premium.
promoTeaserSmall: Midsize premium.
promoTeaser: Midsize premium.
metaKeywords: 2015 Volkswagen Passat; Volkswagen; VW; sedan; German
metaDescription: Midsize premium. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Sedan
Price range: $22,160–$36,815 (includes destination)
Trim levels: 1.8T, 1.8T Sport, TDI, V-6
Engines: 1.8-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 170 horsepower; 2.0-liter turbo-diesel four-cylinder, 150 horsepower; 3.6-liter V-6, 280 horsepower
Transmissions: 5- or 6-speed manual, 6-speed automatic, 6-speed dual-clutch automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 1.8T/1.8T Sport, manual: 24/35; 1.8T/1.8T Sport, manual: 24/36; TDI, manual: 30/44; TDI, automatic: 30/42; V-6: 20/28 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 overall rating
Our favorite standard feature: Automatic headlamps
Notable standard features on this model: Air conditioning, hill-hold assist, multifunction steering wheel, power mirrors, six-speaker audio, Bluetooth connectivity, 60/40 split rear seat
Notable options on this model: 18- and 19-inch wheels, premium audio, eight-way power front seats, keyless access and pushbutton start, navigation
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord,Toyota Camry

While you probably won’t try to break the Guinness Book of World Records mark for lowest fuel consumption by a non-hybrid car, you should know the Passat TDI holds it at 77.99 mpg. The feat was achieved with the new turbo-diesel direct-injection 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine. Along with generating 150 horsepower and an impressive 236 pound-feet of torque, this engine provides excellent throttle response and operates smoothly. With the six-speed manual transmission it provides a cruising range of up to 814 miles. A six-speed dual-clutch automatic is also available in the TDI. For value, check out the Passat Wolfsburg Edition. It adopts all the standard features of the 1.8T S and adds a six-speed automatic transmission, unique wheels, a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, and heated front seats. The Wolfsburg Edition also has satellite radio and an iPod hookup. The V-6 Passat has a long list of standard features including rain-sensing wipers, a sunroof, premium touchscreen infotainment with navigation, and a rearview camera. The spacious, tastefully appointed cabin has just the right amount of bright ornamentation; the leather-trimmed seats with micro-fabric inserts are supremely comfortable. In its top trim, the 3.6-liter V-6 model is outfitted with a six-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission, which provides rapid-fire gear changes. The Passat isn’t the most obvious choice among midsize sedans, but it’s a good one.

New for 2015

Volkswagen’s new 2.0-liter turbo-diesel four-cylinder, rearview camera more widely available, rain-sensing wipers on SEL trims.

subTitle: Nipped and tucked.

pageElements.text:
Type: Sedan, wagon
Price range: $18,145–$32,715 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Jetta, 1.8T, TDI, GLI, Hybrid
Engines: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 115 horsepower; 1.8-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 170 horsepower; 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 210 horsepower; 2.0-liter turbo-diesel four-cylinder, 150 horsepower; 2.5-liter five-cylinder, 170 horsepower; 1.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder/electric hybrid, 170 horsepower
Transmissions: 5- or 6-speed manual, 6-speed automatic, 6speed dual-clutch automatic, 7-speed dual-clutch automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 2.0-liter, manual: 25/34; 2.0-liter, automatic: 23/34; 1.8T: 25/37; TDI, manual: 31/46; TDI, automatic: 31/45; GLI: 23/33; Hybrid: 42/48; SportWagen, manual: 23/33; SportWagen, automatic: 23/30; SportWagen TDI, manual: 30/42; SportWagen TDI, automatic: 29/39; Hybrid: 42/48 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 overall rating
Our favorite standard feature: One-touch power windows
Notable standard features on this model: Air conditioning, Bluetooth connectivity, multifunction steering wheel, cruise control
Notable options on this model: Adaptive HID headlamps, 17- and 18-inch wheels, premium audio
You might also be considering: Ford Focus, Honda Civic, Mazda 3, Toyota Corolla, Toyota Prius

Major styling revisions and added content strive to make the 2015 Volkswagen Jetta more premium than its competitors. Designers have created a new face with a different grille and three horizontal fins, similar to the Passat. An available lighting package adds HID headlamps with LED running lights, trimmed by touches of chrome. Aerodynamic efficiency improvement was also a priority, and the new bumper advances this cause. The Jetta 1.8T and TDI have an active shutter in the grille for even less drag and better thermal efficiency. For the value-conscious buyer, the Jetta lineup starts with the 2.0L S with a generous assortment of standard features. This year’s Jetta Sport is a value-package with SE trim and includes the turbocharged 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine, a sport suspension and seats, two-tone 17-inch wheels, fog lamps, and navigation with a rearview camera. It’s offered with five-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission. The GLI has 18-inch wheels, a honeycomb grille, LED tail lamps and dual-outlet exhaust; its turbocharged 2.0-liter four produces 210 horsepower. Extreme measures for the lowest drag give the Jetta Hybrid—one of the best of its type that we’ve driven—its own face, and the turbocharged 1.4-liter teams with electric drive for a performance advantage against hybrid competitors. Not receiving the sedan’s revisions, the Jetta SportWagen carries over as 2014.5 model and keeps the 2.5-liter five-cylinder engine.

New for 2015

New front and rear styling.

Engines: 1.8-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 170 horsepower; 2.0-liter turbo-diesel four-cylinder, 150 horsepower; 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 210 horsepower; 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 292 horsepower; electric motor, 115 horsepower, lithium-ion battery, 24.2 kWh
Transmissions: 5- or 6-speed manual, 6-speed automatic, 6-speed dual-clutch automatic, single-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 1.8T, manual: 25/37; 1.8T, automatic: 25/36; TDI, manual: 30/45; TDI, automatic: 31/43; GTI, manual: 25/34; GTI, automatic: 25/33; Golf R, manual: 23/31; Golf R, automatic: 23/30; e-Golf: 126/105 (mpg-e) (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Turbocharged engine
Notable standard features on this model: Bluetooth connectivity, 5.8-inch touchscreen, satellite radio, iPod integration, post-collision braking
Notable options on this model: Fender premium audio, automatic climate control, lighting package (HID adaptive headlamps and LED daytime running lights)
You might also be considering: Ford Focus, Honda Civic, Hyundai Elantra, Kia Forte, Mazda 3, Subaru Impreza

The new seventh-generation Volkswagen Golf went on sale last fall, aiming to be something to everybody and pretty nearly succeeding. The Golf is slightly larger, more aerodynamically efficient, and has a bolder look. Choose from turbocharged gasoline or diesel engines or the e-Golf’s battery-powered electric drive. The value-priced Golf Launch Edition comes with a 5.8-inch touchscreen infotainment system, Bluetooth connectivity, satellite radio, and an iPod interface. Post-collision braking, which minimizes the effect of a second impact, is also standard. The GTI has a 210-horsepower, four-cylinder engine under the hood and jaunty plaid upholstery and bright trim inside the cabin. The TDI has a quiet new turbo-diesel, direct-injection 2.0-liter four-cylinder that makes 150 horsepower and an impressive 236 pound-feet of torque. For the most demanding enthusiast drivers, the 292-horsepower Golf R rips from 0 to 60 mph in just 4.9 seconds and puts down the power with all-wheel drive. LED accents and a scowling face indicate the R’s serious intent, which is emphasized by the four exhaust outlets the R displays as it passes. Built on the same assembly line in sequence with all other Golf models, the fully electric e-Golf visually separates itself with energy-efficient LED headlamps and unique wheels and badges. It uses battery power and three driving modes to cover as many as 83 miles on a single charge. There are also three braking modes to generate current on the go.

New for 2015

An all-new model

title: 2015 Volkswagen CC
subTitle: It’s a sedan, it’s a coupe!
promoTeaserSmall: It’s a sedan, it’s a coupe!
promoTeaser: It’s a sedan, it’s a coupe!
metaKeywords: 2015 Volkswagen CC; Volkswagen; VW; sedan; German
metaDescription: It’s a sedan, it’s a coupe! JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Sedan
Price range: $33,860–$44,440 (includes destination)
Trim levels: 2.0T Sport, 2.0T R-Line, 2.0T Executive, 3.6 VR6 4Motion Executive
Engines: 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 200 horsepower; 3.6-liter V-6, 280 horsepower
Transmissions: 6-speed manual, 6-speed automatic, 6-speed dual-clutch automatic,
Fuel economy (mpg): 2.0 manual: 21/32; 2.0 automatic: 22/31; V-6: 17/25 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: good (moderate overlap front, side, roof strength, head restraints & seats), marginal (small overlap front);
National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Heated front seats
Notable standard features on this model: HID headlamps, LED daytime running lamps, navigation, 12-way power-adjustable front seats, automatic climate control with humidity sensing
Notable options on this model: Ventilated front seats, 18-inch wheels
You might also be considering: Acura TSX, Buick Regal, Nissan Maxima

Where did that light come from? It was the Volkswagen CC, whose adaptive headlamps swivel up to 15 degrees to peek around corners. They’re among the standard features of this sleek four-door. Even the 2.0T Sport, the lowest trim level, includes many premium standard features. Besides advanced lighting, it has rain-sensing windshield wipers, navigation, and a rearview camera. Like the R-Line and Executive, it has a turbocharged, direct-injection 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine good for 200 horsepower. A six-speed manual transmission is standard, with a six-speed dual-clutch automatic being available.

In the 2.0T R-Line, the automatic gearbox, which is still optional, features paddle shifters. You can tell the R-Line by its unique face with a large lower air intake, projector-style fog lamps and R-Line logo on the grille. It also has side skirts and unique 18-inch wheels. The 2.0T Executive adopts the automatic gearbox as standard, has its own 18-inch wheels, and piles on the premium features, including a more advanced navigation and infotainment system. Crowning the lineup is the VR6 4Motion Executive. The V-6 and six-speed automatic transmission team up with all-wheel drive for ultimate capability. Inside, the front seats are ventilated and the driver’s seat has a massage function. The premium audio system uses 10 speakers. In former years, Volvo and Saab were strong in this niche for luxuriously outfitted and highly capable European sedans. Now the Volkswagen CC is formidable in their place.

New for 2015

Distinct 18-inch Sport and Executive trim wheels, and more aggressive styling on the R-line model.

title: 2015 Volkswagen Eos
subTitle: On its farewell tour.
promoTeaserSmall: On its farewell tour.
promoTeaser: On its farewell tour.
metaKeywords: 2015 Volkswagen Eos; Volkswagen; VW; convertible; German
metaDescription: On its farewell tour. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Convertible
Price range: $37,010–$43,610 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Komfort, Final Edition, Executive
Engine: 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 200 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed dual-clutch automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 22/30 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: good (moderate overlap front, side, head restraints & seats); National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Retractable hardtop with integrated panoramic sunroof
Notable standard features on this model: Leather-wrapped multifunction steering wheel, dual-zone automatic climate system, heated front seats, navigation
Notable options on this model: Parking assistance, rearview camera, wood-trimmed interior
You might also be considering: BMW 228i convertible, Mini Cooper convertible,

In its last year of production, the Volkswagen Eos, a luxurious small convertible, falls into place between the Mini Cooper convertible and BMW 228i Convertible. It’s well-equipped and luxurious. The powertrain is sporty, with 200 horsepower coming from the turbocharged direct-injection 2.0-liter four-cylinder and with the dual-clutch automatic gearbox providing nearly instantaneous shifting. But it’s still a front-wheel-drive chassis, which won’t return the same dynamic responses as the BMW.

The Eos’s chief claim to fame is the hardtop (with incorporated power-operated sunroof) that retracts in 25 seconds. The roof’s five elements neatly sandwich themselves and drop as smoothly as deviled ham. Leave the top up, and the trunk offers 10.5-cubic-feet of storage. As standard equipment, a wind blocker reduces turbulence in the passenger compartment. To counteract roofless vulnerability, the Eos has automatic rollover support, with support elements shooting out of their housings in a quarter-second if a possible rollover or collision is detected. The Eos lineup starts with the Komfort, which has the power sunroof, leather-wrapped steering wheel, and heated front seats. A five-inch touchscreen with navigation are also standard. For 2015, the Final Edition knocks last year’s Sport out of the lineup. It has a more aggressive stance, a lowered, sport-tuned suspension, 18-inch wheels, and black-and-beige leather seats. The Executive indulges with unique wheels, wood interior trim, and a 10-speaker audio system. The only hardtop convertible with a power sunroof—why didn’t we think of that?

New for 2015

Final Edition model.
